  4140. To possibly improve my chances for toothbrush longevity, I rinse the brush head and toothbrush body briefly under running water after usage, dry it lightly with a hand towel, and flick it a few times to shake the excess water off the brush head.

All Reviews

  1. Good equipment the only thing it needs is a brush that can clean the teeth better in the curves.
  2. Love Sonicare since my mom bought me my first one for Xmas after I had moved away. It broke, the button caved in but I love how clean my mouth/teeth feel after using it (compared to a regular manual brush). Once you go.. sonicare... you never go back. Well, I certainly didn't want to. I do wish this model came with two handles, but instead my wife and I just take turns and switch out our own heads. Awesome brush, but honestly i don't use the 'sensitive', 'massage' or 'Max Care' options so I guess I'll be looking for the less expensive one next time.
  3. This toothbrush cleans well, but only lasted me 2 years, I do also replace the brush heads every 3 months or so, and I traveled with it once for two weeks.<br />I'm disappointed that this $120 toothbrush only lasted 2 years + the brush heads I replaced, definitely too costly. Now I know how electric toothbrush can stop working in 2 years, I will not buy another expensive toothbrush.
  4. My electric toothbrush holder died after 2 years. For the money I expect a product to last longer. I did like it while it worked and my dentist could tell my teeth were in better condition (I brush too hard with regular tooth brushes). I would not buy again though due to the price.
  5. Replacement love this product.
  6. I upgraded to this model after my old elite bit the dust, and I couldn't be happier. I feel like I've just left the dentist after each use. The customer service crew couldn't be friendlier or more helpful - very pleased with this purchase.
  7. I've used Sonicare rechargeable toothbrushes since they were introduced. No problems with ANY of them. This system with the Sanitizer is the best one yet. No Bulky holder for the toothbrush that gets filled with...and has to be cleaned weekly, and the compact brush heads are great for smaller mouths and control when brushing. Flex care is the best. All my Sonicare Batteries have held up. I think it may be user specific for those that complain about the battery The battery has always served me well when I use it on the road. The noise? All electronic toothbrushes I've tried are noisy. Without my Sonicare, I'd be cleaning my teeth in a glass. I'll trade noise, which I hate, for in tact teeth anytime!
  8. So, I have been using electric toothbrushes for a few years. I have tried various brands; you know, the ones when you purchase another toothbrush when the battery dies because its too much of a hassle to get to the battery. Needless to say, there wasn't an inexpensive brand I have not tried. My routine visits to the dentist have been less than desirable. I have had cavities and a root canal. What prompted me in considering the FlexCare stemmed from a close, self-examination of my teeth and gums and I was displeased. I booked an appointment to the dentist but it was a TWO MONTH wait time and I needed to do something ASAP. So, after research, the reviews really spoked for themselves. I searched Amazon and used Google to get the low down on the best at home cleaning options and mostly all pointed to Sonicare products. I particurlarly chose this brand do the sanitizing feature. Call me a sucker for gimmicks but I am a huge germ-a-phobe. Plus being able to have two brush heads in the sanitizing unit allowed for me to use different brushes during the morning and evening...another plus! The unit itself allows for multiple cleaning options: (basic clean, sensitive setting, message setting, 1 minute clean and 3 minute clean). The performance of this toothbrush is unmatched. The power actually caught me off-guard. Of course, I made the terrible mistake of taking the toothbrush out of my mouth during operation...HUGE MESS. The first two brushes were noticeable but by the third day, I handled all settings with no problems. In two weeks of usage I could see a difference in my teeth. A natural whiteness appeared, my teeth FELT clean, and my gums and tongue have actually benefit from usage. My hope is that with continued usage by the time my dental appointment arrives, I will not need root scaling/planing and that my plague build-up will be minimal. Obviously proper oral health and regular dental visits are the best method. However, for those of us thatfeel off track, you first two steps is to get this toothbrush (and don't look back) and find a dentist you feel comfortable with and create a plan to regain optimal oral health. I have no \\"cons\\" on this product. I know many were not happy with the non-replaceable battery. I purchased this unit that gave TWO Flexcare toothbrushes along with two cleaning heads. If I can get 5 year usage, I will be pleased. I would recommend users couple the FlexCare along with the Waterpick Ultra Jet (another excellent product). Tom's of Maine makes excellent mouthwashes that do not include alcohol or saccharin. Colgate Total appears to get the highest reviews for cleaning and post-cleaning protection. I also use Sensodyne's Pronamel toothpaste. I cannot reiterate enough that with the power the FlexCare provides, I cannot imagine any other brush really doing an effective job at cleaning. I will definitely come back and following up after my second dental dentist to discuss improvements with using the FlexCare. If you are hesitant in buying, just think dropping this amount of money on a toothbrush will likely push you to to upkeep a regular brushing habit. LOL Gave it 5 stars because the performance is unmatched. Considering the higher price, most cannot afford to have this even though it should be attainable and because of that, overall I would rate 4.5 stars.
  9. If you've never owned a Sonicare, you will probably find this toothbrush to be really noisy and much heavier than a normal toothbrush, but that's because it actually cleans significantly better than a toothbrush, leaving you with that \\"just got a dental cleaning\\" feeling -- versus those other vibrating/rotating brushes that are basically designed for the lazy brusher and don't really clean any better. (If you've owned an earlier model, you'll find this one is lighter and quieter than those. It's worth the upgrade!) It's not loud enough to wake up my wife while I get ready in the morning -- whereas my electric shaver is louder and will wake her up. As for battery life, I've been using this model for 9 months with no problems. It can easily go a week between charging (even now), and I've never needed the travel charger that it comes with (but it's nice to have one should I be going somewhere for more than a week). I've read the manual, and it is true that the battery cannot be replaced once dead, but I'm confident I'll be able to get at least another year before that happens. The battery seems as good today as it was when I first opened it -- wish I could say the same for my laptop and cordless tools.
  10. I have been thinking about getting an electric toothbrush for years. I decided that for my birthday I would treat myself to this one. The first decision I had to make was a rotating head (Oral B) or back-and-forth (Sonicare). I went by word of mouth and reading reviews. Surprisingly, everyone I know has a sonicare toothbrush. The second decision was whether or not to get the bells and whistles or a basic brush. I liked all the different settings this one offered. I have sensitive teeth and was worried about agitating my teeth. It helped that it was on sale for the same price as the one without the sanitizer. I have actually been able to switch to regular toothpaste instead of sensitive toothpaste. My only concern was of the reviews that mentioned the toothbrush being loud. As a newbie, I've found it to be quite manageable. I can brush my teeth in the morning and not worry about my boyfriend waking up. The most difficult thing to figure out was how to keep all the toothpaste in my mouth will transitioning the brush around my mouth. The brush head is small enough to keep your mouth closed and still maneuver around. Overall, I'm kicking myself for not making the purchase earlier. I'm getting addicted to the dentist clean feel. I now brush 4 times a day instead of 2.
  11. Frankly, I can't say enough about this toothbrush... First, though, my teeth have been a mess for years. This is mostly my fault due to a fear of dentist for a variety of reasons (including the time when the dentist inadvertently stuck me in the arm with a novocaine needle) which kept me from the dentist's office for a long time. My wife finally convinced me to go to a dentist, and I found a terrific one. Anyway, after a lot of work, my teeth are finally nice and healthy, and I bought this toothbrush - Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer - to help keep my teeth in top shape. I couldn't be happier! After every use, I feel like I've just had my teeth professionally cleaned, and it's actually a lot of fun using the thing. I usually start off with the regular \\"Clean\\" function taking care to brush each \\"quad\\" section in my mouth (I usually do this twice), followed by the \\"Message\\" section to go over my gums. The end result is a squeakly clean, refreshed mouth that feels great. If you get this toothbrush, you may experience some tingling around your gums when you first start out, but you'll quickly get used to it. Oh, and I also like the onboard sanitizer to keep the brush clean and germ free. This is truly a wonderful product if you want to keep your teeth strong and healthy, and to give you a smile that'll light up a room!
  12. I have enjoyed using electric toothbrushes for years as I feel they are far superior to manual ones. At the recommendation of my dentist recently, I decided to give the Sonicare a try. The design is different and the brush is a different shape, more like a traditional toothbrush. The rapid vibration takes a bit to get use to but there is no denying the exceptionally clean feeling after the 2 minute timer cuts the power cycle. It is the closest clean to the \\"6 month\\" Dental cleaning I have experienced. I recomment this product for it's ability, design and features although I am unsure what difference the \\"UV light\\" sanitizer really makes. There are plenty of features to utilize like the \\"quadrant timer\\" which alows you to break down the 2 minute timer into 4 sections for the most effective and even brushing. The brush IS very pricey but consider this product if you really care about your dental upkeep.<br /><br />****Amendment**** 2 1/2 years later and this toothbrush system is still working flawlessly. Awesome investment! : )
  13. This Philips Sonicare FlexCare is an update to my previous sonicare. The massage cycle is a treat to my gums. I like the fact there are options to cleaning and massage cycles. The sanitizer is a plus. I have been very pleased with this product.
  14. I had the Intelliclen system I was happy with it in till I learned that sonicare no longer made brush heads for it what ever reason which was stupid but whatever I think it was mainly because they wanted people to upgrade.... So I Bought the 900+ flex-care after the first time I'm glad I did... This little handle packs a punch. it has to be the most powerful sonicare Ive ever experienced with all the options as well ? where could I go? Some people say it's noisy I do not see how this is. It is just has loud/quite as any other sonicare So I do not know what they are talking about.. I think they best Option really is the Quad-placer I'm glad they kept that on there. I personally like it and surprised no one else is even talked about it. Plus having the U.V. Sanitizer on board is nice only takes 10mins to run a cycle. the whole unit really don't take up a lot of room if you have a typical sink. though if you have something like a pedestal you might need a shelf or something because it wont fit. It dose come with two brush size's I personally only the bigger one it also come's with a smaller one. I really hope Sonicare plans on keeping this one around longer then 4 years unlike my last one. If you are looking for a Top notch rechargeable toothbrush you would be crazy not to buy this one..
  15. I've used several Sonicare toothbrushes in the past and feel like they are the reason I've such healthy gums. As a physician I'm very aware that healthy gums are one of the most important things for HEART health, too! So I really have valued my Sonicare brushes. And at the age of 58 I have perfect gums and perfect heart health, inspite of being overweight and sedentary. However, I'm very disappointed in this new model. First off the brush head is really small. I cannot believe the difference in the amount of gunk that remains between my teeth after using the unit the full cleaning program. I've actually gone through several cycles and the trash remains. If I look in my makeup mirror I can actually see it! Now don't you think two full cycles with a Sonicare should get that out??? I guarantee my old one would have. So, I have to floss more diligently than I have in years now. It seems to me that this unit cleans tooth surfaces just fine, but that is not what I use an electric toothbrush for. I want the gum stimulation, which is adequate by virtue of the sonic vibration--you don't need that silly \\"massage\\" setting. And I want really excellent crud removal from between teeth, which I find inadequate with this unit. As to the brush sanitizer: I figure if that nasty sludge that used to build up in the handle of my old Sonicare didn't kill me, surely I don't need an infrared cleaner for the brush head! Perhaps if I had gum disease, or some disease spread by oral contamination, I'd think it was a good idea, but frankly? I think it's unnecessary.
  16. This is my first electric toothbrush, been using it for a year now and I love it. My dentist recommended the switch to this electric because I couldn't break the bad habit of brushing too hard at the gumline. This brush gets my teeth \\"dentist clean\\" while being gentler on my gums, with much less sensitivity overall as an added bonus. For those used to small toothbrushes (size 30), the compact head works nicely. The full size is much too large for me, but works perfectly for my husband. We store both heads in the sanitizer and run it after each round of brushing; tried running it once a day as stated in the manual but noticed some bacterial growth at the base of the brushes (where the color code rings snap on) after a few days, so went back to twice daily and all was well. The travel charger, case and head covers are handy - no more of those awkward, giant 'snap in' travel toothbrushes! The unit is pricey, and having to change out the heads every three months means another $30 or so per person a year, but for us the benefits have been worth the extra cost.
  17. I looked forward to receiving this toothbrush after reading reviews and the product description. I have used it for about six weeks and just can't get past a couple of the design flaws. First, the on/off switch is in a poor location. I keep accidentally turning the toothbrush on and off while brushing, even when I make a conscious effort to avoid the switch. Second, the toothbrush throws toothpaste everywhere when running. My mirror is continually getting splattered with toothpaste and the toothpaste continually dribbles down the brush and handle when in use. I have not had these problems with other electric toothbrushes. Unfortunately, I am now in the market for another unit....
  18. A few years ago - in my quest to find an electric toothbrush per my dentist's instructions led me to stand in front of the products meticulously comparing one vs. another, did it do this that and the other, price point, etc. Oral B won for 1 reason, price and I had a coupon at Costco and their replacement heads were cheaper. That was a few years ago. I was under the impression that all electric toothbrushes were created equally. Although my teeth's health improved, there are still issues. My last cleaning was very intense at the dentist.<br /><br />My Oral B is almost dead - it's been 2 years, the battery will hold for a couple of days, but not over a week like it used to. The search for the next toothbrush started.<br /><br />Surprisingly, I didn't have a hard choice with picking Sonicare. I see the demo/advertising whatever at my dentist. I also knew I wasn't happy with OralB - because my teeth didn't feel clean, and I knew that it was definitely not getting into all the contours of my mouth.<br /><br />My first use with my Sonicare<br />I felt like a light bulb exploded in my head. It was ridiculous how clean my teeth felt, as if I just had them cleaned and polished at my dentist. How is that possible with only 1 session? Was my Oral B that bad? Maybe this was a fluke. A few more days went by, my teeth stayed with that smooth clean feeling. It's been a few weeks and I'm hooked.<br /><br />What's so different about it - the brush head for one. Oral B has a circular head, it spins with use. With the Sonicare, it oscillates back and forth, mimicking real tooth brushing motion. There are contours of the brush so it gets between the teeth. The bristles are stiff to clean my teeth but gentle enough to get into the gums w/o causing bleeding. Oral B brush heads were rough and painful.<br /><br />This product is great for small mouths, hard to reach areas/crevices and for sensitive teeth.<br /><br />I like that it has options for sensitive and regular or whitening. I like that it's timed so I know I'm doing the right amount. The toothbrush will shut itself off after 2 minutes. It'll be good for kids too, so they're not doing a swipe and say they're done.<br /><br />I'm very impressed with this product, very glad I got it and can't wait until my next dentist appointment. I've had it for a few weeks and notice not only are my teeth cleaner, but they are truly whiter.<br /><br />UPDATE:<br />I've had it for a few months - went for my cleaning and my dental hygienist noticed my teeth/gums were improving. She asked me what I did differently and told her I switched toothbrushes. HA!!! LOVE LOVE LOVE my toothbrush!nt. The toothbrush will shut itself off after 2 minutes. It'll be good for kids too, so they're not doing a swipe and say they're done. I'm very impressed with this product, very glad I got it and can't wait until my next dentist appointment. I've had it for a few weeks and notice not only are my teeth cleaner, but they are truly whiter. UPDATE: I've had it for a few months - went for my cleaning and my dental hygienist noticed my teeth/gums were improving. She asked me what I did differently and told her I switched toothbrushes. HA!!! LOVE LOVE LOVE my toothbrush!

  20. We've been using Philips Sonicare toothbrushes since they were first introduced. If you've never used one, you will be amazed at the huge positive difference they make in your tooth and gum health. Using a Sonicare twice a day preceeded by flossing, has resulted in perfect or near-perfect gum checks every dental visit. This model builds on their Philips' expertise, and works even better than the original models. The pop-off heads are a huge improvement over the screw-ons, as many other reviewers have said. My only gripe is that the mode/routine button is right where I have been used to holding the handle with my thumb. It took me a few times to realize that the toothbrush was changing speeds because I had accidentally hit the button. I'm slowly learning to keep my thumb away from it; it's not enough of an issue to downgrade my rating.

  26. I bought this brush six months ago on recommendation of my dentist. It didn't matter how much I brushed or flossed, I was still having issues. So, I broke down and decided to spend the money. Today, I went to my 6 month check up and the hygienist barely had to do anything. She said I was doing an excellent job. I am so happy because I've had already a couple of oral surgeries and sure don't want to go through it again. Spending $150 now, will potentially save me thousands in surgery. Best purchase ever!
  27. A SonicCare toothbrush is definitely a change from a normal brushing. It is at first a bit hard and surprising to use for people not accustom to it / first try - especially, if other parts than the bristle touches your teeth, the sensation is close to a drilling machine at the dentists (so avoid contact of the brush plastic extender with your enamel). When handled properly, the end result is a definite fresh and crisp feel: your teeth feel super-smooth and this, in a few mnts of handling (a result you cannot achieve in the same amount of time with a standard brush). I use the timer and it tells me when to change area. However, set it to \\"sensitive\\" as the \\"clean\\" mode was far too strong and may get your gum to bleed. Other than that, I have not used my regular brush since I purchased this item (it is more efficient to use the Sonic). The battery charge last about a week unplugged for a normal usage (2/3 times a day brushing). Finally, use the small brush: I was tempted to use the largest one being accustom to standard tooth brush but the smaller one is best fit for electric toothbrush.
  28. I received this product faster than anticipated and so far it has worked well. We'll see what the results are during my next dentist visit.
  29. I had the original sonicare which served me well for many years till the electronics quit. Got this new flexcare but I am disappointed. First of all it is not as vigorous a vibration as the original so it does not feel like it is cleaning as well. That is not the worst part though. There is a defect. Perhaps just mine or perhaps systemic. If I press more that just a little the vibration stops. Sometimes I barely put any pressure at all. It has gotten worse over time. I can get around it by putting my finger on the back of the brush stem so it does not move back and press up against whatever it is inside that stops the. These things are sealed so I don't want to crack the thing open and try fix it. Considering how much I paid for this model I am very disappointed. My recommendation is to get the less expensive models. Either the one that takes the same brush heads or the one that uses the screw on angled brush head. The multiple settings, buttons, and LED's on this thing are just useless gimmicks IMHO. I guarantee you the only setting you need and will use is the normal one! The UV sanitizer is perhaps a bit more useful but still not necessary. One other thing with sonicare in general. You have to buy the expensive sonicare replacement heads and these heads are designed to not last too long. The newer ones even more so IMHO. The razor manufacturers play the same tricks but I digress.

  31. DON'T BUY IT ! The Sonicare toothbrush is good, but THEIR CUSTOMER SERVICE SUCKS ! Bought one in Dec 2009 for $100+, and the shaft went bad 2 months ago, shaking very badly. Called up Sonic Care Customer Service. They confirmed it's still under warranty, sent me a replacement unit, and asked me to sent the defective one back in the same box, and I did. This replacement brush stops working today, after only 2 months of use. It just hums but does not vibrate when turned on. Called Customer Service, and they REFUSED to replace this replacement unit that they just sent me 2 months ago, claiming that the 8-digit number on its bottom (08-08-28, I guess for Aug. 28, 2008) shows that is out of warranty. Asked to speak to a supervisor, and got Corey R. on the line. Cory confirmed that \\"080828\\" means that this replacement unit came from a production batch of hundreds of brushes made on Aug. 28, 2008. I asked Corey why they replaced a defective unit under warranty with one that was made in Aug. 2008, that goes out within 2 months, and for which they refuse to replace because it's out of warranty. He said they normally don't do that. But he doesn't have the records of the replacement unit they sent me. He still refuses to replace the \\"replacement unit\\" because it is itself out of warranty now ! Don't you love this warped and amazing logic? Morale of the story? Decent but EXPENSIVE brushes AND VERY LOUSY CUSTOMER SERVICE who replaces defective products with OLD products that crap out soon afterward! For which they refuse to replace, because the replacement itself is now out of warranty ! So you have to shell out $100 for a new one ! Not only am I NOT buying another expensive Sonicare brush, am making sure that I get this message out far and wide on the Web to alert other consumers. No longer using Sonicare in Houston ;-)

  34. I have never had a Sonicare toothbrush that didn't break down. The first one I had was an older model with the cup tops, it broke down in the second year. My wife's Sonicare of the same model broke down within the first year. Last September I bought the newer model, Sonicare Flexcare, with the UV light; it broke down in less than one year. The price was $126. A replacement tooth brush is about $10 [[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]]. Kinda high. There is no excuse for such appliances that quickly break down, particularly at their high cost. (Is this truly planned obsolescence?) The batteries are not removable and they are likely the cause of the problem that Sonicare has yet to address. Since the last Sonicare broke down within one year of purchase, I called their customer support and they are sending me a replacement handle. I would not buy this product again and I am looking for a lower cost replacement electric toothbrush.
  35. I bought this to replace a Sonicare that suddenly died so I knew what I was getting: an exceptional toothbrush that cleans your teeth way better than a manual one does. My dentist recommended the Sonicare over other electric toothbrushes, but that doesn't mean the others aren't as good. I have no hard data that this the Sonic system is better than other pricey electric ones.<br /><br />However, all I wanted was a toothbrush, and one that took the same brush head as my old one did as I have 4 unused brush heads bought as replacements for both my husband and me. The only model that my replacement brush heads would fit is the one with the \\"sanitizer,\\" which I think is entirely unnecessary and which, of course, added to the price of the toothbrush.<br /><br />Philips makes different style brush heads for different models of their Sonic care system. It seems to me to be a way of making people buy new replacement brushes when their old ones get worn. You have to be very careful when buying a Sonicare of any model to replace an old one. If you aren't, you may well end up having to throw away any replacement brushes you already have. Since they don't specify names or types of brush heads, you have to examine the pictures closely to figure out which brush heads each model requires.

  39. This is the third one I've bought! The first one was great! So good that now two other people I know have one from me! When you go to a detist & get your teeth cleaned? How really clean your mouth feels? Well that's what the Sonicare does each time you brush! The toothbrush is informative too! Three green/yellow LEDs keep track of the battery power level. You have various cleaning modes too! A very well thought out toothbrush. The ultrasonic brushing cleans everything clean. You mouth would only feel cleaner if a professional had just cleaned it! The quality of the equipment is excellent. None of the cheap made-in-China-construction. Carefully crafted to give you best qualitity instrument. A beautiful blend of electronics & well thought out dental health. Well worth the money. Only complaint is why are the toothbrushes so very expensive? Don't see any constructon in them that justifys the nosebleed price. They do work excellently, however is Philips really making an outrageious profit on them? All-in-all a product well worth using if you want to keep your teeth really clean!

  41. I have had one before, but the brush would not stay on the handle, so it was time to order another. I love this brush and the options it has.
  42. I've owned several of these over the years. An innovative and terrific design and product. Consumer Reports gave it and the Rotary thumbs up. I bought the rotary Braum for a test. Forget it. CR missed this one by a mile.<br /><br /> The one I have now is a HX6932 with the sealed top to keep the crud out. It broke outside of warranty so I bought a new one. For a tool that's used 2-3 times a day I'm a happy camper. My shop tools should be this good.<br /><br /> So I cut it open for a post mortem exam. A tiny screw came loose that clamps the vibrating steel brush rod to the guts. This is a fix for broken units where the steel brush post wobbles around only! Drill a 3/16\\" hole in the case 1.5\\" below the end of the steel brush rod. The on/off switch is facing you. Get a tube of Locktite blue from your local auto parts supply store and put a drop on the loose Phillips screw before re- installing. Then plug the hole with Goop marine glue from Lowes. Good as new.er I hope.No warranty here especially if your clumsy.<br /><br /> Everybody write Phillips service and tell them to have their China supplier use Locktite. I have no connection with Locktite. I'm just an Engineer. Actually using a screw for this ap is totally STUPID.Lots of ways to do this at half the manufacturing cost. I think an ex GM engineer designed this part. At least it sure looks like their work. Did marketing do this on purpose to sell more units? ? Hmmm.
  43. The handle stopped working about a year after I purchased it. Philips sent a replacement. That stopped working just after the warranty for the original handset expired (they don't reset the warranty after they send you a new defective handset) and they told me there was nothing they could do. So I spent $176 plus the cost of replacement brushes on 2 defective handsets and they don't even have the courtesy to reset the warranty for a new device. Pathetic.
  44. We purchased this toothbrush in March 2010 and in April 2012 had the problem I've read about in other reviews -- the metal shaft that the brush heads attach to became loose, causing a really loud noise when operating the toothbrush. We didnt notice any lessening of brushing quality, but did start thinking of buying a new one. Just the handle is almost $100 and we assumed we'd just missed the 2-year warranty ..... Still, I called Philips customer care number (800-682-7664) just in case.<br /><br />And guess what? Because we had registered the product, we have an extra 6 months on the warranty!!!<br /><br />Philips sent a replacement handle right out (they do send a prepaid label and ask you to mail back the old one) and we got to keep the $130 we were about to shell out.<br /><br />I've used Sonicare for years and will continue. This is a really good model and compared to the older Elite:<br /><br />PROS<br />- Slimmer<br />- Cleaner head replacement (just the tip of the brush now)<br />- Sensitive mode<br />- Sanitizer on base to eliminate bacteria<br />- 2 week charge (great for vacations in Europe when charging is an issue - my old one only charged for 48hours I think!)<br />- Great customer service from Philips<br /><br />CONS<br />- expensive replacement heads<br />- these toothbrushes don't seem to last much beyond 2 years anymore<br /><br />Overall definitely worth the great cleaning you get. Though there are some good combo packages on the Elite through Costco (with extra handles and bases), for us it is worth staying with the newer model for the additional modes and features, and the gunk-free head replacements!

  46. I have owned four Sonicare toothbrushes over many years. First the original I picked up in the early 90's. Lasted for many years, actually cracked on the threads in 1996 and was replaced for free, I paid a nominal s/h charge.<br /><br />Wanted to get the new model with the smaller head design around 2003/2004 so I gave my dad the original one, which he still uses today! After about two or three years the new model simply wouldn't charge. Was told it probably had water damage and was out of warranty.<br /><br />Picked up a another new one around 2006. In 2009 that one stopped taking a charge. I was offered nothing from customer service.<br /><br />Bought this model in 2009 and now it has stopped taking a charge.<br /><br />The last two had the exact same problem. First it started turning itself on randomly. If you ever turned this on with the cover in place and sitting on the counter in a hotel room it is a little startling at four am. This continued until battery was fully discharged and then will not accept a new charge. The first one to suffer this fate I had stored on the charger every day. The most recent one I decided maybe that was the problem so I only charged when battery got low. Same end result. Again I get the water damage/out of warranty line from customer service.<br /><br />As far as a toothbrush goes they are the best. This model has a great design and really gets your teeth clean. The UV cleaner is gimmicky. Used it a few times but noticed it increases bristle wear and they aren't cheap. Different modes do nothing for me personally. Like the travel charger base as I travel alot and often for more than two weeks at a time.<br /><br />The orginal one that still works 20 years later, was not a Philips product. My history coincides with great product and customer service until Philips buys them out. I simply cannot believe that 20 years later we have gone backwards in rechargable battery technology. Maybe they have a marketing plan toforce consumers to buy a new one every few years. Great for Philips bottom line, not great for the consumer.<br /><br />So what am I going to do? Love the benefits of using the Sonicare but do I want to shell out $$ every three years. Philips has definetly found a way to make money on this product! I will be ordering the easy clean for $60 soon.<br /><br />How do I rate this? Well, the brush is clearly five stars. Philips would get zero stars but I still love Sonicare toothbrushes, so I settled on four stars.

  55. Generally speaking, this is a great product. I purchased it a few weeks ago to replace an approximately 2-year old Sonicare elite that my cleaning lady threw in the garbage. :rolleyes: I like the new style brush heads -- easy to snap on/off (2 of us share the brush) and they don't build up all the \\"gunk\\" of the older version. Battery seems to last much, much longer. I use the UV sanitizer about once a week; I have no problem getting the two brush heads (both large) in place. I have no idea how well it sanitizes, though; I'm not a chemistry lab. Now to the reason for the 3* review. The product gets dinged one star for a design flaw -- the mode setting button is poorly positioned so that my finger inadvertently changes the mode while I am in the middle of brushing. So all of a sudden the vibration diminishes, and then it will go to \\"massage\\" mode, which is a lower frequency pulsing. I've tried holding the brush differently, but it's not comfortable. The button should be disabled while the brush is in operation, if not moved to a different location on the handle. I've also dinged the product one star for what I feel is sham marketing by Philips. When I first purchased my Sonicare elite several years ago, they said to replace the heads every 6 months. Then at some point, all of a sudden, they're telling you to replace them every three months. Has the workmanship gotten that shoddy? Has some major study come out telling everyone to replace their brush every three months? No, it's just a ploy to sell more brushes, I imagine the margins are *very* high on the replacement heads. I doubt they cost more than a dollar to manufacture. (To be fair, I doubt Philips is the only one who has done this -- Arm & Hammer does it on their baking soda boxes as well, now you're supposed to put a new box in the fridge every 30 days -- used to be every 90 days. Ugh.) But in any event, I'm not falling for this, and I feel the companies should be held accountable. Somy part is to lower the rating by one star...
  56. I love this toothbrush. I replaced another Sonicare with this one because the old one was dying. This one had the sterilization feature that I wanted as well as two heads. It works great for my husband and I. I like the quick 1 minute cycle for a quick brush. No complaints!
  57. After having used 2 other models for a couple years each and then breaking, I was a little nervous about spending a lot of money on their top model. I have to admiot it was worth it and this is better than the 2 older models I had because it has a slimmer brush wand and also has speeds settings to chose from. I wish the brushes were a little less expensive, but I would still buy again.
  58. I really wonder if these are good for your gums. I suspect they are not. I stopped using mine when I got a horrible check up
  59. I have tried the Oral B electric toothbrush in the past but never really liked it. It was messy and didn't seem worth the bother. My periodontist recommended the Sonicare, so I gave in and bought one. Wow, when I'm done brushing with the Sonicare, my whole mouth feels intensely clean and my teeth are as smoothly polished as they get after a cleaning at the dentist. It's a night and day difference from the Oral B. Yes, electric toothbrushes are by nature messy, but this one is worth the bother.
  60. In the past, I used an Oral-B electric toothbrush, and I liked it quite a bit when I first got it. It cleaned better than a plain toothbrush, and did a lot of the work for me. I also used a Crest Spinbrush, and didn't really find it to be nearly as good as the Oral-B. It served its purpose, but it only did a moderate cleaning. There wasn't enough power to really get a great cleaning from it. Then my dentist recommended the Philips Sonicare line of toothbrushes. After looking at them, I decided on the FlexCare w/ UV Sanitizer for three reasons: 1) lots of cleaning options, 2) comes with two brush heads, 3) UV sanitizer. (I guess you could also say the reviews and dentist's recommendation played a role in the choice, too.) I had no idea how well this brush would work until I first tried it. Talk about a HUGE difference! It's not a cheap spinning brush head, it's just vibration. You may not think that some simple vibration will clean well. But MAN does it work! (This is similar to the sonic cleaners they use for jewelry and such, except for your teeth.) With the FlexCare, I don't work nearly as hard as I did with either of my other brushes, and I get a MUCH better cleaning from it. This is one incredible brush! Oh, and that tingly feeling in your lips and gums is kinda weird at first, but you'll learn to love it pretty quickly. It's the feeling of \\"clean\\"! And once I'm done, I pop the brush head into the sanitizer for a nice, clean brush the next time I use it. I haven't made too much use of all of the cleaning modes. I regularly use the standard \\"Clean\\" mode, which is good for everyday use. I tried out the \\"Max Care\\" mode, but it didn't do much for me. It gives you more time to massage your gums or clean additional places, I guess. I'll probably never use the 1-minute \\"Go Care\\" option, but it's nice to have if you're strict about brushing after meals and take the brush with you on the go. I have not tried the \\"Sensitive\\" option. I like that the brush heads don't twist to lock onto the brush. You just push them down until they slide right onto it. Great design. And the brush heads are long enough to keep gunk and toothpaste suds from making their way between the head and the base. I've yet to really clean between there at all, as it doesn't need it. Last, but not least, I love the little things on this brush. I like the battery level indicator. My Oral-B never had one, so I only knew if it was running low when it would slow down. Now I know how much battery I have left. (Not that I think I'll ever come close to draining it.) It comes with a soft travel case for keeping the brush and heads in, and a includes compact charger for travel that doesn't have the sanitizer. (An extra charger! Sweet!) The main unit has a rubberized handle grip to help you hold onto it with wet hands so it won't slip. And a 2-year warranty is nice. Hopefully it'll last much longer than that! Bottom line: This is quite possibly the most awesome toothbrush ever invented! I don't think I'll ever switch to anything else. It's THAT awesome.
  61. This was recommended by our hygenist. Since my husband and I have both had sinus infections this winter, the sanitizer has been wonderful. you can make sure your brushes are clean and sanitized and will not transfer germs back into your mouth. As for the Sonic toothbrush, it makes my teeth feel cleaner than they have ever been. My teeth are very close together and I am unable to get between them. With the Sonicare food stuck between my teeth comes out with no problem.
  62. I originally bought this brush back in 2007. The first two years it worked fine, but then all of sudden the brush heads started slipping off of the brush into my mouth. So I bought replacement heads (for way too much money)and the same happened with those three. I assumed after two years it was broken so I bought a new one. For the first three months it worked fine. Then, again, the brush heads started to slide off again. Again, I bought the replacement pack of heads. They all started to slide off. The second one in my pack CHIPPED MY TOOTH. So now I figured I had a serious problem here. I called customer support to see what the problem was. They told me that miraculously I was the only person who had ever contacted that particular support staff with the brush head problem. That I was the reason stating that I was taking off and replacing the brush heads incorrectly. How can that be if they only fit on one way? She said if I had kept my receipt then they could move the case to the escalation team. Sadly, not thinking I was going to have problems with a $100 toothbrush, I didn't keep it. My mistake. I trusted a multi-million dollar corporation and it's product to stand behind said product. Oh well, I would recommend a safer $15 spin-brush. At least those won't fly off into your mouth. Or, buy a $3 regular brush. It was good enough for generations before us!
  63. I have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for about 5 years now and am currently on my 3rd brush now with the Flexcare(For the record, I replaced my last 2 brushes due to upgrades, not product failure.) That being said, this one is by far my favorite for one VERY important reason - NO MORE GUNK in the brush heads. I have been relcutantly cleaning my Sonicare heads thoroughly after each use for years now, and still managed to get mold etc in them. No more with this brush! The head has been completely redesigned (even though the brush portion itself is basically the same) and no longer requires daily \\"maintenance\\" to keep it clean. For this reason alone, the brush is definitely worth the price. Outside of the new design, the brush has a few new features, but nothing too noteworthy in my opinion. The new brush head design is what really makes this brush better than their other offerings.

I'm going to stick with Sonicare, but will try the lower priced R710 -- same lightweight design & ProResults brushes as the FlexCare, but under $100 (of course, you lose the extra modes, but I can live with that).

  76. This is a great toothbrush, the 'soniccare' experience is far above any brush I've ever used. I can honestly say that I can feel the difference this toothbrush made versus my old (non sonic) electric toothbrush. My dentist recommended that I get a sonic toothbrush since I have mild gingivitis. When I went back 2 months later she said that things were looking better. I believe the toothbrush made a big difference. My only criticism is in regards to the price. I think some of the less expensive soniccare toothbrushes would do just as good of a job at a lower cost. The UV cleaner is fine. It's easy to use but I've never had an issue in the previous 28 years when I didn't UV clean my brushes. I never use the additional settings that the brush offers either. You can set it to either the normal 'clean' setting, 'sensitive', or 'massage'. There's also another setting for 'go care', or 'max care'. I can't remember what go care does but the max care sets the toothbrush for a normal 2 minute clean as well as a 1 minute gum massage setting. In summary, if you want all of the additional features it's a fantastic toothbrush and probably worth the additional price to you. If you want a straightforward toothbrush without all of the settings or cleaner I think you could save some money and get one of the other soniccare brushes.

The go care option seemed to make sense for the quickie midday brush.<br /><br />Now for the design flaw. The switch to change the brushing options is right where anyone with a good sized hand is going to hold the thing. I NEVER get through a brushing without changing the setting from clean to sensitive (which my teeth definitely aren't). So I have to stop the thing and reset it. Worse still is that the switch is sizable and takes almost no pressure to actuate. Worse still is that you have to switch it through four options to get it back to clean.<br /><br />Before you spend the small fortune to buy one of these, try to find one you can hold in your hand. You can hold it at the very end and not have this problem but that feels awkward to me.<br /><br />I may go back to my old one and ditch this.

  90. Like others, I have been a Sonicare user for years and years. After owning the FlexCare for about a year, the vibration and noise got increasingly worse, and then the metal post encased in a rubber sleeve finally broke, rendering the brush head inoperable. Philips sent another. Approximately 8 months later, same thing. They shipped another. I am now about to experience the exact same thing -- the head is vibrating wildly and making horrible noise. I can tell the metal post is about to give way again. I guess I will make another support plea and see if they keep sending a new unit. My husband and I use the unit twice a day, meaning at least 4 brush head changes per day. Apparently the toothbrush cannot handle this. It's a shame, because it really is a great toothbrush when new. When I needed a new toothbrush for our cabin, I decided against the FlexCare and just purchased an Elite. Much cheaper and none of the headaches. UPDATE: July 2, 2010 -- yes, Phillips/Sonicare did, yet again, replace the failing FlexCare that I spoke of in my initial review. Now, the 3rd (or is the 4th) unit is experiencing the exact same problem yet again -- the metal shaft seeming to come apart inside the rubber sleeve. When you go to remove the brush head, the rubber sleeve turns into Gumby and s-t-r-e-t-c-h-e-s out until the head finally comes loose. So, I go to the Phillips/Sonicare website and log in and report another failed unit; however, now there is no email support; you must call in. No problem. So today I call, and they tell me that the problem is MY fault -- that this toothbrush is not built to withstand frequent head changing. HUH? He said it's my fault, because my husband and I change out the heads each twice a day so that we can both use the toothbrush. Why, then, do they provide different colored rings for the brush heads? I thought this was so that Mom, Dad, SuzieQ and Little Johnny could all use it? Nope. He said he could send me a $15 rebate coupon ifI could send him the original purchase receipt. Wow. His solution was that we each need our own FlexCare toothbrushes and not remove the heads so frequently. Great. Not a viable option when they are so expensive to begin with. Bottom line: great toothbrush; nothing beats it, but be prepared to replace it frequently, as its lifespan is less than one year, if you intend to use it between/among more than one family member.

  103. Long time user of Sonicare products. This version is an excellen product with usual home charger, but also comes with smaller charger for travel including a travel container for the brush and portable charger.
  104. The Sonicare is much superior to the Oral-B we phased out. The Oral-B's \\"action\\" was increasingly useless, perhaps because the replacement brush heads were becoming poorer in quality over time. The Sonicare has a very vigorous, and seemingly very effective, brushing action (the next visit to the dental hygienist will tell the tale). There is a bit of a hazard, though, in using this machine. The brush head does move in a very energetic way, and it is made of hard plastic. When the back of the brush rattles against the other teeth (the ones opposite of the ones you're brushing), it is not merely an annoyance, it can chip a crown. This goes from annoying to expensive in the blink of an eye. Philips has not taken the design responsibility to put a soft rubber/plastic on the back of the brush head, so you will have to take care on your own. Another design shortfall is that there are two buttons on the handle of this model: one for on/off; one for \\"mode.\\" The mode button is actually more readily accessible than the on/off. As a result, when you are brushing you will often inadvertently change the mode. Nothing but an annoyance, not nearly at the level of the chipped-crown thing, but it is something that should have been seen to in the design stage.
  105. The brush works well. Has several options, including a timer for those who are particular about brushing for the recommended 2-3 minutes. Quick clean mode for brushing on the go.

  108. This is my first high-end toothbrush. Both my wife and I have whiter teeth (after a couple of weeks). We actually noticed are teeth getting brighter. After reading a couple of the negative reviews, I learned from their mistakes (I think). After each use, we rinse the handle and head. Then, we towel them off. There is no gunk, no mold, nothing. My brush head looks brand new after three months of use. On the downside, it is a bit noisey and tickles a bit too much at firstl. You do get used to it. I set mt brush on the MAX CLEAN and it beeps when I am supposed to move to the next section of my teeth. At the end of the day, I do love it. Also, let the battery run all the way down, then recharge it. It will last longer.

  112. I have never used an electric toothbrush before so I carefully reviewed all the brands, reader comments, consumer research reviews, etc. I had settled on the Sonic Elite, but wasn't thrilled to hear about the messy part (I planned on buying the silicone cover to help alleviate the problem). I realized the next evolution of the product was out, and expecting to use the toothbrush for many years to come, decided to pay the extra money for the top of the line version. Not having used an electric toothbrush before, I expected to be wearing a lot of toothpaste the first not around, but not so. No problems. The toothbrush is very light and easy to manipulate in the mouth. I have been using the compact head since I have a small mouth. Given some of the other review I was somewhat concerned about the noise, but it is not an issue. It is a low-toned buzz, far quieter than an electric razor. No one in the next room would even hear it. My teeth look much whiter, even after the first time (I'm a coffee, tea, and cola drinker)and they always feel dentist clean. The Flexcare Sonicare has been a pleasure to use and to keep clean. I've had it a little over a month and I love it, I would hate to think of ever giving it up. It is well worth the money.<br /><br />Update August 2014: This is still working great, the battery does last as long (New-the battery lasted a little over two weeks. It is now down to a week). It looks a little rough (I understand the whitening toothpastes do something to the finish), but the toothbrush still does a terrific job. I'm still very satisfied and will definitely purchase a new one when mine ultimately dies. I think five plus years of daily use is very good.

  114. I've been a Philips Sonicare fan since I got my first electric tooth brush for aprx $100 (on sale!) at Bed Bath & Beyond in 1997! My Series E toothbrush is still going strong and I have never had a single problem with it. I have traveled with it, I have dropped it a thousand times, and for the past couple years I've shared it with my husband (the handle, not the brush, ew). I've used it for nearly 14 years every single day and I've had good oral health for years! I love it! But the overall appearance of my toothbrush was... kind of old, and gross. I was really sick and tired of cleaning the gunk off the base, and from the inside, and in between the dome and the brush stick. UGH! So gross, so done.<br /><br />I considered getting the [[ASIN:B000AMRII0 Philips Sonicare Essence 5300 Power Toothbrush]] because of the price. But then I read the review &#34;Pay more for the better design&#34; by College Jane and I decided to go for this one, the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer. &#34;I&#34; didn't really care that I got a sanitizer but I wanted THIS toothbrush - plus, it came with TWO brush heads. It was the best deal since I would've had to get extra replacement heads right away with the Essence 5300 Power Toothbrush. I love the multiple settings! I'd had oral surgery the week prior to ordering and I was excited to try their Sensitive mode (it's great by the way!). I love the thinness and how light it is! Not to mention how quiet it is. It makes brushing much easier and pleasant, especially when you have stitches in your mouth and can barely open your mouth. The GoCare is perfect after meals. My husband loves this upgrade as well. He started sharing my old one over a year ago and his oral health improved immediately! But his favorite things about this new toothbrush? How clean it stays, and the sanitizer. My favorite? How much whiter my teeth are! I can only hope this brush lasts me as long as my old one did (I'm storing the old one just in case). I do not like the reviews that complain about loose brush heads and dead units within the first year. They don't make 'em like they used to, I guess.<br /><br />UPDATE: Dec 2010<br />A couple of months ago the toothbrush stopped charging. It made a vibrating/pulsating morse code when I put it on it's base to charge. After a week it was dying, and the brushing power was only getting weaker with use. I called the warranty number (1-800-682-7664) and they sent me a new handle (with a new brush head and travel charger included). Super easy. Still, it sucks that I had problems so soon after purchasing it. This can't be a good sign. I hope this one lasts longer...<br /><br />UPDATE: 10/21/2015<br />My toothbrush began doing the vibrating pulsing thing again, but this time it was every second or so, for a couple days...then it died and wouldn't charge. I called the number above and after a little troubleshooting they were kind enough to offer a replacement even though the warranty was expired by 3 years - just as a one time courtesy! It really made my day! So happy with Phillips customer service! My last brush lasted way many more years and I hope this new replacement will go the distance for another 3-5 years before I have to buy a new one. Love these electric brushes!just in case). I do not like the reviews that complain about loose brush heads and dead units within the first year. They don't make 'em like they used to, I guess.<br /><br />UPDATE: Dec 2010<br />A couple of months ago the toothbrush stopped charging. It made a vibrating/pulsating morse code when I put it on it's base to charge. After a week it was dying, and the brushing power was only getting weaker with use. I called the warranty number (1-800-682-7664) and they sent me a new handle (with a new brush head and travel charger included). Super easy. Still, it sucks that I had problems so soon after purchasing it. This can't be a good sign. I hope this one lasts longer...<br /><br />UPDATE: 10/21/2015<br />My toothbrush began doing the vibrating pulsing thing again, but this time it was every second or so, for a couple days...then it died and wouldn't charge. I called the number above and after a little troubleshooting they were kind enough to offer a replacement even though the warranty was expired by 3 years - just as a one time courtesy! It really made my day! So happy with Phillips customer service!   116. Wish I had bought this years ago. Was sick of all the cleaning in the dentist's chair so got this and it really leaves you with the same feeling as when you come out of the hygienist's office. Has a ramp up feature that will go up to maximum power after two weeks. My teeth feel incredibly clean!
  117. Caution if you plan to buy this model. I went through THREE of these over a 14-month period before downsizing to a hopefully sturdier Essence. I will credit the company for customer service (they provided me with free replacements when the first and second models broke down during the year-long warranty) but I knock the FlexCare's design for lack of durability. You will know the end is near when you start hearing a loud rattling noise during brushing. A week or so later, the brush no longer works.
  118. Sonicare Flexcare: The Perfect Toothbrush?<br /><br />About six months ago I decided it was about time to upgrade my toothbrush. It had treated me well, but the battery was no longer holding a charge for more than 60 seconds, and the heads were getting harder and harder to track down. Using Google and Amazon, I was quickly able to determine that the heavy hitters in the power toothbrush playing field were the Sonicare Flexcare and the Oral-B Triumph.<br /><br />The Flexcare is Sonicare's flag-ship model. Earning its moniker from the multiple cleaning modes feature, this lithium battery powered device is the Mercedes of electric toothbrushes.<br /><br />Alternatively, the Triumph is Oral-B's \\"Most technologically advanced toothbrush.\\" It's claim to fame is what Oral-B calls SmartGuide technology. Wirelessly, it transmits brushing feedback data (pressure, time, etc.) to an LCD screen. A bit over the top? Perhaps.<br /><br />Both models offered top-of-the-line features and each had earned near 5-star reviews on Amazon. After reading through some of the reviews and pricing out each model I decided to take one last step before making my final decision: ask my dentist what they recommended. To my surprise they didn't have a preference. I was instructed that either model would work great, so long as I brushed at least twice daily and flossed nightly!<br /><br />I ended up purchasing the two-handle Sonicare Flexcare bundle with UV sanitizer. One handle for me, one for my girlfriend, and a super cool UV sanitization chamber to play with! Aside from the two handles (handle is really just Sonicare lingo for toothbrush) the box also contained: two travel pouches, one travel charger, and different color rings used to personalize each toothbrush. The colored rings certainly come in handy when two people living in the same household use the same model toothbrush!<br /><br />Here are my thoughts after six months:<br /><br />Build Quality:<br />Excellent. The Flexcare feels very solid in-hand. The buttons are all sealed, easy to press, and the head slides on and off with little effort. The charging station is fairly compact and interfaces well with the handle.<br /><br />Ease of Use:<br />Pressing the mode select button will move through all available brush modes. Including: quick care, max care, massage, clean, and sensitive. Press the power button (with the toothbrush in your mouth!) and the Flexcare goes to work. After about 30 seconds or so the head will vibrate on and off a few times, this is a signal to move on to another section of your mouth. Sonicare calls this feature \\"Quadpacer\\" and claims it helps promote even cleaning. After two to three minutes the brush shuts itself off and you are done.<br /><br />What I like:<br />-Keeps you honest. Turn the toothbrush off before the brushing cycle ends and you are only cheating yourself out of a thorough cleaning.<br />-Multiple cycles. I tend to use the quick care (one minute) cycle in the mornings and in the evening I switch off between the normal clean cycle (two minutes) and the \\"Max Care\\" cycle (three minutes).<br />-Newly designed head. Made to resist toothpaste build-up, it is easily removed for cleaning/sanitizing. The included heads are also very soft and extremely comfortable to brush with<br />-Battery life is amazing. We're talking upwards of two weeks used 2 to 3 times daily.<br /><br />What I don't like:<br />-Splatter! Don't think about taking this thing out of your mouth while it is on, if you do micro droplets of toothpaste will go everywhere.<br />-Cost. Price is high, but then again you can't really put a price on healthy teeth and gums.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />What really triggered me to write this review is how pleased I have been with this toothbrush over the past six months. Yes, three minutes feels like an eternity when brushing your teeth, but fire up your cell phone and read news/twitter updates/email/etc. and will go by in no time - the beauty of multitasking! What does my dentist think? At my last cleaning I was told my brushing could not have been better. No plaque, no tartar, and most importantly, no cavities. I wholeheartedly believe if everyone brushed with a toothbrush like this, dentists would lose a great deal of business! Hats off to Sonicare for making an excellent product that needs no improvement. A+rtar, and most importantly, no cavities. I wholeheartedly believe if everyone brushed with a toothbrush like this, dentists would lose a great deal of business! Hats off to Sonicare for making an excellent product that needs no improvement. A+

After it starts doing this it only works intermittently and then finally dies permanently. The new one lasted 13 months. The replacements only last two months!<br /><br />Customer service was initially very pleasant and the replacements cost me nothing. H O W E V E R, Philips initially refused to provide a third replacement because I did not have proof of returning the previous two defective units! Keep in mind the units were both returned within one week of receipt replacement using the PREPAID label provided by Philips. When I pointed out that Philips PAID for the the return shipping and therefore would have its own proof of return, I was told that was a different department and that it was MY RESPONSIBILITY to provide Philips with the return tracking ID. I am not optimistic about this product's reliability. If you look through the reviews, you will see others have experienced my exact same problem.
  124. I bought this toothbrush soley based on the reviews on this site, as it was rated highest. It is truely one of the best purchases I have made in a long time. I was buying it for both me and my husband and was considering buying 2 (1 for me and 1 for him), but no need! Sharing works out great, and there are 2 spots in the UV holder, so both of us can store our toothbrushes in there. The toothbrush guides you through brushing, prompting you every so often to move on to the next \\"quadrant\\" in your mouth. I found that really helpful - my husband doesn't really pay attention to it and does his own thing. Quite a few people on here commented about how their thumb ends up turning \\"off\\" the unit while brushing because of it's placement. I would like to say this... That has never happened to either of us. I understand that it entirely depends on where you hold the base, but unless you are gripping the base really hard (which by the way, you shouldn't be!), there is no way you will push the \\"on/off\\" button. Overall, awesome purchase. Our teeth are cleaner, and definitely whiter!

  126. I've used manual or cheap battery powered toothbrush my entire life so when my dentist recommended the Sonicare FlexCare I was a little skeptical that it was just going to be another cheap electric toothbrush with a much higher price tag. But I decided to fork up the hundred dollars to buy this product and I have never been happier! This toothbrush really massages your gums and cleans your teeth better than any other cheaper battery powered brushes out there and it leaves your mouth with a clean fresh feeling that I have never felt in my life! The UV sanitizer that comes with this product is just a added bonus that I enjoy having because I have always worried about the bacteria build up on brush heads. My recommendation to you is that if you are looking for a new toothbrush, and I know you are because you clicked on this product, then buy this toothbrush and enjoy all the oral health benefits that come with owning a sonicare.
  127. I will be on my 3rd of these brushed in less than 18 months. The first one the shaft somehow got disengaged from the motor which seems to be a common problem with this unit. The next one somehow got water inside it. It stopped working and was only turning on intermittently so I opened it up to see for myself and there was tons of moisture inside all over the electronics. Somehow the seals around the top must have leaked. I purchased a replacement handle only on %bay, b/c I really like how the brush works (when it's working). If it breaks I'm going to change to Oral B.<br /><br />If you're considering buying one of these don't - yours will break too eventually probably only weeks to months after buying it. Get another brand and save yourself the headache.<br /><br />***Update - April 2013. The third replacement unit I got has been working fine for over a year. Maybe it was bad luck getting two duds early on.
  128. I LOVE the Flexcare's brushes but the toothbrush itself only lasts a few months. I've gone thru 2 of these in the past 9 months. I've tried to reset them but to no avail. Oral B's products are much more reliable, but their brushes are way too hard compared to the Sonicare. But I can't afford to throw this much money away every few months for this toothbrush. I'll have to go back to my old reliable Oral B toothbrush, but I'm gonna really miss the softness of the Flexcare brushes.
  129. At my last dental checkup, the hygienist said the buildup was excessive and that I should now start having cleanings three times a year rather than twice. She recommended using a power toothbrush as well, but made no brand or model recommendation. Based on the reviews on Amazon, I chose the Philips Sonicare Flexcare Rechargeable with Sanitizer. I was amazed at how smooth my teeth felt the first time I used it. The best feature, other than the thorough cleaning itself, is that the program ensures you brush for the proper length of time and that you spend an equal amount of time in each of the four quadrants of your mouth (top inside, top outside, bottom inside, bottom outside.) A couple of minor complaints: 1.) The travel charger doesn't fit into the travel case; only the toothbrush itself fits. 2.) Each time you turn on the toothbrush, you must re-select your program. It doesn't remember the program last used. I have used the cheapie battery powered brushes and there is no comparison. This is a completely different thing. The difference is in the degree of cleanliness achieved. Overall, I really like this device and would never go back to manual brushing.

  137. I purchased this toothbrush in early 2009. It is my first electric toothbush, and now I can never go back to a manual toothbrush. The original broke after 9 months, and the replacement just broke as well. Thankfully, Philips customer support is pretty good. They ship a replacement toothbrush to you within a few days rather than requiring you to first ship in your broken toothbrush.   138. I purchased this product based on a recommendation from my dentist. Afterwards, the office recommended using a Sonicare toothbrush. I was reticent, as my only experience with electric toothbrushes was from many decades back, when such things only used an exaggerated up and down brushing motion. I wasn't sure what to expect with this product. However, to say I was blown away with what this thing does is understatement. From the first time, I felt like I got a better cleaning than I got even from the dentist. My wife agrees. I have nothing but superlatives to say about this toothbrush. Well, except for the cost. This is a pricey unit, and the replacement toothbrush heads are outrageously priced, even here on Amazon. However, the cost is well worth it if it keeps my teeth and gums in the shape that the product appears to be capable of. I can only hope that the problems I've read here about the toothbrush not holding up for the long haul won't be something we encounter.

  142. I've had my FlexCare for a little more than four months and I am very happy with it. Hopefully it will have a long life and I will prosper from it! I am so far, anyway. Like some other reviewers, I have a real problem with plaque. And I am somewhat embarrassed to say that I do not floss because my teeth are so close together that it's nearly impossible (even the dentist has commented on this). Nor do I visit my dentist nearly as often as I should. As a result, I have been fighting gingivitis for years. Now that you know a bit about where I'm coming from, here are my comments concerning the FlexCare: 1. When I used a &#34;manual&#34; toothbrush, my gums bled EVERY SINGLE TIME. This is probably due, in part, to the fact that I brushed too hard, trying to get rid of the freakin' plaque! But with the FlexCare, I don't need to (and am not SUPPOSED to) brush hard. The brush does all the work, and it does it without mangling my gums. My gums don't bleed, yet my teeth feel so much cleaner than with the manual, it's downright amazing. In fact, it's slowly getting rid of plaque buildup that I thought my dentist would have to scrape off. (Please don't think you can get away with not going to the dentist because of this; I'm just telling you what I, a chronic dentist-avoider, am experiencing!) I'm convinced that the next time I go in for a cleaning at the dentist's office, I am going to be able to maintain that cleanliness for a LOT longer with my FlexCare than I ever could with a manual toothbrush. 2. I have not changed my toothpaste, yet I am convinced that my teeth are at least twice as bright as they were before I started using the FlexCare. I can only assume that there is a sort of polishing side-benefit to using it. Huzzah! 3. I have not yet had any problems with the chargers, the sanitizer, the brushing attachments or the handle itself. All seem to work just fine. However, please remember that I have only had it for four months. If I eventually have a problem with it, I will try to remember to post an update. 4. I don't have an issue with the sound or vibration, unlike some other reviewers. In fact, I kind of have to laugh a little at those who complain about the noise it makes. I mean, seriously?! Have you looked up the definition of &#34;sonic&#34; in the dictionary? Not to mention you're using it INSIDE YOUR HEAD. What did you expect? Unless it's making you deaf or genuinely malfunctioning, I don't understand why that's a serious issue. 5. What I DO agree with wholeheartedly is the complaint about nonreplaceable batteries (thus the four stars vice five). There is absolutely no good reason why I should be unable to personally replace the battery/batteries in ANY device manufactured after, say, the year 2005 (and that's being generous). I cannot think of any good excuse for the folks at Philips designing it this way, unless it is a money-making scheme. For shame, Philips. Get with the program! GO GREEN! 6. Which leads me to my second and last complaint: the price is pretty high, particularly when you factor in the nonreplaceable battery. However, I may change my mind about this when I find out how much it saves me in dental bills ... not to mention how much &#34;chair time&#34; it may save me when I'm AT the dentist's office! Bottom line: I think this is a great toothbrush. I would buy it again. May 4, 2010 UPDATE: Still going strong! Still happy with the product, and would still buy it again. Rock on, Philips! Feb. 9, 2011: Still working like new. Very happy customer. April 29, 2012: No problems. Great product! March 7, 2015: Still working great. Sometimes the sanitizer compartment won't turn on without some fiddling, but otherwise no complaints. The non-disposable battery hasn't failed me yet.

  146. I only gave this product 4 stars as it went weird on me after having it about 6 months. It started turning itself on and off like a ghost was pressing the button (I don't have any ghosts as this house was built by me about 10 years ago and no one has died here yet) at random. I called customer service and explained the problem. After a few questions, the gal just told me to package it up with all the components and ship it back to them. (I had the original packaging by chance.) They shipped me a brand new unit in a couple of days. Yes, I was out shipping (the old unit back), but it was worth it. I haven't had any problems with the new unit. As to does it work, I think so, although my gums don't feel that much better. If you do get one, realize the first time you use it, your gums will freak out; it kind of tickles, but it is not a comfortable feeling. That goes away the second or third time you use it as your gums develop a tolerance for the vibrations. I like the unit, and I use it on the 1 minute cycle. Don't put a lot of toothpaste on your brush, and make sure you have it in your mouth before you turn it on (otherwise expect to clean up toothpaste on your walls or wherever).

  151. Several of the comments have said that the buttons on the front get bumped too easily and you find yourself changing brushing modes even when you don't want to. I suppose if you grip the toothbrush in a closed fist that could happen. It's never happened to me, as I grip it lightly down the side grip pads. Another comment said there was a concern with mold in the UV unit. For that to happen there has to be standing water. I always dry the toothbrush off before putting it back on the stand - no mold issues. This is not my first Sonicare. I switched because I was tired of the gunk in the area where the toothbrush meets the handle. This one doesn't do that. I haven't decided yet how useful the sanitizer is, since it kills invisible stuff I think it's there to make you feel like your toothbrush is cleaner. Overall, it was definitely worth the upgrade.

  156. Have owned a Sonic for about five years. Got it because my dentist said the oscillating action this model has was good to not only brush the teeth, but that it would scrub away plaque from between teeth and along gum lines better than my old 'up-and-down' electric or regular toothbrushes.   159. I have purchased different types of electric toothbrushes and not one measures up to the Phillips Sonicare FlexCare! I have braces and since day one, I've used an electric toothbrush for better cleaning, less flossing (sensitive gums;bleed easily), and overall better care of my teeth and gums. Since using the FlexCare, my orthodontist and dentist have been raving about how well I take care of my teeth; truth is, I brush just like everyone else!! It REALLY feels like you just left the dentist after brushing. I dont have plaque on my teeth through out the whole day, even through multiple meals. It has a massage feature which helps my teeth move faster after getting my braces tightened, a sensitive and clean feature for regular brushing (personal preference - sensitive), a go-care feature for when youre in a rush and just need a quick brush, and max care if you have some time. I absolutely love the sanitizer feature, its like using a new toothbrush head every time. Thank you Sonicare for this wonderful product, it has shortened the time of when I get my braces off by 3 months!! THANK YOU!! :)

  161. My husband and I bought this toothbrush in the summer of 2009. After 10 months or so the rubber backing started to peel off from the top back of the toothbrush - we trimmed it several times but it looked awful. Then after 14 months the brushing mechanism became very loose to the point where I don't think we are getting the same clean as we did previously. I contacted Philips about this since we had paid $189.99 plus shipping and taxes for the toothbrush and we expected it to last much longer than 14 months. The rep at Philips said they cannot replace the toothbrush due to wear and declined to offer me any solutions. We considered buying another one - we liked the brushing features, the overall design and size plus the sanitizer - but have opted to go for an Oral B this time instead. Hopefully it will last us longer than this one did.
