  336. The Sonicare Flexcare gives you that \\"dental cleaning\\" great feel. The toothbrush handle is lighter and easier to handle than the original Sonicare style. Now for the bad. The toothbrush head would not fit flush on the handle. There was a slim gap between the base of the brush head and the control/handle unit. This then 1. Caused the toothbrush head to come loose and at times to pop off. 2. Because of the gap and the looseness, the brush cleaning selection malfunctioned. While brushing in the clean mode, it would switch to the \\"massage mode\\" or the \\"sensitive mode\\". At first I thought I was accidentally touching the selection button by mistake while brushing. But, I believe now it is related to the poorly fitting toothbrush head not seated properly and snug on the poorly designed/or manufactured \\"metal rod fitting\\". I contacted Philips Sonicare using their \\"Live Chat\\". After a short discussion of the problem and giving the rep. the model number and serial number of my unit, I was told a new Flexcare would be sent out to me and arrive in a week. A return label will be included to return the defective toothbrush. Philips has excellent customer care. However, whoever is manufacturing these units are not doing a great job of quality control. Chinese made? Says so on the box, but the Flexcare says that the unit was assembled in the U.S. My original Sonicare was still working but I was getting tired of cleaning it and the brush was a bit heavy and cumbersome. My original Sonicare was over 12 years old and still doing well. Philips....you have a great product...please make a more reliable product.
  337. I've had several Sonicare toothbrushes over the years. There were minor problems with each of them. But, their effectiveness kept me coming back. The first ones got cracks in them (their support people told me toothpaste with hydrogen peroxide caused them). The more recent models I had (including the one that dispenses toothpaste) collected saliva in the heads and in a cavity in the handle. Bacteria grew in them that made the toothbrush absolutely disgusting! But, I knew Philips had to get that right eventually.<br /><br />On to the FlexCare Rechargable. The problems of the past have been fixed. My last couple of SonicCare's withstood my toothpaste fine. So, I'm expecting this one will too. The handle has been slimmed down and there is no place to saliva to collect inside the toothbrush. The addition of the UV Sanitizer is quite nice. And, even without the UV, it's great to have a place to stick your brushhead so that it's not sitting out on the bathroom counter all day collecting flying bacteria from the toilet.<br /><br />There are several brush modes now. I only use one- full power baby! This thing gets your teeth cleaner than you can imagine. I build plaque in a couple of places. Right behind my lower teeth in the front is one. I was due for a cleaning at the dentist about 2-3 weeks after getting the brush. The plaque is smooth normally, so I don't notice. But, a couple of days after getting the brush, it actually took some of the plaque off that the older brush was missing. I was amazed.<br /><br />This toothbrush is quite expensive. But, if you have the gum problems I potentially could have (because of the plaque build up), it's worth it. I had a dentist keep telling me, I needed to come every 3-4 months for \\"scaling and planing\\" and that got to be very expensive. Since getting this Sonicares, my gum checkups have been stellar. I'm on a normal six month rotation and the brush has, in actuality, saved me money.<br /><br />Peace,<br />Brian
  338. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush going back over 10 years. I think this is the best one ever and totally worth the money. I really hesitated before spending so much but am very satisfied that I did. You can't go wrong.
  339. UV Sanitizer: I have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for years and I love, love, love them! With frequent sinus infections, strep, pneumonia, bronchitis, and other illnesses, I'm all too grateful to have the UV sanitizer, and don't mind taking a fraction of a minute's time twice a day to prevent re-infection and/or throwing away so many toothbrushes. Sensitive teeth: Having extremely sensitive teeth, I had my doubts when my hygienist recommended Sonicare, but was relieved to find it to be gentler than a manual toothbrush with extra-soft bristles. Timer: I tend to brush longer than the longest cycle, so as soon as the timer automatically turns off the brush, I \\"automatically\\" press the power button and continue brushing without missing a beat. Twelve years ago I used to pooh pooh electric toothbrushes, but my first Sonicare quickly made a convert of me. So, thanks to my dental hygienist for introducing me to Sonicare, and thanks to Philips for keeping a healthy smile on my face!
  340. I'm of two minds on this product. On the one hand, it's incredibly effective and, in my opinion, the best powered toothbrush out there. I'm thrilled with the new, slim, snap-on heads as a great improvement over those gunk-collecting screw top types. All of the other pluses mentioned by other reviewers are all true: works incredibly well, Quadtimer is great, new head design is terrific, it's smaller and slimmer than earlier models, etc.<br /><br />BUT, and it's a significant but, this is the third Sonicare toothbrush in our household that has died literally days after the end of the warranty period. I'm so exasperated by this!! It's a lot of money to put out every two years for a product that should really have greater durability. Given that Sonicare is a behemoth in this product market, has been doing this awhile, and gets a lot of feedback on this one major and frequent complaint, one would think they would have better addressed the durability issue by now.<br /><br />I suppose they realize they're getting away with it, because people like me bite the bullet and give it another try simply becaue it works so stinking well. Next time, though, I'm giving the newest generation Sonicare competitors another look to see if they've caught up. It's entirely possible they will.
  341. I probably wrote a review before...or not...but I'm not looking through seven hundred other reviews to find out. I went to the dentist yesterday; after the hygienist finished,(this included the picking and probing and cleaning), she told me things looked really good. I told her it could only be attributed to this particular toothbrush (never had a comment from her while using the Braun), brushing three, four minutes when I used it. I have to say I don't use with any regularity the side attachment to where the toothbrush is stored; there's no particular good reason for my NOT using it. But I always feel, after I brush, that my teeth feel really clean. I recommend this particular brush, even in a less expensive presentation. I think Phillips is really on to something with an electric toothbrush that works as effectively as this one does.
  342. I bought this toothbrush as an upgrade for an Elite Sonicare I happily owned for a year. And I must say, this product has everything I missed from the last one: it's perfect. My main concerns with the previous toothbrush was it worse than average Ni-Cd battery, it's non-universal charger, and the rigidity of its 2-minute timer.<br /><br />The Flexcare improves in all these aspects:<br />- Great Li-Ion battery: can recharge the toothbrush anytime without worrying about breaking the battery.<br />- Universal travel charger: great to take anywhere. (especially for anyone like me living in a 220V country)<br />- Plenty of brushing programs: I specially love the GoCare for when I'm in real hurry. I used to do a \\"manual\\" go care counting on my mind with the previous brush.<br /><br />The cheaper brush replacements and the UV sanitizer are welcome additions. With this product I really don't miss a thing, it's the perfect tooth cleaning solution next to a professional inside your mouth. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
  343. I love this toothbrush, it seems to do a lot better job than my old sonicare toothbrush and is much lighter and easier to hold. and I love the santizer that assures me that I am not putting germs back into my mouth
  344. A dental hygienist recommended the Sonicare to me several months ago, I soon found several friends who had been using the product as well. As these things always go, I put off the purchase for several weeks. When I finally purchased and started using the Sonicare FlexCare RS930, I honestly wondered why I had not used the product before. Simply put, it does a great job. The design is great. I particularly like the induction charger; no exposed power contacts between the base and the toothbrush body. EVerything is sealed up and much easier to clean up in the wet world of the bathroom sink. The UV sanitizer is nice too, keeps the brush heads out of the way as well as sanitizing them. Speaking of the brush heads, both the standard and small size worked well for me. New users: the vibrations of the brush do tickle until you become accustomed to the sensation; the small brush head definitely helps with that. Within a week or so, you don't really notice the vibrations and the larger standard brush is OK. Finally the most important part; it does an outstanding job of cleaning your teeth. Definitely better than manual brushing and surprisingly superior to the electric rotary toothbrush I had been using. I have not been disappointed.
  345. ive hade the oral-b and this thing smokes it. if your on the fence just buy it. the smaller size and the sanitizer didnt seem like that much of a big deal until you use it. p.s. it feels like you just got out of the dentist every time you brush your teeth!
  346. I bought this toothbrush following a recommendation from a dental hygienist, who only said two words: \\"Philips\\" and \\"sonic.\\" So I was on my own trying to winnow down the wide array of models and features available online and at local retail stores. I settled on this unit based on several positive reviews, its feature set, and the fact that for $5 more than the next model down, it came with the UV sanitizer feature. Although that is an unnecessary embellishment, I thought what can it hurt to try it out for about 3% more money?<br /><br />I have now been using the Sonicare Flexcare for more than 90 days, and I have to say I am extremely pleased at its performance so far. The sonic action really does leave my teeth and gumline feeling cleaner than I was EVER able to get them by manual brushing, and I have even seen slight improvement in my periodontal situation (some moderately deep pockets). Of course I did start with a pair of very thorough periodontal cleanings 3 months apart, but my periodontist and hygienists agree than the Sonicare is an outstanding dental home-care maintenance tool.<br /><br />The features on this unit all work as advertised, and are actually handy. I found the 14-use \\"ramp-up\\", which slowly increases the brushing to full-power over about a week's time, to be a good way to ease into the Sonicare experience, which can be startling for a newbie. This is a very powerful cleaning tool, unlike anything I have ever felt, other than at the dentist's office. I normally use the \\"MaxCare\\" cycle, 30 seconds of cleaning plus 15 seconds of massage on each quadrant. The regular \\"Clean\\" cycle (30 seconds of cleaning per quadrant) is fine for the morning brushing. The \\"GoCare\\" cycle (15 seconds of cleaning per quadrant) is fine if you're in a hurry, or just want to touch up The \\"Sensitive\\" cycle will probably come in handy as I ease back into brushing following any future dental work or periodontal surgery. The \\"Massage\\" cycle is fine for some gum stimulation.<br /><br />I find the feature that makes the toothbrush \\"burp\\", a tiny pause and beep after each of the first three segments of a cycle, to be also extremely handy. I don't have to keep track of time, I just switch to the next quadrant when the toothbrush tells me to. The brush heads fit perfectly, and do not seem to get any gunk underneath where they attach to the unit. I do take the brush head off and clean the mounting post about once every 8-10 days. The battery seems excellent: the instructions say a full charge takes 24 hours, so when the battery indicator has been on one green bar (out of three) for a couple days, I put the unit on the charger after my evening usage, and leave it there for 24 hours, using a manual brush the next morning. The charge has lasted at least 10 days per, so far, or at least 20 cycles. It might even go longer, but it's probably bad for the battery to drain it all the way. BTW, I do NOT keep the unit on the charger, but stand it up next to it. I believe it is better for the battery to \\"cycle\\" all the way up and most of the way down, rather than keep it fully charged all the time. Your experience and intuition may vary.<br /><br />I use the sanitizer about once a week, putting the brush head in the little compartment after the evening brushing, firing up the UV light, and then wiping off the unit's mounting post. The sanitizing cycle takes only 10-15 minutes, and shuts itself off automagically. So far, I have avoided any hideous mouth diseases (except for my pre-existing periodontal disease), but I didn't contract any in my previous 55 years of non-sanitized toothbrush use, so I can't say this UV sanitizing thing is too essential. Might be good if you shared the brush AND the brush head. (Yuck-o!)<br /><br />I was able to buy extra brush heads for about $8.50 apiece for a 3-pack, cheaper than retail. Philips also sent me one free one as a purchase bonus for signing up online with them. You're supposed to change the brushhead every 90 days, but you can probably go 4-6 months between new heads without diminishing brushing effectiveness too much. Since you actually do NOT need to press the brush hard against the tooth and gumline surfaces, the brush does not wear out and get ragged as quickly as a manual brush.<br /><br />Regarding criticisms that this toothbrush spurts toothpaste and water all over, is difficult to use, make a deafening sound, is accidentally activated, etc, I can only say that some people clearly did not read the instructions carefully. I have found NONE of these flaws and, if used correctly, the unit is fairly easy to use. It should be held lightly but firmly, not clenched in one's fist, taking care to keep your fingers off the various buttons on the front. No \\"brushing\\" motion is required: simply moving the buzzing brush head over the tooth surface and gumline at about a 45 degree angle does the trick. My teeth feel cleaner than they have ever felt, and seem to stay that way between professional cleanings. I have also noticed an appreciable increase in the overall \\"whiteness\\" of my smile, an unexpected benefit.<br /><br />I cannot speak to the longevity of this product, but the two-year warranty should take care of any issues. If it breaks in month 25 of my ownership, I will definitely buy another one- it's still cheaper than dental work! To possibly improve my chances for toothbrush longevity, I rinse the brush head and toothbrush body briefly under running water after usage, dry it lightly with a hand towel, and flick it a few times to shake the excess water off the brush head. So far, I am VERY pleased with this product, and recommend it unconditionally to anyone seeking to maintain and augment their professional dental care.<br /><br />SEMI-DISCLAIMER: My dad is a retired dentist (practiced 45 years) and had nothing to say about, or add to, this review. I showed him the toothbrush, he felt the buzzing brush head with his finger, and said, \\"Huh. Might have to get one.\\"head every 90 days, but you can probably go 4-6 months between new heads without diminishing brushing effectiveness too much. Since you actually do NOT need to press the brush hard against the tooth and gumline surfaces, the brush does not wear out and get ragged as quickly as a manual brush.<br /><br />Regarding criticisms that this toothbrush spurts toothpaste and water all over, is difficult to use, make a deafening sound, is accidentally activated, etc, I can only say that some people clearly did not read the instructions carefully. I have found NONE of these flaws and, if used correctly, the unit is fairly easy to use. It should be held lightly but firmly, not clenched in one's fist, taking care to keep your fingers off the various buttons on the front. No \\"brushing\\" motion is required: simply moving the buzzing brush head over the tooth surface and gumline at about a 45 degree angle does the trick. My teeth feel cleaner than they have ever felt, and seem to stay that way between professional cleanings. I have also noticed an appreciable increase in the overall \\"whiteness\\" of my smile, an unexpected benefit.<br /><br />I cannot speak to the longevity of this product, but the two-year warranty should take care of any issues. If it breaks in month 25 of my ownership, I will definitely buy another one- it's still cheaper than dental work! To possibly improve my chances for toothbrush longevity, I rinse the brush head and toothbrush body briefly under running water after usage, dry it lightly with a hand towel, and flick it a few times to shake the excess water off the brush head. So far, I am VERY pleased with this product, and recommend it unconditionally to anyone seeking to maintain and augment their professional dental care.<br /><br />SEMI-DISCLAIMER: My dad is a retired dentist (practiced 45 years) and had nothing to say about, or add to, this review. I showed him the toothbrush, he felt the buzzing brush head with his finger, and said, \\"Huh. Mighthave to get one.\\"

  350. I bought this toothbrush after using the Philips HX5351 Sonicare Toothbrush for 4+ years. I always thought that the old Sonicare was a solid electric toothbrush but after using the flexcare for about a month I'm so glad I got the new one. It is much more compact and more wieldy than than my old toothbrush. The blue indicator is excellent for someone like me who forgets when to change out the head. The biggest thing is that now that with the pop in head you don't get the build up of nasty gunk like you did in the old screw heads. My only complaint is that the brush is very hard to the point where it almost hurts your gums. I was hoping the bristles would soften up after a while but they still haven't. Also the Sanitizer is excellent. I don't know how I ever used a toothbrush before it. I now truly know that my brush is clean and that there's nothing gross secretly growing on my brush. I had read one review where someone mentioned that they don't use the sanitizer because they fear that it'll just leave the UV resistant bacteria like when antibiotics are used to much. Well from my knowledge of how UV works (with a little help from wikipedia) UV light isn't like antibiotics and there's really nothing that is UV resistant just because of how UV affects DNA. So there is no real need to worry about UV resistant bacteria. Apparently Biology labs use UV light to sanitize their workspace so I think that says something. To sum up Pros: Compact so its easy to travel with Sanitizer makes sure you're not spreading filth on your mouth Very strong, my teeth are already noticeably whiter New heads are so much more sanitary and easier to use Cons: Bristles are a bit tough and will hurt when you first use it
  351. This is the first Sonicare toothbrush I have owned. While it may sound like a lot of money to pay for a toothbrush, you will not be disappointed. However, 8 months after purchasing this wonder brush, it has developed a mind of it's own. It extremely loud and distracting when it is in use, don't bother trying to listen to anyone talk to you unless they're yelling. It also turns itself on periodically, and I must say the random buzzing while I was in the shower took me by surprise. We now plan on investing our money in a toothbrush that will hopefully last quite a bit longer. My last electric toothbrush lasted over 3 years and it just doesn't seem reasonable to spend over $100 on a toothbrush that can't even last year. However, if money is not an object for you, I would recommend this product.

SO I took a chance and ordered this one. I love it...I hope the results are as good as she(the dentist) expects. I feel as if my teeth are much cleaner than with a regular toothbrush and I only have to use a dab of toothpaste.
  364. I bought this at my dentist's recommendation when my rotadent died. This works fine, charges well, but I feel that the brush head is too large, and I don't feel like it works as well as the small round brush on my previous toothbrush. I'll continue to use and see how it goes.
  365. Philips Sonicare is incredible! I would recomend it to anyone, it cleans your teeth very good. I purchase one for my husband and few months later I purchased one for myself. It is definetely a great buy.

I'll continue to purchase Philips products.

I keep changing the mode when I'm brushing my teeth usually in the morning when I don't have time to be mucking about with the thing. It's not every time and it's probably mostly me just needing to change my grip on the toothbrush.<br />I love it so far and I only wish I had bought the second handle to take to the office.

However,the toothbrush stopped vibrating after 5 months, and even with meticulous cleaning, gunk accumulates at the bottom of the UV sanitizing box (Q-tips and bleach is the only thing to get rid of that).   376. My old rotary brush died, this one tickles and causes excessive salivation but I assume it is doing a better job than the old Braun.
  377. I've owned Sonicare toothbrushes for more than 15 years. My latest purchase was this FlexCare with sanitizer. If the sanitizer does what it claims, it's a nice feature. There's no way to tell besides having the brush head tested for bacteria, so I'll take their word for it. My problem is the two of them that I've owned have both broken. The first lasted about 13 months, and the second lasted 16-17 months. With the 2-year warranty, the first was replaced, but not the second. Like most places, your warranty date doesn't reset when you get a warranty replacement. I will say that this is the first model I've had problems with. For all of the others, I threw them out when the battery died. So I'm giving up on Sonicare. It's just too much to pay for so-so quality. If Braun Oral-B doesn't work out, I may try Sonicare again.
  378. This toothbrush was great until it stopped working. Fortunately, it was only a year old and still under warranty. They sent me a new one that also worked great for a little over a year then it broke as well. Now I am out of warranty so I called to find out if I could pay a flat fee for a replacement toothbrush. I was informed that once the product is out of warranty there are no repair options. I was told to buy another one. I love the toothbrush but can't rationalize buying a third one...
  379. My husband and I had the older version of the Sonic Care toothbrush and liked it okay. We just replaced them a month ago with this newer version and really LOVE it! It is easier to keep clean, does a great job cleaning teeth, and you can sanitize the different heads too. We have used both the regular and smaller heads. Nice to rotate them on usage. Only complaint is the button that changes the \\"speed\\" is located where you hold the handle when brushing. So, sometimes you accidentally change in the middle of brushing and have to push it again once or twice to resume regular speed. Not terrible but it should be changed in the next design. Then I would give it 5 stars!
  380. I really liked the sonic toothbrush until yesterday when it would no longer charge. This problem is normal for batteries, and normally easy to fix. Then today I find out I can't fix my $180 sonic toothbrush by replacing a $5 battery -- I have to spend another $180-$220. No thanks.
  381. I bought this brush in 2008. The first year it worked great; all the features were nice and dandy. But little do people here come back to review such products after years of use and let you know how it performs over time! Into my second year the battery died fast; the metal part where the brush attachments stick on completely BROKE OFF. Philips Sonicare told me my warranty expired and they could not help. Their warranty policy is specifically designed in a way that the product will crap out after the warranty expires. I read online that Sonicare was engineered to last ONLY 2-3 years. Basically, Philips want us to buy $150 dollar toothbrush and $30 dollar brush heads every year? I hate when corporations like Philips exploit customers with intentionally designed inferior products that breakdown fast so that you will run and buy a new one. Bye-Bye Philips. Just like your electric-shavers that broke down on me fast, so did your Sonicare toothbrush. I will never buy from you again. Nor can I recommend Sonicare for such an expensive price if it breaks like a Chinese made toy!
  382. It was a great toothbrush. purchased from amazon a little over 2 years ago. Now 2 years, in it's broken. Battery will not charge anymore.   383. I've been a sonicare user for a very long time but always hated how the older model was hard to clean the handle. We have very hard water here so the calcium deposits always gathered in the corners and I would have to scrub it out with brushes and hot vinegar or rubbing alcohol, it was a pain. This brush has a easy to wash handle that doesn't have any crevices to collect junk. On top of that it has a basic clean, sensitive, massage, quick clean (15 seconds for section) and max care that is like the usual clean but adds in 15 seconds of massaging at the end of each section (i use this one all the time). It also has the uv head cleaning holder thing. Pretty neat stuff and my teeth feel great. My only complaint would be that it would be nice if there was a special head for the gum massage instead of using the toothbrush but that really isn't a deal breaker or anything.
  384. I've had several versions of Sonicare, and this is the best I've used. There is only 1 flaw, and that is with the sensors on the handle - it is difficult to brush you teeth without changing the setting. Other than that, I'm very, very happy with this purchase.
  385. I love this tooth brush! My mouth doesn't even feel this clean after leaving the dentist. It really delivers on what it promises to do. Compared to any regular toothbrush, spin brush or even an Oral B sonic toothbrush I had bought, Sonicare completely blows them away. There's no comparision. This by far is the best tooth brush I've ever used. I would definitely recommend this to anyone.

  390. I had to have the first toothbrush replaced after about 6 months. The replacement only lasted less than 6 months. I think the problem with this one is that they moved the entire mechanism inside the handle. So instead of having the moving parts replaced every time you change your brush head every 2-3 months, the mechanism in this unit never gets changed. When they failed they got very loud and then quit altogether. I ended up going back to the E series. It is actually cheaper and I've had it for 2 years now with no problems (other than having to clean out the nastiness that lurks under the brush head). Bottom line, save yourself the trouble and $ and buy the e-series instead.
  391. I had a Sonicare toothbrush for (incredibly) about 10 years and although it was still working, it seemed a bit slower. Knowing several new models have come out, I decided it was time to finally take the plunge and replace it. After checking online dental reviews, it appeared that Sonicare is still the best choice out there. I chose the Sonicare Ultra Flex since it was fully featured, and amazon had a good price and rebate on it. Its a great brush and the package I bought included a hard carry case, recharge combo/UV base and a small travel recharge base. The brush body is smaller and much more ergonomic than my old model, and angled for easier use. It has an LCD panel and selector to chose several modes, including a shorter brushing cycle for quick freshen ups, and a gum massage mode. As others have mentioned, it will also be much easier to keep clean since the threaded head style of my old model (impossible to keep clean inside) is gone now replaced with a simple slip-in brush head that should have no such issues. Its a very nice brush, and my teeth have never felt cleaner (I can tell my 10 year old model had apparently slowed down a bit). One concern was that the brush started out very quiet, but became very noisy in about 2 weeks. Those who have the brush might think this was when the brush speeds up after its gentle \\"startup\\" mode, but I had disabled that setting since I was already used to Sonicare. Customer service was excellent and sent me a replacement with a postage paid return for the old brush and it still runs normally. Seeing a few others report issues and failures, I hope this brush is as reliable as my old. I may be glad it has a 2 year warranty. Assuming it turns out to be reliable, I love this toothbrush.
  392. I bought this toothbrush in 2007 and before the warranty was out it died. I called Philips and had to wait many months for a replacement handle. The new handle I received in 8/10 JUST DIED OUT AGAIN!!! I am leaving it plugged into the sanitizer base and not using it in any strange way. When I called Philips to complain, they did NOTHING! They will not replace the handle again because they only honor the warranty of the original purchase, not the replacement. No logic whatsoever. So I am screwed out of a working toothbrush. When it worked it was terrific, but I have to think many people are having this problem with the toothbrush dying out. My husband uses the Oral B and has had it for years with no problem. Buyer beware!! I just found helpful info from a battery manufacturer who uses this brush. He says DO NOT LEAVE IT IN THE CHARGER. Let it go down to 10-15% charge before recharging in order to prolong battery life. If only Philips would tell its customers that!
  393. I loved this toothbrush, works great. Unfortunately after about 1 1/2 years the brush heads just start vibrating right off. Makes the toothbrush pretty worthless. For this type of money invest in a different brush. Not worth the price with only a 1-2 year lifespan.

  397. I have to say I am in love with this little guy. I got it in the mail maybe 3 weeks ago & have been a teeth brushing addict ever since. It is not as loud as I expected it to be and not nearly as annoying to my mouth as other brands. I know it sounds stupid but I suffer from migraines and some of the buzzing sounds & vibrations from other brands seem to trigger them (my migraines) early in the morning. I have yet to have this problem with this little guy. My teeth are more than clean, they seem to be squeaky clean after using this. I am also a fan of the uv sanitizer because I am also currently sick & don't ever like to keep a toothbrush that can prolong my illness. No worries here, because I can sanitize the brush head after each use if I so please. I think it was a great buy for the price & the fact that I am taking much better care of my teeth by using it.

At first the vibrating almost made my head hurt but once I got used to it that went away. It took me about a week or so to get comfortable with it. As someone else noted the beep between quadrants is more of a pause so that was a bit confusing until I figured out what the deal was.
  403. I researched articles on the web before buying the Sonicare Rechargeable toothbrush and this was the one with the highest reviews. Leaves my whole mouth feeling clean. I like the pulse indicator that tells me when I have completed brushing one section of my teeth and it is time to go to another.   404. We have owned a number of Philips products from shavers to toothbrushes and TVs. When something goes wrong (and it usually does,) you're out of luck. There is no customer service. No response to phone calls, no answer to mail. Nothing. We'll never buy another product with the Philips label.
  405. This is my second purchase of this type of toothbrush. I bought this one for my son. They work great and give your mouth that clean feeling like you just left the dentist office. Thank you!
  406. I have to give a kudos to Phillips Customer Service. I have used Sonicare brushes for the better part of a decade and never had a problem with any of the older \\"first-generation\\" units. Since I decided to treat myself to an Christmas upgrade in December 2009 I have been very happy with this FlexCare plus model I purchased from Amazon.com. I enjoy the sleek look and minimal heft and the UV sanitation option. I especially appreciate the cleaner base attachment for the brush head (the old models seemed to accumulate gunk and required constant maintenance). Recently in May of 2011 the toothbrush stopped working and stopped charging. It died on a Thursday. On the following Saturday when I was off work and had time, I contacted Phillips customer service via their online chat option, because I generally dislike talking to customer service over the phone. In under 15 minutes the courteous and helpful representative walked me through a series of diagnostic problems attempting to pinpoint the source of the malfunction. After 6 or 7 of these steps the representative stated they would send me a replacement within 7-10 business days, since the product appeared to be broken and I am within the 2-year warranty period. I had never sent in a warranty card or anything but using the serial number on the base of the handle I presume they verified purchase date. Today, Wednesday, a brand new entire unit was sitting on my doorstep when I got home from work. It is an entire assembly, including a new UV/charger base, travel charger, travel case, and 2 new brush heads. They also sent me a prepaid FedEx return label for the dead unit. So, now less than one calendar week from when the toothbrush died, I have a brand new set up and tomorrow I will drop the dead set at FedEx. Great service, great 2-year warranty. How can you go wrong?!? Oh and plus, I often get compliments which validate the Sonicare efficacy from my dentist and hygienist, and also just friends and people I know.Yes, Sonicare is not cheap... but seriously, you only get one set of teeth, and Phillips really stands behind their product. GO FOR IT!!
  407. My 2nd unit is about 2 years old. It turns on by itself and runs Intermittently when I turn it on. My first unit was replaced through the warranty. It lasted less than one year. It kind of froze up...would turn on but barely move. I'm about to call my dentist for a recommendation for another brand. Sonicare could be a great product but just doesn't last nearly long enough for the price. Guess I won't be buying any more $30 replacement brushes for this $130 unit.
  408. This is a really great product. The built in timer lets you know when it's time to move to a new section and the three brushing modes add to its flexibility. When I first started using it I was constantly using the \\"sensitive\\" setting, but after a few weeks I have been able to use the regular \\"clean\\" setting thanks to less sensitive teeth and gums. My teeth are definitely whiter after a month of steady use and my mouth has never felt better. If you're the type of person who brushes too hard and whose gums are receding then this is the toothbrush for you. As for the UV cleanser. I am on the fence about that. I use it about once a week because, as people have stated before, being TOO clean can lead to your body being unable to fight off bacteria, or bacteria becoming more resistant. So I clean it once a week and I figure that should do well enough. Buying it on Amazon will definitely save you some money. If you don't need the UV cleaner then buy a standalone version. Either way, this is a great toothbrush. Pros: Flexible cleaning modes. Good for people with sensitive gums. Whiter teeth in a month. Cons: Price. UV Cleanser is an OK gimmick, not a deal breaker. Could have saved some money buying only the brush.
  409. This was the best price I could find for this product which my dentist asked me to get. It is easy to use and does clean better than my previous electric toothbrush. It also held a charge well during a long trip and charged both in the US and Europe.
  410. The only other electric toothbrush experiences I had before this were the $5 Colgate battery operated from Walmart and the Braun 3D Excel (a Consumer Report favorite a few years back).<br /><br />The default setting of \\"Clean\\" was too intense the first time around. It tickled my gums and I could almost not bear it. The second time around I use the \\"Sesitive\\" setting which was more tolerable. Try number 3 back on \\"Clean\\" and all was good, though it will still take a bit getting use to. The \\"Massage\\" mode is supposed to be the easiest on the gums but not as good with the cleaning so I didn't even bother with that setting.<br /><br />Everything is real easy to maintain and clean or replace parts from the diagrams provided. LED for power is clear and bright.<br /><br />The toothbrush pauses during brushing four times. Each time is a sign that you should be done with that quadrant so you can move to the next. No biggie, actually a nice feature. My wife's complaint is that it just shuts off after all four quadrants are \\"done\\". She prefers the Braun 3D Excel that sends you a beeping noise signalling the end but lets you keep brushing if you want. For me, I don't care. I could always turn it back on if I really wanted to and do another cycle.<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE:<br />My teeth feel the cleanest with this new toothbrush and it better for the price! But if it can help save me from dental work, which could easily run into the hundreds or thousands even with insurance, then so be it. Worth the purchase/gift and I'm sure the dentist will say brushing twice a day would make life even better.
  411. I have been using philips sonic toothbrushes many many years, during that entire time I never needed any dental work or fillings, infact I did not even need to visit the dentist. People would always comment on how beautifully white my teeth were. When I did visit my dentist he said my teeth were in far better condition then he had ever seen, my brush needed replacing so I asked his advice, he did not like the philips sonic toothbrushes claiming oral B was the best and the only one they sold and told me to switch to oral B. Believing him to be an expert, I did switch to oral b, and oh what a mistake, because I paid alot of money for it I kept using it. It will be of no suprise to hear that for the first time in that period of use I needed a filling for the first time in 17 years, and another filling came out all together, my gums became very sore from the oral b and I developed gingivitis, and my teeth were not as white as they were. I was so pleased when the oral B broke (after less than 2 years of use). I was back on the internet searching for my beloved Philips Sonic toothbrush, and found the best ever yet, yes the Sonic flexcare with UV sanitizer, I agree it is noisier, and for me I have to use the compact head, however the different modes for cleaning is really great for those with sensitive gums, and find the oral b too abrasive, I cannot stand the heads on the oral b either. The Philips sonicare flexcare heads are better shaped and I find I can reach all my teeth, and there is no toothbrush on this planet that will leave your teeth and mouth as clean as this brush will. Yes it is pricey, but dental hygiene is extremely important and for me I did not hesitate to pay the price as it is something I use everyday twice a day and know it actually works and does what it says it does. I think they will bring out another model with 2 brushes inside and additional extra's. I think it is worth getting the sonicare flexcare without the UV sanitizer and buying the philips UV standalone sanitizer separately as the standlone UV sanitizer will take other brush heads as well.

  415. My original Sonicare toothbrush just gave up the ghost after just under a decade of use. Like most people, I was taken back first by the vigorousness with which it brushed my teeth, but over time became accustomed to it & my mouth felt dirty when I tried brushing it with any thing else but my Sonicare. The few things that annoyed me with my first one was 1.) the replacement brush had to be screwed on & off. 2.) Black gunk built up where the brush resided in the charger & in the thin plastic molding groove on the brush & had to be cleaned once every few weeks. 3.) the brush was larger and a bit cumbersome to maneuver around in your mouth to brush exactly the way you were supposed to. 4.) The price (& wastefulness) of getting new brush heads every 6 months. I ended up getting the premium model (as a gift) for a replacement & I must say it is a significant disappointment. The only improvement over the previous model is that the brush head isn't as bulky & easier to use. Gunk still builds up both on the bed of the charger & (now) on the underside of the brush (as well, since there is no screwing mechanism preventing water from running underneath the brush head). The brush head is easier to take on & off (just pull it off & snap it on), however I only ever had to remove the old one 2 or 3 times before it needed to be replaced. With this model, I need to remove the brush head several times a week because the brush bristles themselves collect mold where they meet the plastic part of the head. This never happened on my old model. I have a mold allergy & this downside prevents me from giving it any more than 1 star. Not only is the black mold really gross, it's actually in the part of the brush that goes in your mouth & is impossible to entirely remove. The ultraviolet light \\"sanitizer\\" that comes with the model is worthless (the previous model didn't have one, because it didn't need it!). I tried (as suggested on another review) soaking the head in hydrogen peroxide 2x a week, but mold still remains in the bristles even after soaking for 24 hours. Any other extras that come with this thing, are really only their to pad the price. So, in almost every respect, this thing is a step backwards.
  416. My new dentist & hygienist recommended that I purchase the Philips Sonicare toothbrush. He said it will clean my teeth much better than a manual toothbrush and prevent my gums from receding. I have used it for only 3 weeks and my teeth and gums never have felt and so clean. I love the UV sanitation and always worried that my toothbrush was in an environment that would collect germs. I highly recommend this toothbrush.
  417. This is a great toothbrush...when it works. Less than a year after purchasing this toothbrush, it suddenly stopped working. I called Philips, and they sent me a replacement. The replacement lasted less than a week, at which point the power button fell off, the toothbrush filled with water, and that one ceased working. I am now on toothbrush number 3. This product does a good job -- my mouth feels fresh and clean after using it, and I can never go back to a manual toothbrush after getting used to the superior cleaning of an electric toothbrush, but I would recommend buying an Oral-B instead. Those last for ages.

  422. I bought this toothbrush because of so many 5 star reviews. The toothbrush is powerful, but just push dirt up to near and under the gum. 2. Made my gum bleed a couple of times (bad bleeds, enough to make a cup of water red), I tried different settings. Overall, Teeth are not cleaner, just pushes all the dirt to the gum, lossen gum, bleeding gum, I do not like this product at all, and feel ripped. no wonder its a 28 day guarantee... when the bad effect happen after 28 days. UPDATE (2/12/2012) It has been years using electric toothbrush and I realized the above experience is from the sudden switch to electric toothbrush.
  423. Great product. When my old one from many years ago finally gave out, I tried to just use a regular toothbrush. It is just not the same.
  424. I bought my first one of these toothbrushes about two years ago based on a recommendation from my dental hygienist, and I didn't know they even existed in this price range until I saw this one. I had a hard time clicking the \\"add to cart\\" button, but now that I've had it for a while I've come to appreciate some of the features my cheaper toothbrushes never had. For example, I like the timed brushing cycles so you brush long enough, the interval timer so you spend enough time brushing each part of your mouth, the UV sanitizer, and the travel charger. I don't use all the different brushing cycles and modes - just the default 2-minute one. This toothbrush is also a lot more powerful than the cheaper toothbrushes I had before. The first one of these that I bought two years ago died recently, and I just got a second one last week to replace it. There's a two year guarantee on page 13 of the owner's manual, so it lived up to the guarantee, and maybe that's just how long these things normally last until they shake themselves to death, or else I just got a bad one. Either way, I somehow expected it to last longer. But in spite of my disappointment with the two year lifespan of my first one, the bottom line for me is that I liked the power and the features enough to buy another one.
  425. The recharge did not work after a few months and it took a lot of hassel to get it replaced (needed to go through Philips instead of Amazon). Later the brush does not work anymore. It stops in the middle and makes weak buzz. It only starts to vibrate when I push hard against my teeth at certain angle. Compared to the Oral-B toothbrush my wife is using, this product sucks and I ordered a new Oral-B toothbrush from Amazon.

  429. This toothbrush is great. I wasn't sure I would like a sonic toothbrush, but I got used to it quickly. There is a program built into it to help you get used to it. The only downfall is that it's a little hard to get the back of my front top and bottom teeth, but other than that, no issues.
  430. I purchased this unit in 2009, it became very loud and didn't vibrate as effectively a year later. Philips replaced it free of charge. Now, a year and half later, the replacement unit has become annoyingly loud and does not vibrate as well as it did originally. I have anxiety about whether my dental hygiene is being compromised due to the unit's degradation in performance. There should be a way to test these units to determine if they are operating up to standards as time goes on. So, when it works, it appears to work well. But, beware, based on my experience, the unit appears to be designed to self destruct or degrade in performance just after the warranty period runs out. And, the warranty period starts the day you buy the unit - it doesn't get extended another 2 years if they replace it.
  431. My Dentist reccomended I get this for my family. I had a friend tell me I would throw it out after the first use... I LOVE IT. First off, Its a little off putting to have a motor in your mouth going a hundred times a second, and vibrating the top of your mouth... It really tickeled, and I LOL. This thing oscilated very fast, If you can get over the feeling of the first time, the way your teeth feel after makes up every time for that first. Thi particular model comes able to setup for a new person to Sonic toothbrushes. It starts gentle, and after the next 14 cycles it will gradually step up the frequency... I think its the first try that will make or brake it for you. I tell you, your whole day, no matter what you eat, afterward, your teeth will feel great. The different cycles help people who are sensitve (less of a frequency). Theres others that are a timer, so you brush long enough. All in all, I tell everyone I know to get this, and only wish I had bought it sooner!
  432. I've used successive generations of Sonicare electronic toothbrushes for a number of years now and every generation has been better than the last -- and they have all been great, right from the beginning. The one and only small ergonomic foible with this latest generation is that it's far too easy to bump the control switch on the handle when I'm changing quadrants or moving from the inside to the outside of the teeth, or vice versa. So, from time to time, I find the toothbrush spontaneously changing to an unwanted setting while brushing. I think that this problem is abetted by the slimmer design of the latest generation, which makes gripping it a tad more difficult. Not a big deal really, but just another little challenge the ergonomic folks should solve before the next version ot he toothbrush hits the market. Bottom line -- I wouldn't use anything else but Sonicare, it's simply a terrific product.
  433. Our old sonicare toothbrush recently died so we decided to upgrade to this one. It is by far the best toothbrush my wife and I have ever owned! Here's what it does; gets your teeth extremely clean.

Not only is it a superb electric toothbrush, my mouth feels like it does after a dental cleaning. This is comfortable to use, has preprogrammed cycles for different types of cleaning. The ultraviolet cleaning is a thoughtful addition and maybe especially useful for families. In short, great product and works as advertised.

  436. I purchsed this product in January 2008 as a replacement to a much older version of a Sonicare product. It worked well for about 10 months. Then the vibration got weaker and weaker. The battery is charged and it sounds like it's working fine. Now, after 11 months, it does not vibrate at all, even though I can hear the battery working. I'll have to send it back to the manufacturer. This product is far too expensive to have to go through this. I do not recommend purchasing such a high-end toothbrush that has given others similar problems. UPDATE: I called Philips customer service center, was on the phone for under 5 minutes, and they shipped a whole new unit to me. It arrived within a week. They prepaid a package to return the old unit to them. So while I still am disappointed that the initial product broke, I am very pleased with the ease of replacing it. Philips' customer service department was friendly, efficient, and apologetic.
  437. I've been using an older Sonicare model, the \\"Essence 5300\\" on which the switch was beginning to go out. I decided to upgrade to a Flexcare model and am very glad I did. The Flexcare has been a great improvement all around.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />-New Lighter, Slimmer Handle<br />This is probably the first thing you'll notice if you're coming from an older Sonicare handle, and it is a very welcome improvement. The FlexCare handle is small and feels much better in the hand than my old bulky 5300 handle. The unit is actually longer than my old brush, but that's not a big deal at all.<br /><br />-New ProResults Brush Head system<br />The new heads are great. Sonicare moved the tuning fork from the head to the handle, which means smaller brush heads than on the old models. A 3 pack of the new heads is the same price as a 2 pack of the old heads, making them actually a better deal for a superior product.<br /><br />-No More Crud in the Handle!<br />The biggest problem with my old brush was that old toothpaste/drool/water tended to collected in the space where the handle connects to the brush head. It would get all moldy and gross if you didn't clean it out regularly. Thankfully, this problem is completely gone with the Flexcare handles.<br /><br />-Lithium Ion Batteries<br />I've waited a long time for Sonicare to upgrade from inferior NiCd batteries, and they finally have. With Lithium Ion, you don't have to worry about battery capacity decreasing over time, or a memory effect. The new batteries charge faster, too.<br /><br />-UV Sanitizer Included<br />UV Sanitizers for toothbrushes are relatively new to the market, and a great idea. I always felt a little gross letting my brush sit out on the counter, even with the cover that comes with sonicare heads, and then putting it in my mouth. Scientists actually recommend that a toothbrush be kept 3 feet from the toilet due to \\"airborne particles\\" from the flush - yuck! A UV sanitizer will kill anything that might land on your brush, as well as things such as cold germs that might have come from your own mouth. Using the sanitizer is easy, just pop the brush head(s) in, press the green button, and wait for the UV light to kill the germs. I store my brush head inside the sanitizer until I need it next. The Charger is integrated with the sanitizer, although a separate travel charger is included.<br /><br />-Quadpacer<br />This is basically a beep that goes off every 30 seconds while brushing, reminding you to switch to a new area of your mouth. It has appeared in previous models (not my 5300 though), and is nice if you'll use it, but I tend to go at my own pace as I focus more on problem areas in my mouth and less on others.<br /><br />-5 Total Brushing Modes/Routines<br />There are 3 selectable \\"modes\\": clean mode: (2 minutes broken into 30 second segments), sensitive (a \\"gentler\\" clean mode) and massage (the brush pulsates for gum stimulation). Go Care Routine shortines the standard 2 minute clean mode to 1 minute, while Max Care is a longer, 3 minute cycle that includes both clean and massage mode. I set the brush on clean mode and tend not to use the other options, but some may find them useful.<br /><br />-More Environmentally Friendly<br />Although buying a new product of any sort will always have a negative environmental footprint, these new brushes are better than the old models due to their Li-Ion batteries, reduced bulk, and lower waste in the smaller replacement brush heads.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />-Price<br />Let's be clear on this: a Sonicare toothbrush is a luxury product. You're paying a lot more up front, and you get to keep paying more every time you buy replacement heads. Surprisingly, heads for Flexcare units are actually a cheaper than the older models; you get 3 Flexcare heads for the same price as 2 of the old heads. The per head price is still several times what it would cost to buy a new manual brush; but for me the superior cleaningis worth it.<br /><br />Noise<br />-Flexcare models are louder than older models. I'm not sure why this is, and supposedly vibration has been reduced in exchange, but the noise can be too much for some. The UV sanitizer also makes a quiet electric \\"hum\\" when plugged in with the door closed, even if the UV bulb isn't run.<br /><br />-Buttons can be depressed while brushing<br />A couple of people have complained about accidentally hitting 1 of the 2 buttons on the handle while brushing. It hasn't happened to me, but for completeness I'll include this as a possible con.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />This brush is a vast improvement over my previous brush, and has fixed most of the problems I had without introducing any significant new ones. The fact that replacement brush heads are actually cheaper than on my old brush is a big plus. I highly recommend the Flexcare brushes as a great upgrade to any toothbrush, electric or manual, that you're currently using.has been reduced in exchange, but the noise can be too much for some. The UV sanitizer also makes a quiet electric \\"hum\\" when plugged in with the door closed, even if the UV bulb isn't run. -Buttons can be depressed while brushing A couple of people have complained about accidentally hitting 1 of the 2 buttons on the handle while brushing. It hasn't happened to me, but for completeness I'll include this as a possible con. Overall: This brush is a vast improvement over my previous brush, and has fixed most of the problems I had without introducing any significant new ones. The fact that replacement brush heads are actually cheaper than on my old brush is a big plus. I highly recommend the Flexcare brushes as a great upgrade to any toothbrush, electric or manual, that you're currently using.

  463. I have owned two Sonicare Flex in the last 18 months from two different vendors. One was bought from Sam Club and the other was from Amazon. Both does the tooth cleaning well when they are working. Both Sonicare Flex have the same problem: quit working after 9 to 12 months. Both batteries were still hold charge, and the vibrating mechanisms were still working. Inspection of both Sonicare found a small screw (approx 3/8\\" long) that transferred the vibration to the brush was backing out completely. It takes less than 5 min to pull the Sonicare Flex gut out and re-install the screw. However, the design can be improved to prevent it from happening in the first place. For a person that can not fix the issue, paying > $120 a year on tooth brush is not acceptable. [[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]]
  464. My wife and I have used Sonicare exclusively for &#62;10 years, and now so do our children. During this time, we've owned many models. My experience has been that the battery life has been reduced drastically during this time. This most recent purchase had a battery life of less than 2 years from the time we began using it, a common complaint you can read in the reviews for every one of their recent models. When you're spending over $100 for a toothbrush, that's simply unacceptable. Moreover, the design prevents the consumer from replacing the rechargeable battery only. The battery is &#34;hard wired&#34; inside and access to the battery is impossible for practical purposes. At best, this is consumer-unfriendly and at worst, it appears to be planned obsolescence in order to encourage repeat revenue from newer models. Philips could make any number of paths to improve the consumer experience here, including: inclusion of better batteries with longer lifespans, and/or a longer warranty of the battery, and/or redesign to allow a consumer easy replacement of the battery. They haven't. Ask yourself why.

There are various settings for the toothbrush depending on how sensitive your gums are, or depending on what type of brushing you prefer. After using the toothbrush, I was convinced that my teeth felt much cleaner and smoother than they ever had when using a manual toothbrush. Once again, I know there are studies out there that state a manual toothbrush is as effective, if not more effective, than an electric, but I preferred the electric. Despite the above glowing review, after about a year, the toothbrush stopped working properly. It would not charge properly and it would go on/off even when I hadn't pressed the button. Upon further inspection, I realized that the rubber that insulated the electronics from the outside had become loose and as a result, water had damaged the internals. At that point, it was worthless. I bought another one because I found it at a great price, so hopefully I'm more successful with this one.
  479. Perfect for someone like me who is always yelled at for not brushing properly.<br />This is the best solution for brushing because it apparently does everything by itself.<br /><br />That includes by the way disinfecting the heads, using the built-in UV light that it comes with on the base.<br /><br />It was a wedding present & one of the best ones I received I might add.

I also like the convenience of three cleaning modes and the intensity level variety.<br /><br />4) I have used it for two days now and my teeth appear polished and shiny. Don't know if they are actually sanitized, but there is no way to test that of course. I think the consumer should know they are spending that kind of money on a product that only lasts so long. When I contacted Sonicare they told me: Harry: I'm sorry for the inconvenience, but since its a technical device most of its life depends on how its been used and some time they fall faulty. Me:I find it odd that 3 out of 3 toothbrushes failed within the first 2 years. How could we all be using the toothbrush in a faulty way? Basically he just said that since it's not under warranty there's nothing they can do and ended the chat abruptly. He did give me this link to follow up furhter: Harry: [...] I hope no one else is having this problem but 3 out of 3 toothbrushes that ended up faulty is a bit ridiculous, and Sonicare wont help you after the warranty. It's like the design them to fail after 2 years (conveniently when they are out of warranty). I wish we could avoid buying these toothbrushes but they are so great for your teeth. I think consumers need to flood them with complaints if this is also happening to you. It's just not fair!

  511. The Sonicare FlexCare rechargeable toothbrush is lightweight, comfortable to hold, and comes with a variety of functions: Just press a button to set it for a thorough Cleaning (too much vibration and tickling for me and it shakes the toothpaste off), Sensitive (perfect for me) and Gum Massage, which is great when you have extra time. You can also set it for Go Care which is one-minute long, and Max Care, which is three-minutes long.<br /><br />The brush has bristles of various lengths that get in-between the teeth and feel quite soft. The motor is quiet on the Sensitive setting, and won't wake anyone else up. The recharger base has a nifty UV sanitizer cycle to keep your brush tip clean. There are three color bands to place on the brush tips, but it comes with only two tips. (For this price, I would expect at least four brush tips, since they recommend a new tip every three months.) The kit includes a handy, small travel recharger and a nice travel bag.<br /><br />I enjoy my Sonicare and will continue to use it. It's good-looking, easy to use, does the job, and feels good. Highly recommended.
  512. ok, so i lucked out and got to try this out free as a bzzz reviewer. but that doesn't change the fact that this is an amazing gadget. here's why: 1. it looks pretty. this does not rank high on my list of necessary attributes of my toothbrush, but i just had to say it. and now the fact that it is, makes me happy. 2. it's easy to use, despite being packed with features. won't bore you with the details (which you can read above in the item description), but really, you have just enough options not to overwhelm you, but to suit your every dental hygienic need (short of a root canal or cavity filling, but you shouldn't need them if you keep using this thing). the 2 week \\"ramp-up\\" program that gradually increases the power for the 1st 2 weeks you use it is pretty cool. 3. it sterilizes your toothbrush heads. i keep reading those gross articles that talk about the bacteria growing on toothbrushes and flying through the air from flushing toilets and i had to just not think about it. now i can think about it and say, 'ha ha--i gotcha! die a terrible uv death, you bastards!' to those nasty, nasty microbes. 4. it's fun to use. which means i'm now a thorough brusher. ok, so i NEVER in a million years thought i'd use an electric toothbrush b/c i thought it was a stupid idea. but this thing makes me actually want to brush, and even gets me to brush for an entire 2 minutes each time! my dentist would approve. now if they could only do something like this for flossing... the only drawbacks i see are: 1. i totally agree with the whole messiness issue. toothpaste spit goes flying everywhere unless i keep my mouth closed and even then, i drool. guess it gives philips another reason to invent something i didn't think i needed--a toothbrushing shield/guard to protect my mirror from all those annoying toothpaste spit spray dots. i just make sure to change into my day clothes AFTER brushing. hint: ALWAYS always *ALWAYS* turn off the toothbrush BEFORE removing it from your mouth, unless you want the 'snow-covered' look on every surface in your bathroom. 2. it's slightly more cumbersome to travel with. but i don't do much traveling anymore w/2 small kids. and even if i did, i could just bring a regular toothbrush and leave my new treasured toothbrush safely at home. 3. i guess i'll have to buy refills. which i'm sure will cost more than the 2 buck ones at the drugstore. but did i mention my toothbrush is now pretty?

  516. I purchased a set of the Sonicare Flexcare HX6930 toothbrush(s) about a year ago from Costco. I paid around $150, which included the UV Sanitizer, a few extra brush heads, and the travel charger. There's a lot to like about this unit's ergonomics, but two glaring fault's make all the good things about it unimportant. The unit does not allow battery replacement, and the high breakage rate (motor to brush head coupling) indicate a very problematic design. Both of these problems happened several months ago, and so neither of my brushes now work. I have spent some time on the net researching these issues, only to find out that my problems are certainly not unique, and that subsequent models (I was hoping for a fix) still have the same issues. It is obvious that Sonic did not place the same emphasis on reliability that they placed on such an elegant design. I cannot recommend this unit; The cost, lack of manufacturers commitment to addressing the design flaws, and continuing to produce newer models with the same flaws only indicate a profit over all else approach.
  517. This is my first electric toothbrush and I love it! My teeth look and feel amazing after I use it. My old style tooth brushes and hand could never give me the cleaning that I get each time I use this. Beautiful!
  518. Had mine for about two years now and it is still going strong. Battery life still last forever. I've dropped it a few times -no problem. Phillips, I will make deviled eggs for your next company picnic; I love you.
  519. At my last dental checkup, the dentist said I had early gum disease and needed deep scaling/planing. My hygienist, who did the scaling, recommended I start using a Sonicare FlexCare Plus. After shopping around, I opted for the plain FlexCare model, because it has all the same functions as the Plus--they're just labelled differently. Also, at Amazon I was able to get this model with the UV brush sanitizer. I was skeptical about spending so much money for a toothbrush, but the positive reviews, plus my disdain for periodontist visits, convinced me to try it. Upon arrival, I charged it for 24 hours before using it, during which time I thoroughly read the instructions. I suggest any buyer do the same, as this thing has a lot of settings and options. Once I started brushing with it, I couldn't believe the difference in how my teeth feel after using the FlexCare. I use the standard cleaning cycle, two minutes with a pause and beep every 30 seconds to tell you when to move to the next quadrant. My teeth feel noticeably cleaner and smoother after brushing with the FlexCare, pretty much like when you get them cleaned at the dentist. Can't tell much difference with my gums, but given its speed when it's operating, it obviously does as advertised--forces the toothpaste/water solution between your teeth and under your gum line to completely clean all the places you can't get with a normal brush. The FlexCare comes with two brush heads. The shorter one has a concave bristle surface; the longer one has a double-concave surface and has a larger set of bristles, and is supposed to do a more through cleaning job. I use that one; the smaller one seems better suited for a child. The handle unit seems well made and carefully sealed against moisture. The weight is about perfect--just heavy enough to keep it stable when it's running, but not too heavy to maneuver and hold for several minutes. It's also well balanced. At first, the controls and LED indicators on the brush handle seem confusing--but I've brushed manually for the last couple decades, so that's likely just me. The power button is logically placed just under your thumb, and all you really need to do is turn it on and brush. The unit shuts off automatically. The only time you have to push another button is when you're changing brushing cycles. The handle comes set by default to the two-minute clean cycle, the 30-second beep cycle, and the startup mode--this uses a slower brush rate to start, and gradually increases over the first two weeks to the full speed. You can change the cycle with the handle controls, and the other defaults can be reset while the unit is in the charging stand. There's a quick clean cycle and a gentle setting for those with sensitive teeth. The two-week startup mode is a great feature, because this brush takes some getting used to. It vibrates so fast that it startles you unpleasantly if you touch the plastic shaft of the brush tip to your teeth while it's running--which is easy to do. It took me a few brushes to get used to shifting directions without inadvertently rattling my teeth. The FlexCare comes with a soft travel case and a separate travel charger--that's a nice touch. They also include a set of three alternate snap-on color rings so multiple family members can easily identify their own brush tip. One thing it doesn't have is a separate base or stand for the handle. Our bathroom counter space is limited, so I have the charger/cleaner on a shelf unit separate from our vanity. It'd be nice to have a small base that would hold the brush upright, rather than tossing it in a drawer or letting it lay on the counter. I don't want to keep it in the charger all the time anyway, as it's usually better to completely drain a rechargeable battery before recharging. But that's a minor gripe. The only real negative I can see is the cost of replacement brush tips--around $20 for a pack of 3. That can get pricey if more than two people use it. Each tips is supposed to last about three months. There's a $5 coupon for these in the FlexCare box, and your dentist probably has the coupons available. Overall, the FlexCare is worth the money--especially at Amazon's price. It's made well, comes well-equipped, has a lot of settings to choose from, and most important, it seems certain to do a great job keeping your teeth and gums healthy.
  520. I was really skeptical about this toothbrush because it has a lot of characteristics I don't like: needs recharching, expensive consumables (replacement brushes), additional features I don't want (UV compartment.)<br /><br />After using it for a week, I have to say the results are amazing and I'm thrilled enough with the results to take the time to post this review. I am an ardent brusher (2x daily), flosser (1x daily), and mouthwasher (1x daily, after flossing), but this toothbrush does a better job than I ever did. All the feedback I've read about \\"as clean as a dentist visit\\" match my experience. What surprizes me most is that I've even noticed a decrease in \\"morning breath.\\"<br /><br />Using this thing is a little scary at first because it buzzes like an orbital sander. I was really worried because I have rather tender gums with some receeding gum lines; I was surprized that this brush doesn't hurt me anywhere.
  521. I am very pleased with this product. It is easy to use. The UV Sanitizer is great.
  522. Having owned the original Sonicare for about 4 years now I was impressed and then disappointed when my battery finally gave out, then I found the Sonicare RS930! After doing a little research I picked one up... Yes its a little pricey as most point out, but what is your only set of teeth really worth to you? Thinking about that anything in the Sonicare line is inexpensive! I read over every review I could find and as many pointed out it looks like some of the 'annoying' issues have been corrected over the original model (mold/scum collecting under the brush head mount, handle sticking to the charger like glue at times!) I have only used this brush a hand full of times since it is brand new but there is no doubt its a night and day improvement over the original Sonicare. I really like the smaller size of both the handle and brush head, the brush head is much easier to move around in your mouth and reach the very back. I am still up in the air on all the new `settings/cleaning modes' but I will definitely give them all a try. The UV sanitizer is one of those things you really didn't know you needed but the more I think about it it's a must have and great idea! If there is one thing I wish could change a little is the price of the brush heads themselves, yes they are cheaper then the other Sonicare models but at about $10 each they still seem a little high priced for what they are... even with that I have no complaints! There is no doubt that my teeth feel cleaner then with the earlier model Sonicare. Hands down this is a very big improvement over the original Sonicare and I would recommend to anyone who cares about their teeth!

  529. I actually received this toothbrush free as a product test over a year ago and I still use it everyday. It is the best. My teeth always feel so clean, like I just left the dentist's office. I love that the sanitizer cleans the brushhead after each brush. I always brush my teeth now for the full two minutes. It's the best toothbrush I've ever owned and if this one ever dies, I'll be replacing it with the same thing!!!!
  530. I have used other electric toothbrushes in the past, but always ended up switching back to a conventional toothbrush because I felt like they never cleaned my teeth well enough. My dentist recommended I try a sonicare brush for an even better cleaning. However, I waited for years to purchase one because I thought the price was too much and I figured I could do just as good a job myself. Lately, I decided to go ahead and give it a try and I am sooo happy I did. I immediately noticed a difference in the brightness of my teeth, and they were soooo clean, as if I had just returned from the dentist. The sonicare brush also made it easy to get the teeth further back in my mouth really clean. This is definitely a great investment and I would recommend it to anyone in a heartbeat. I am in love! Amazon shipped it within 24 hours too even though I selected the free shipping method. It comes with a carrying case, extra charger for travel and two brushheads with covers to keep them nice and clean during travel too which I love. This product deserves more than 5 stars!
  531. This was amazing product i used.
  532. Unlike the older Sonicare models, this one has a cheap rubber green button that disintegrates after 6 months of usage. Five months into my brushing, it started fraying, grew holes, and popped out. I tried using superglue to keep it attached, but it was hopeless - by six months it had broken off completely and couldn't be glued back. Without the green covering, I resorted to using a metal rod to poke at the button to get it to start. Then the brush started vibrating even after I had turned it off (apparently it will work only with the green button!) Unfortunately, I lost my receipt and couldn't prove it was still under warranty, so I was out over $100!! Now I see the same type of cheap rubber is being used for the Sonicare FlexCare model. Buyer beware!
  533. This toothbrush does a fantastic job. Between this toothbrush and flossing every other day my trips to the dentist are quick and easy. It's also nearly impossible to over brush at the gum line with this toothbrush.
  534. I like my Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer very much. I would recommend it.
  535. I purchased this toothbrush about a year ago for my wife. As far as cleaning teeth, it does an amazing job and the UV sanitizer is a nice bonus. However, after about 5 months, the toothbrush just stopped working - all it would do is emit slight buzz, like the motor is running but it's not connected to anything. Philips replaced the brush very promptly (the service was great) but unfortunately, after about 4 months, the replacement seems to have gone the same way as the original brush. It is dead and I will be contacting Philips again. Maybe it was just really bad luck, because were it not for this reliability issue, the product would easily earn a 5-star rating. But based on our experience, it is tough to recommend it, especially given the pretty high price. FWIW, I have been using the Oral-B Triumph for over 3 years without a problem but my wife feels its cleaning effectiveness is inferior to the Sonicare. Guess we'll just have to see how long the second replacement will last...
  536. LOVE IT. I've had it for nearly a month now and it's still on the first charge. I read a review that said he couldn't tell the difference in vibration. I've had other Sonicare toothbrushes that made my hand go numb, this one doesn't. Much lighter. Additionally, I really like the three brushing cycles 1-3 minutes.
  537. An excellent product that performs well. Much better than the Oral \\"B\\" I used previously. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is due to the unavailability of firm brushes. It seems that med. brushes are the only ones available.
  538. Although I balked at the price of the toothbrush, when I made up my mind to attack my dental problems the Sonicare Toothbrush was the first to come to mind. It is so worth the money. Everytime I brush I feel like I just left the dentists office for a cleaning. The vibrations seemed a little intense but after a few uses it wasn't a factor anymore. I had a big problem with tartar and even a few weeks after I left the dentist, I could see the tartar building up again. With the Sonicare Toothbrush that tartar was gone in about a week and I don't see it coming back anymore.

I called Philips' customer service and said they'll send a replacement within 10 business days. It's covered under the 2 year manufacturer's warranty.
