  543. I have been using the Philips Sonicare Flexcare w/ Sanitizer for exactly three days now. With Optic White toothpaste I can already tell a difference. It certainly gets the job done. I have 19 capped teeth and, even though I was afraid the thing would vibrate my caps off, I can already tell that coffee and tea stains are disappearing. The product seems to be well made. It comes with two brushes, a sanitizer/charger, a travel case and a travel charger. I especially like the sanitizer. The head pops off the toothbrush easily and slips right in the sanitizer. The sanitizing process takes several minutes but it's good to know that there is something in my bathroom that is 99% germ free. I enjoy the way my teeth and gums feel after I use the toothbrush. Overall, I am pleased with the product and would recommend it to anyone. ADDENDUM: I have been using the toothbrush several weeks now and I have noticed that several people have commented on my teeth. My sister asked me yesterday at Thanksgiving if I had something done to my teeth! ;) I told her that all I had done was buy a new toothbrush!
  544. We purchased this at the advice of our dental hygienist. It arrived in time and was in good shape, just as advertised. Packaging was good and I am quite happy with the purchase. The system takes a little getting used to, but works very well. The oscillation of the brush head is a strange sensation on your teeth and gums, but once you get used to it the system works very well. We have noticed better reports each time we go in for cleaning.
  545. As a number of other reviewers have noted there are major reliability issues with this brush, and I have gone through 3 in the last year or so. After 3-6 months the connection between the motor and the brush head fails leaving it useless. Luckily I got mine through my dentist so I have no issues getting replacements through them, though each time I have had to wait 2 weeks. As well as it works, for $175 canadian this thing is just not reliable enough, for that kind of money it should last at least a few years, not a few months. When I can no longer get warranty replacements I will not be buying another one.
  546.   549. this brush has been in use for 5 years now and it is still trucking. i think the dual brush unit from costco is a better deal for the same money, but this is a great brush. i had to take it apart about 3 years in when the post for the head unit seemed to have come disconnected from the main unit internally, making the brush head very wobbly. it was an easy fix to slide the guts out, put superglue on the post hole and then re-install the head piece. 2 years in it is very sturdy and still cranking.

For example, there is a Clean Mode, described as \\"standard mode for sueprior teeth ceaning; a Sensitive Mode for a more gentle cleaning for sensitive gums and teeth; and finally, a Massage Mode for \\"gum stimulation.\\"<br /><br />There is also a UV sanitizer for sanitizing the brush head after each brushing that is easy to use and also a carrying case for the toothbrush when you travel.
  551. For the longest time I've been thinking about buying this toothbrush. The price was stopping me but I was still longing for it. I mean, how cool is that? :) Highly recommended.
  552. I have had three sonicare toothbrushes over the last ten years. This is the best one yet. Quieter, smaller, and easier to handle. Only problem is I tend to hit the button that sends it into gum massage mode. But this is minor. Without this toothbrush my gums go wild.
  553. Before I start reviewing, I should mention that I bought the Special Edition package from Costco with 2 Sonicare brushes for about $170. With this setup you can have His and Hers, one for mom and dad and one for the kids, one for home the other for work, or even one for home and one for vacationing. Of course, Sonicare's reputation precedes itself, which is one reason I bought these. However, the main reason I chose this model is because it has a thin handle compared to other electric toothbrushes. This makes it easier for my wife, who has small hands, to use. The other reason I chose this model is the UV sanitizer; have you ever looked at plaque under a microscope? Or threw out a brush head ($$$) after getting sick? Also, the 'Go Care' and 'Max Care' settings are very convenient and take the guesswork out of how long you've been brushing in each area of your mouth. After using it for a month now, I know my teeth are cleaner than when I used to use a regular electric Oral-B. I recommend the Sonicare Flexcare to anyone who cares about their long-term dental health. The price is reasonable considering the full 2-year warranty. And if you can get the Special Edition with 2 handles, even better. UPDATE 2/3/2012 These still work like new and will hold a charge for at least a month. Very satisfied with this product. Although the brush heads are still pretty spendy.
  554. I had been using Sonicare for several years now and wanted to get a newer model. My old one wasn't charging as easily anymore and I saw this model and thought I might like it better. It does the job that I expected and the added feature of the uv sterilizer is nice especially after you have had an illness. I hate to floss and do it infrequently but the brush helps to keep my gums in better shape.
  555. This is a very good brush. I was originally skeptical, and it took a lot of convincing from my dentist and from 3 rebates (1 amazon discount, 1 amazon coupon, 1 philips mail-in rebate) to finally get it. However after using it for a few weeks I am totally convinced and can't imagine going back to manual brushing. It gives a real 'clean' feeling, very smooth teeths to the tongue. With negative points however, the 5 timings are an overkill. Two would be enough - the 3 minutes regular brushing and the minute additional. The UV cleaner is fancy, but I have no medical-base opinion whether it's really useful.
  556. I really like it! It's small and works great! I always get the fresh out of a dentist chair feeling, but you get use to that feeling after a while.
  557. Well, I'll ignore the fact that I found the two pack with an extra handle at Costco for $[...] more than I paid for this just three weeks after I got it for the purposes of this review, that has really pissed me off...<br /><br />That aside, I had mixed feelings about this toothbrush. I have used the disposable electric toothbrushes in the past, but nothing close to this. So for anyone thinking of this as their first electric toothbrush, give this one a try for a few weeks. I found out that they have a 30 day money back deal direct from the manufacturer (check to make sure it still applies before buying), so I figured I had nothing to loose. I arrived at this one after at least 20 hours of reading reviews online and comparing models, so I'm positive that I got the best one on the market.<br /><br />My first brush: As I held the device in my hand and the toothpaste slid off (I guess I should have listened to the person who said to turn it on only once it is touching your teeth), I couldn't help but wonder if this device could take tar off a roof with how fast it vibrates. And indeed, it took what was basically tar off my teeth, but it made my teeth, gums and tounge numb when I was finished. I brushed for about 60 seconds (using a clock with a second hand to make sure I did 15 seconds in each quarter of my mouth) just to be sure I was following the recommended useage for this first time. I almost returned it right then and there because of how numb my mouth became. To understand why I didn't, you'll have to know a little about my mouth: My dentist says that I have a plaque problem. In fact, over the years (because I moved from place to place) I can remember four different dentists telling me that I should be brushing more and flossing more and coming more often. I go once a year, I brush twice a day, and I floss every few days. I have never walked away from a dental cleaning (even a \\"full mouth debridement\\" that I had a few years back which took an hour) without being able to still feel ridges at the edge of my teeth where there was still plaque built up (that's right folks, I can feel my plaque with my tounge because it is so hardened on). Ok, back to my story. As I put the toothbrush head in the UV sanitizer and replaced the handle on the counter, I noticed that I couldn't feel any plaque! In one minute this has done more than any toothbrush I've ever owned, more than flossing, more than a full hour of horrible deep cleaning by a dental hygenist, more than four different dentists (and perhaps more when I was younger) could do. This took all of my plaque away! I have a cleaning in a few weeks, I'll try to remember to update this after the cleaning to tell you what my dentist has to say.<br /><br />So why four stars? Well, for two weeks my mouth felt numb after each use, which would have dropped my rating to two stars when balanced with the excellent results. But after two weeks that started to fade and now I only feel a little tingle. So I bumped it up to four stars because if you stick with it you'll get used to it and not feel it as much.<br /><br />What other features does it have? Well, the UV sanitizer was a great deal for me because I have always used one with my regular toothbrushes and I would have had to get one to fit whatever brush I got. The sanitizer works great and I give it five stars without complaint. The only thing I can't comment on is its longevity, since I have had the cheaper ones break a lot, but hopefully this one is made well and will last long.<br /><br />Then there is the charging base. This uses a new technology that I read about last year after CES which send electricity to the device just from being within less than an inch of the base top. Try it, hover above and it will charge! This is not only cool, it also means no metal to corrode in your bathroom. The travel charger works the same, but my complaint there is that a lack of weight will cause you to need to position the cord carefully when putting the travel charger down or you wont be able to use it. Also, the travel case doesn't hold the charger. However, for short trips I'm going to bring a cheap disposable electric in a travel sanitizer so I don't risk my expensive toothbrush so that isn't a problem for me.<br /><br />The \\"deluxe\\" travel case is a joke, being that it is made from canvas and very cheap, I give it two stars. However, I didn't expect much so I wasn't dissapointed.<br /><br />The brush head is smaller than I am use to. This was annoying at first, but I got used to it. If it was larger, it would be harder to fit into smaller curves around the gumline. Since it does the brushing for me (I just move it slowly back and forth, less than 50 strokes does my whole mouth), this isn't a problem at all now. The pro brush head is also designed well and it cleans great. I will continue to use that head.<br /><br />Now for the two complaints that I have aside from my initial reaction of numbness: First, the battery is one of those that you have to use up before you charge. That isn't a problem, except that they should have put a charge button on the charger because I have to store it next to the charger instead of on it when I don't want it to charge. The second complaint is that the programs (which I haven't figured out yet) clear whenever you stop using it or if you don't turn it on for three seconds. This means that you have to find your setting, move the brush quickly to your mouth, and turn it on, all within 3 seconds. And the next time you use it, the brush has reset to its default. Apparently they put money into designing these program modes but they don't want you to use them. I just ignore them because of this.<br /><br />All in all, everyone needs this toothbrush! I hope that dentists start to recommend it and readers start to buy it. I can't say enough about it! Of course, there are major flaws and if another brand comes out with something better I will be quick to switch, so they really need to put in some more R&D to improve these few flaws before someone else comes out with a product that does...l charger down or you wont be able to use it. Also, the travel case doesn't hold the charger. However, for short trips I'm going to bring a cheap disposable electric in a travel sanitizer so I don't risk my expensive toothbrush so that isn't a problem for me. The \\"deluxe\\" travel case is a joke, being that it is made from canvas and very cheap, I give it two stars. However, I didn't expect much so I wasn't dissapointed. The brush head is smaller than I am use to. This was annoying at first, but I got used to it. If it was larger, it would be harder to fit into smaller curves around the gumline. Since it does the brushing for me (I just move it slowly back and forth, less than 50 strokes does my whole mouth), this isn't a problem at all now. The pro brush head is also designed well and it cleans great. I will continue to use that head. Now for the two complaints that I have aside from my initial reaction of numbness: First, the battery is one of those that you have to use up before you charge. That isn't a problem, except that they should have put a charge button on the charger because I have to store it next to the charger instead of on it when I don't want it to charge. The second complaint is that the programs (which I haven't figured out yet) clear whenever you stop using it or if you don't turn it on for three seconds. This means that you have to find your setting, move the brush quickly to your mouth, and turn it on, all within 3 seconds. And the next time you use it, the brush has reset to its default. Apparently they put money into designing these program modes but they don't want you to use them. I just ignore them because of this. All in all, everyone needs this toothbrush! I hope that dentists start to recommend it and readers start to buy it. I can't say enough about it! Of course, there are major flaws and if another brand comes out with something better I will be quick to switch, so they really need to put in some more R&D to improve these few flaws before someone else comes out with a product that does...
  558. I have owned several rechargeable toothbrushes for years and have been happy. When I needed to replace mine, on the recommendation of my dental hygienist, and a little rebate offer, I decided to try this. The brush head is great, I like the different cycles, and the sanitizer is an extra bonus and easy to use. It seems this brush is simply easier to keep clean as well. I highly recommend it. I would give it 10 stars if I could.
  559. Here are two things Phillips will not tell you about their Sonicare toothbrushes and heads. 1) The collar that holds the toothbrush to the handle will disintegrate in a couple of months. That's what prompted this review, because they would not replace mine after it fell apart two weeks after purchasing a replacement. They manufacturer these things to disintegrate so you will continue to buy replacements - planned obsolescence. However, I suspect their China supplier is skimping on the plastic specifications and they fall apart in weeks instead of months. (Do you think China would really do that?) 2) UNPLUG your base until you need to charge the toothbrush. If you charge it up overnight, then unplug the base, the toothbrush will work for four brushings per day for about a month. Then, when it signals or stops, plug the base in to charge it. This method will allow your toothbrush to work for five years or longer. If you keep the base plugged in all the time, these NiCad batteries develop memory and will stop functioning after 18 to 24 months. A bonus, if you travel a lot as I do, you don't have to pack the charger. Just make sure it's topped off and you're good for a month's vacation.
  560. For once I am looking forward to going to the dentist. I have problems with plaque and my dentist gets so annoyed with me - thinking that I do not brush properly. I decided to try the Philips Sonicare FlexCare toothbrush and I am very pleased with the product. My teeth feel so clean and I just know that the plaque problem is over. I am brushing my teeth more often and for a longer period of time. The product is easy to use and the sanitizer keeps the brush clean and dry. I would definitely recommend this product to everyone. In addition, I found that Amazon offered the very best price. I see my dentist in February and hope that he is pleasantly surprised.
  561. I am really enjoying my new Sonicare Flexcare with the Sanitizer. I had an older version but it died on me in months ago and I really missed that clean feeling. Good points: - Handle is thinner and easier to hold. - smaller toothbrush head is more comfortable - easier to clean and to keep clean (no more gunky buildup inside the brush!) Neutral: - UV cleaning cabinet which holds a spare brush. I find it too easy to press the button that changes the cleaning mode while holding the brush. So definitely a good replacement for the original.

  564. i moved up from an other brand power toothbrush to this model which was recommended by my dentist for better plaque removal. i usually don't use all the modes that this toothbrush comes with, but i was comfortable even with the default settings right from the first time. it is NOT loud (for me) as some other reviewers complained and it is pretty compact compared to other sonicare models. although this comes with 2 brush heads, i imagine most people will end up using the compact one all the time. i like the uv-sanitizer function and use it all the time, but you can argue whether it is needed.

  571. Date: 12/06/2013 Today, about 1 1/2 years after purchase, the shaft came out of this unit while changing the brush head. I have a couple of these and in my experience, the shafts get wobbly/loose after a year or so. This is the first time one actually pulled out. If you call or Live Chat Philips saying you have a problem, the first thing they ALWAYS ask me is if the shaft is loose. Telling. The Sonicare is my favorite toothbrush. I don't find that much of a difference in models. The brush heads are very expensive IMO. Now the failures are annoying BUT Philips has been nothing short of FANTASTIC in replacing these under warranty! No problems at all. A few questions about Model, S/N, date of purchase and BOOM they send me a replacement in a week or two. The old one must be returned. So they stand behind the thing, but I can't help of think it might be better for PR and the bottom line to up the engineering or construction. That's their business so it is what it is. I'll buy again as necessary.

  574. We initially purchased this unit almost 4 years ago back in 2008. Since then, we have had the original and two replacement units, but all three we have had died. Philips replaced the first two, but we received the third one more than a year ago so if we want another one, we have to buy it. The problem is the piece that the head mounts on becomes dislodged/broken inside the unit from the mechanism that vibrates it. The toothbrush itself is great when it works and really gets your teeth and mount clean. Just plan on replacing it every 13-16 months. We are now researching new ones and either will replace it with another Sonicare (this was our second) or go with something else.
  575. This new brush has far more power than the version I had, which was the version before the Elites (and Phillips' purchase of Sonicare). It's like putting a jet engine in your mouth (although it's not painful or uncomfortable, as all these brushes sometimes can be for first-time users), and you can feel the difference on your teeth when you're done. I also like being able to have different modes of cleaning, for thorough versus on-the-run toothbrushing. And it's nice to have a way to clean the gunk that collects in the spaces in these brushes' handles and to sanitize them. That's apparently what the UV cleaning feature does, though I haven't had the brush long enough to have a view of it.
  576. Electric toothbrushes of various kinds have been around for a long time now - at least since the sixties - and manufacturers are having to get more inventive about adding features to keep consumer interest. I have seen one advertised that electronically displays - on a device that you attach to your mirror - what pressure you are applying. Is that really of any use to anyone?<br /><br />With this new model, Philips have released a high-end (ie horribly expensive) product that has a host of useful features but none that can be dismissed as gimmicks. You can adjust the type and strength of vibration, you have a timer that encourages you to keep brushing, a travel charger and a very neat UV sanitizer.<br /><br />The quality is excellent, but it is very noisy. Also, the whole thing is designed as if for one person, with just two, different-sized brushes. Of course, you'll be able to buy extra brushes, but there's no holder for them. One reason for getting a brush like this is that it might encourage your gadget-crazy kids to brush their teeth more, so many people will require those extra brushes.<br /><br />I've given it 5 stars because the quality and performance are so good, but you have to decide if you want to spend all that money on what, when all is said and done, is just a toothbrush.<br /><br />Peter Reeve.
  577. This is a quality, easy to use toothbrush that really does seem to get your teeth almost as clean as they are after a visit to the dental hygienist. And this toothbrush does have some nifty special features including the sanitizer, travel charger, timer and three different speeds. As other reviewers have said this is a noisy gadget but for a few minutes every day it is tolerable. Is it worth the rather hefty price? I'm not sure but I think I'll know after I get a report on the state of my gums after my next dentist's visit.
  578. I've been using the Rotodent for the past 5 years. You can only get it from your dentist office and I've been fairly happy with it but it's the only electric toothbrush I've ever used so I've had nothing to compare it with. The one problem I've had with the Rotodent is that because the brush is so small and round I was getting some staining on the surface of my teeth and had to alternate using the RD with a regular toothbrush, so since my Rotodent was wearing out I was very interested to try another brand.<br /><br />I was excited to try the Sonic to see if I could avoid having to use two different brushes and especially because of the UV sanitizer which the Rotodent doesn't have and is a wonderful addition. I love being sure that my toothbrush is clean!<br /><br />My first experience was a bit startling. On the regular setting the brush has a bit of a high pitched whine so since then, I've used the 'sensitive' teeth setting and that works just great. There are two different brush heads, a regular size and a smaller size one. The toothbrush also comes with a travel charger and a travel bag which makes it super easy to take with you on vacation or on work trips.<br /><br />I have to say that my teeth feel cleaner then they ever have after I get done brushing with the Sonic (other than when the dentist cleans them), so if you're looking for clean and healthy teeth and gums this is a great choice.
  579. I love my Sonicare toothbrush. You just don't know how clean your mouth can be until you try one. This model comes with some new settings, basically a quick version and a rather intense deep cleaning version that massages your gums. It also has a travel charger and a brush cleaner mounted to the more stationary charger. These are handy additions, but the real value is the toothbrush. It's the last toothbrush you'll ever buy.
  580. I had the Sonicare Elite from 5 years ago, and its battery ran out (they're not replacable). I got the FlexCare and absolutely love it. It's a little quieter, quite a bit smaller, and *much* easier to clean. I use the UV cleaning but don't know if it's really useful. I've used the various modes (normal, max, massage, etc.) but don't think they're that important. If they come out with a lower-end model without all the various modes, the UV cleaner, etc., at a much lower price, I'd recommend that over this model. Still, over 5 years, the price of this model isn't too much to spend on your teeth.
  581. This toothbrush is great. It is smaller than the previous models yet seems even more powerful. Your teeth feel very cleaned and smooth. I've had mine for almost two weeks (2 x 2 mins a day) and the battery is still on 2 diods out of three. Great thing is that it has the travel charger for up to 220V. I don't really use the UV sanitizer and could do without it as well as without all the bells and whistles for little less money but so far I am very pleased. I used to have the AA battery operated e3000 which is a sure \\"self-destructor\\". I hope this one will last. My only complaint is about the second button, I seem to accidentally switch the modes while brushing because it is quite sensitive. Greatly recommended.
  582. I had the opportunity to receive this unit as a demo and I have been over the moon about it! Up until a couple weeks ago, I was using a battery operated oral-b disposable toothbrush. I had seen electric toothbrushes and I knew that dentists recommended them, but just couldn't imagine what was so great about them.<br /><br />Two weeks of using the sonicare flex care and I have to say, I'm a total convert. When my flexcare eventually dies, I will immediately go out and replace it with the best sonicare has to offer because this toothbrush is incredible.<br /><br />Other reviewers are right... this brush does take some getting used to. It will feel like an overpowered rocket in your mouth the first time or two you use it... but stick with it. Your teeth will feel dentist chair clean every time you brush. I've never been one to make brushing my teeth the biggest priority. I mean, it was something I did every day, but not something I really focused on...and I had the sensitive gums to show for it. I use the 3 minute max care cycle twice a day and truly find myself looking forward to brushing... no more \\"ugh, i'm already in bed and don't really feel like brushing...\\" I also find myself flossing a lot more too...mainly because I really see the benefits this brush offers and figure I should do the best I can for my teeth.<br /><br />When I first read the reviews, I didn't really believe that the flexcare would make a difference whitening my teeth. I'm pleased to say, I was quite wrong. I already see a noticeable difference in just two weeks. I also will do extra massaging on my gums in the mornings. My gums are pretty sensitive and prone to bleeding when I brush with a normal brush, but while I've had a tiny bit of sensitivity issues (no more than when I brushed with a regular brush), my gums have not bled once since using this toothbrush, and I've used the 3 minute max care (includes 15 seconds of gum massaging per quadrant) every time I've brushed. My model only came with a standard brush head, so I'm ordering the compact because I think it will be more comfortable for my smaller mouth. I also like that it is very compact, making it quite convenient for travel.<br /><br />The experience can be a bit messy, though I'm finally getting the hang of it. You definitely need to have the brush in your mouth before you start it or you'll end up with toothpaste all over you and your bathroom. I usually end up with toothpaste on the brush head stem and the base, but it is a snap to clean. I use the sanitizer every time I brush not because i'm a germaphobe, but because I'm drawn to things that are shiny and pretty and I love the litle blue light that shines through the sanitizer (yes, I'm a dork. a dork who loves her new toothbrush).<br /><br />I'll see what my dentist has to say on January 21 when I go in for my six month cleaning, but I already know it will probably be my best dentist visit ever. Seriously, if you're saying to yourself \\"that's all well and good, but only crazy idiots who are rich spend $180 on a toothbrush,\\" know that until 2 weeks ago, I was right there with you. But this toothbrush ranks right up there with my TIVO (with whom I have a serious relationship!) in terms of gadgets that truly changed my life. I smile more, I'm more comfortable about my smile, and I know I'm finally taking good care of my teeth. who knew!?!?brush head, so I'm ordering the compact because I think it will be more comfortable for my smaller mouth. I also like that it is very compact, making it quite convenient for travel. The experience can be a bit messy, though I'm finally getting the hang of it. You definitely need to have the brush in your mouth before you start it or you'll end up with toothpaste all over you and your bathroom. I usually end up with toothpaste on the brush head stem and the base, but it is a snap to clean.   585. I've had various Sonicare toothbrush models over the last 10 years or more. It has been my experience that this brand continues to improve with each new model. I've loved every Sonicare toothbrush I've owned, this being my favorite so far. Once you've used a Sonicare a few times I cannot imagine going back to a regular toothbrush, nor any other electric toothbrush. My husband and I are both big coffee and tea drinkers, and every time we are complimented on our teeth I attribute it to our Sonicare toothbrushes. We don't use whitening toothpastes or any other whitening products, but we do both use our Sonicare 2-3 times a day. On the rare occasion that I've been without my Sonicare I'm always shocked by how dirty my gums and teeth feel after brushing alone. It's more noticeable the next morning after brushing with a regular brush instead of the Sonicare. My mouth feels much cleaner when I wake up after having brushed with the Sonicare the night before. The UV cleaner is fairly fast and I think it's worth the investment. I still have all 4 of my wisdom teeth and so I like the compact brush heads vs. the standard b/c they can effectively clean the backs of my wisdom teeth which are usually hard to get to. One word of warning for those who haven't used a Sonicare before: be careful not to slip up and press the power button before you get the toothbrush head into your mouth or you'll end up with toothpaste everywhere!
  586. DO not buy this product. It lasted us 5 months..now it's completely dead. I have no idea why the battery is not recharging. Amazon please contact me to see what can be done about this please.
  587. Had it for 3 weeks now. Works fully as expected. Meets my expectations thus far. Really cuts down on the amount of toothpaste that I need to use (I did not get it for that reason). After every brushing, my teeth feel like they have been polished. Friends and the manual said not to press too hard, especially early on; I followed that advice and I did not have any problems with my gums hurting after first several uses. Now, after 3 weeks, I press a little more because I am acclimated to it, and pressing more feels good. I hope it continues to perform well for many yrs.
  588. Take my advice and get this for you dental benefits. It cleans the yellow right out of your teeth. Follow the directions and a year later you will have white teeth like me.<br /><br />This is the best toothbrush I have ever come across. It also has a built in 30 second reminder to tell you to switch to a new area of your mouth followed by an automatic 2 minute shutoff. The UV ray cleaner is a key feature that provides peace of mind that you are using a clean brushing tool free of germs and molecules. STICK THAT IN YOUR MOUTH!!
  589. This toothbrush has kept me out of the dentist office for repairs since I bought the first one 4 or 5 years ago. I bought the newer model in July 2011 and liked it very much and especially liked the new design which keeps gunk from accumulating in the head. When the new one began spontaneously turning itself on recently I contacted Phillips and they agreed to promptly send me a new one at no charge -- covered by the 2 year warranty. I arranged for the replacement in just a few minutes with a friendly Sonicare representative via Internet chat on their website.
  590. There is a screw in the brush head that works its way loose over time. It looks like it was threadlocked in place. Once the threadlocker fails, the toothbrush is useless. Retightening it will only buy you a little more time before it loosens again. I tried more threadlocker, but it didn't hold.<br /><br />The handle just buzzes harshly, and the brush doesn't clean well anymore.<br /><br />Also, scum and mildew build up on the heads and the base they sit on. If the stems were just a little longer, allowing the heads to sit up off the surface, it wouldn't be an issue.<br /><br />Opening the toothbrush will also seriously mar the base. even if you use the correct size screwdriver. The plastic is just too soft.<br /><br />For the money this cost, it should have been better designed and lasted a lot longer. And I just bought new brush heads too. Oh well. I'll give Oral-B a shot.
  591. Wow - I read many of the reviews in detail before I decided to shell out the bucks for this expensive toothbrush and finally after a couple weeks of arguing with that voice in my head about how big a waste it would be - I took the big bite and ordered it. Let me just say, the first couple times wasn't all that enjoyable and like many others, I forgot to place it in my mouth before turning it on. The plus side of that was my sink, counter, and mirror were cleaner for those first couple weeks than they had been in weeks. Once I got used to the feeling though, I really started to enjoy the toothbrush. The biggest drawback is that it has its own timer on when to shutoff - I feel like it needs to go for just a little longer - but not a big deal, I just hit the button again and brush until I feel I'm done - then turn it back off.<br /><br />Definitely recommend - teeth are actually starting to turn back to a whitish look rather than the coffee stained yellow.
  592. Have not had an electric toothbrush for about 10 years, but got the Sonicare after a dentist recommended. Brush seems to clean better than manual brushing and you get used to the vibration etc. A few quibbles: Phillips should have the brush remember the last setting. It resets to default \\"Quick Clean\\" 1 minute setting every time. Don't expect to hear the \\"beep\\" of the \\"Quadpacer\\", (the timer that does 15 seconds per quadrant in Quick Clean mode, or 30 seconds in \\"Max Clean\\") it really is just a pause. The lithium battery is not replaceable. Philips expects you to remove the battery for special disposal and toss the rest of the brush away, then buy a new one. Since lithium batteries have a fixed life, the battery should be user-replaceable. I expect that the brush will outlast the battery, so throwing it away is a waste. Additional note 2/1/10. Product quit working entirely in January 2010. Phillips replaced it at no charge, even though it was well out of warranty.
  593. I know, I know, that much for a toothbrush? Really? The price is the biggest drawback to this toothbrush. But if you decide to take the plunge, let me tell you what you're getting yourself into. I've owned a sonicare for several years now, and I have always been impressed with the level of performance. I'm moving up from a sonicare advance, which is their base model. I was blown away by the difference between the advance and the flexcare. I knew it would be better, but not this much. In my review, I will compare it to the advance for a reference. The Design: Compared to the advance, the design is much improved. The body is slimmer and therefore easier to maneuver around. The brush design was the best improvement. The advance uses a larger, more square shaped brush which makes it somewhat awkward to reach the teeth in the very back. The smaller, more rounded brush head on the flexcare makes it so easy to reach all of the teeth in my mouth. Also, the screw on brush head is gone. Yippee! The brush head now slides on and locks into place. With the screw on models, gunk and grime would build up underneath the threads which made me very queasy. I think my favorite improvement comes with the new design on the base charger. In the older models, the toothbrush would fit into the charger, so about an inch of the toothbrush was hidden while on the charger. This design inevitably lead to a build up of gunk on the bottom of the brush and on the inside of the charger unless you completely dried off the toothbrush before placing it into the charger base. This was very annoying and gross to look at. Philips redesigned the base with the flexcare. Now the base charger is completely flat with a little peg sticking up in the middle. The toothbrush has a complimentary hole in the bottom for the peg to fit into. Now the toothbrush is completely exposed to the air so it dries out better. No more gunk! Also, it would be pretty easy to share this toothbrush with someone else, assuming you have your own brush head :) Performance/Features: Performance is great. Simple as that. My teeth feel dentist clean every time I use it. The brush has a couple different settings to fit your different moods, but the normal clean mode turns the brush on for two minutes, which is divided into 30 seconds for each quadrant. The brush signals each quadrant change by a split second interruption in the brushing action. I almost would have preferred a beep, but this works ok. For the first 14 brush cycles, this unit ramps up on the intensity of the brush action. If you use a sonicare currently, you should have no problem adjusting to this. I didn't notice any of the irritating tickling vibrations common on the sonicare brushes. If you've never used a sonicare, don't worry too much. Everyone always becomes accustom to the vibrations, and after a few brush cycles you won't even notice it anymore. UV Sanitizer: It's an interesting addition to the toothbrush. I can't comment on how well it works since I don't have the means to test that, but you simply detach the brush head and put it into the UV compartment for a 15(?) minute cleaning cycle. A toothbrush that cleans itself, nifty. Overall this is a great toothbrush. If you're unwilling to spend the big bucks for this model, and I certainly understand, I would suggest getting the flexcare without the sanitizer or go for the elite model. Heck, you can't go wrong with any of the sonicare models, as they are all improvements over the manual sticks you have been using.
  594. This is my fourth Sonicare product. I \\"upgraded\\" from the basic Sonicare model to this newest model. It is much lighter and feels a little more powerful than the previous models. It is compact and the cord storage and travel charger are really handy. While waiting for it to arrive, I went a week or two with just a manual toothbrush and I definitely felt the difference in terms of my overall oral health and \\"freshness.\\" (I am an efficient brusher manually, but it just does a better job. Period.) I could hardly wait for it to charge overnight to get a good and thorough cleaning. My experience is that the brushes do have a limited life, (just over two years and just after the limited warranty expires), before they die. I brush 2-4X a day. However, even knowing it will not last forever, I consider the price a worthy investment for the time I do get to use it and am happy to replace it every few years. I will be a lifetime user unless someone else makes something even better... so far, they haven't.

  603. I have enjoyed this toothbrush greatly WHILE IT LASTED.<br /><br />The problem is that for the money I spent, and the minimal daily use it got (two brushings per day by a single user.), the value just isn't there.<br /><br />Having bought two of these, and known another purchaser, none of our top end models has lasted long enough to engender confidence in the durability of the motors or mechanisms of Sonicare electric toothbrushes. Unless of course, you are grading reliability on lasting less than two years. The motors go bad, become a noisy racket, and thus, do not vibrate well enough to clean properly. Bad.<br /><br />The replacement price for the exact same toothbrush without the charging station and UV Sanitizer (which I originally purchased as a package) is $149. from a third party distributor (not Amazon fulfilled). Other options to replace just the broken brush handle itself are not the most desirable because they come bulk packaged, which questions the authenticity.<br /><br />At the rate of failure these Sonicare toothbrushes have shown over three purchases (around 16-24 months), the cost of operation to own this toothbrush, along with the ongoing brush head replacements, is well over $10.00-$13.00 every month. And that is a permanent situation. Its like having a lease, with no option to buy. You can use it as long as you keep on paying, and paying, and paying...<br /><br />Electric toothbrushes are fantastic, but technology must exist to manufacture more reliable motors and mechanisms. Draw your own conclusions on why Sonicare does not offer that technology. I know I have.

  606. I have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for about two years now. I started off with the Elite model and have recently upgraded to the FlexCare. The best part of the FlexCare are its 5 timed brushing options: 2 minute clean, sensitive, massage, 1 minute (Go Care) and 3 minute (Max Care). I like to use the 3 minutes when I can and cut down to the 1 minute for a quick clean when I have to run out of the house in a hurry. The next best part of the timer is the quadpacer which gives a slight pause to help break up the time brushing into 4 sections. The UV sanitizing system seems like a good idea, just put the brush head in, push a button and UV light cleans any bacteria on the brush head. The new style brush heads are smaller, easier to put on and seem to keep a lot cleaner at the base where they connect to the handle. The travel charge is nice so you don't have to lug around the large charger and UV sanitizing base. It also has a nice 3 light battery level monitor. My ONLY complaint so far is with the \\"luxury\\" soft travel case. My previous brush came with a hard plastic case that fit the brush head and handle perfectly. The soft travel case is just a cheap fabric bag to throw the brush in. Not a huge deal as Sonicare has improved the condition of my teeth as I now have less problems at the dentist. I believe this is because of the sonic fast pulsing of the brush head and timer that allows me to brush for the full recommended time. If you have never timed yourself brushing your teeth you might be surprised, sometimes 2 minutes can feel like an eternity, especially if you're in a hurry.
  607. I love the brush, the small piece to travel with, the fresh feeling after brushing, the timer to make sure I spend enough time everywhere.   615. I love how clean sonic brushing is for the teeth. Phillips customer service did not have a replacement part.   616. The handle has a serious design flaw. It leaks water into the unit causing it to short out. Some people get a year or so before this happens. I contacted Phillips about the issue as my replacement handle has also shorted out. Please see my conversation below with the rep:<br /><br />Welcome to Philips Chat, you're chatting with Shawn. How may I help you?<br /><br />Shawn: Hello ryan. How are you doing today?<br /><br />Ryan: Shawn, I purchased a new Flexcare system back in June 2010 from Amazon. The handle quit working and it was replaced under warranty in May of 2012. Now, the replacement handle has also quit working. The problem is that water gets inside the handle and shorts the electronics out. I know this is a problem your company is aware of because there are hundreds of reviews out there about this issue. Now that my warranty is expired, I am hesitant to spend the money to order another one. What are your thoughts on this issue?<br /><br />Shawn: It seems that you are typing some text. Would you please send the text that you have typed so I know you are still connected with me?<br /><br />Shawn: I aapologize for the inconvenience and will be glad to assist you.<br /><br />Shawn: As your unit's 2 year warrenty is expired, at this point of time, the best option that I can suggest to you is to purchase a new unit and to help offset some of the cost, we can offer you 15% off your total Sonicare purchase along with free shipping at our online store.<br /><br />Shawn: If you are interested to buy the new Toothrush, should I go ahead and help you with the 15% discount code?<br /><br />Ryan: But why should I have to replace the toothbrush every 1.5 years?<br /><br />Shawn: The expcted lifetime of the product depends upon the usage and the way it is maintained.<br /><br />Ryan: So you have this lifetime vs. maintenance schedule posted somewhere?<br /><br />Shawn: I do understand your concern Ryan, I wish I could help you more on this but at this point of time I can only suggest you to buy new Toothbrush with the 15% discount.<br /><br />Ryan: The HX6921/02 is on Amazon for $119.95 free shipping.   617. Good toothbrush for it's entire short life of seventeen months. I expected it to last longer than it did but it did not.
  618. Since purchasing this toothbrush, my dentist and hygienist have both commented on well my teeth and gums are doing. I love the three settings and the carrying case makes it easy to take with me when I travel.
  619. My wife and I received one of these for a gift about 5 years ago. She still uses it to the present! I must admit, I was not too excited about the gift at first. But once we began to use it, we knew it was a great gift! The results were notice by our dental hygentists. The system and my trusted brand of toothpaste make my teeth feel so much cleaner than any other toothbrush I have ever used (manual or electric/battery operated). An ultraviolet light cleans the brush heads after each use or when you choose to do so (two at a time). The brush heads can be identifled with color-coded rings per user. There are several modes, which may be selected to clean teeth. Has a timer-type mode, which may be valuable in teaching the kids to brush. We have not had to make any repairs. Only have purchased new brush heads as needed. They seem a little pricey at approximately $10/head. However, coupons and price specials can ease the stress on the wallet! Excellent system! You will not be disappointed!
  620. Having used this product for a month now and gotten over the intense tickling it originally caused I am very happy with it. Use is easy and I like the sanitizer also. A good buy for the money. I would recommend its use to anyone who has difficulty brushing all their teeth with a manual brush.
  621. The whole package is expensive, even more is the replacement brushes. The compact head is much better than the standard. However, the design of the brush is only good for brushing along the gumline outside and reaching the last back teeth. It is useless to brush the horizonal surfaces, definitely cannot brush any part and the gumline of the inside dentition. I consider it is a failure. I needed to use manual brush to do the main job. Now I have abandoned the Flexcare and just use the manual brush to save the trouble. I may want to look for Oral B's new smartguide model. Sonicare does have problem in brush design all the time since inception.
  622. My husband and I have been using this brush for a month now. Because it comes with 2 separate brush heads, 2 people can use it. Neither of us remotely misses our old \\"manual\\" brushes. As with any new product, the FlexCare took a little bit of getting used to, but now it is quite comfortable and our teeth feel extraordinarily clean. Yes, it is loud, but it's not a significant drawback.
  623. My previous Oral-B Sonic Complete was holding less and less of a charge, so it was time to look for a new brush. I've used just about every type of high-end electric toothbrush, going back to the original InterPlak. I've also owned Oral B ProCare, SonicCare Classic and Elite, and the Oral B Sonic Complete. I can say without a doubt that this is toothbrush system produces the strongest vibrations ever. My teeth feel exceptionally clean after brushing with this. Two things I really like about these model. First of all, there's a battery meter. I can't tell you how many times I've started brushing my teeth and have other models quit on me half way through. I only like to recharge it when the battery is very low -- that is to prevent rechargeable battery memory. The other thing I like are the selectable modes. The Go Care provides a quick 1 minute freshen up. And the Max Care provides a deep 3 minute session with alternating massage and clean modes. The UV sanitizer is there if you need it. Personally, I think it's a marketing gimmick for paranoid germ fearing suckers. It lights up pretty. The only reason to use it you want to share your brush with someone, I guess. Or you brush your dog's teeth with it.

  625.   626. Love this product, makes my cleaning visits to the dentist alot shorter. Makes my teeth & gums feel really refreshed & clean. Love the UV sanitizer.
  627. 11/13/09 - I had older Sonicare and after years of use/abuse it finally died when it hit the floor one too many times. I got this new, slimmer model. After using it for probably 9-10 months, the metal prong that fits into brush head became loose and noisy. I read other reviews here of similar issue and lengthly replacement times. I called Phillips/Sonicare Customer Service. They were courtious and very helpful. After telling them I had no receipt (my sister had got this new one for me) and guessing it's age, they asked for the code on the bottom. They said they could tell it was still within warranty and that they'd get a replacement out to me. TWO DAYS later I received new unit in the mail! And package tube had new label for me to return broken unit back to them. The whole (short) process from beginning to end was truly exemplary customer service! I have loved my Sonicare tooth brushes and was very relieved that they stood behind their product and service.
  628. I've not used an electric toothbrush in the past, but this one was recommended by my dentist's hygienist, and I decided it would help me reach the hard-to-reach back teeth. I've been happy with the product. It's pricey, and the smaller of the two brush heads that came with the machine seems too small to be of much use (and the replacements are expensive), but I would recommend this product to anyone who can afford to pay $170 for a toothbrush.
  629. I purchased the flexCare with the sanitizer as a replacement for an old Sonic Care A model: Advanced. My old Sonic Care wore out (batteries ceased to hold a charge). I am very happy with the FlexCare!! It is much lighter than the old a-series. I note that initially the FlexCare was a little noisey, but, this noise went away after a few uses. My teeth feel smooth and very clean. I am so glad I purchased this brush. It feels good to my gums and my teeth feel great!!!!! I wanted the sanitizer after watching a news report about the amount of E-Coli found on surfaces and items in the bathroom. The brush head is used for 3 months, giving it plenty of time to accumulate the bacteria that is found in feces (E-Coli). I noted in another review that the reviewer was concerned about too much sanitizing and use of anti-bacterials. However, the need for the sanitizer is real due to the nature of the type of bacteria floating around most bathrooms. All in all, I would recommend this product to anyone who is looking for a great toothbrush!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
  630. The FlexCare replaces my old Philips Sonicare Advanced model, which lasted me over 8 years! I've had the newer model for well over 6 months and it works exactly like the previous model, but with some marked improvements. The much smaller and simpler FlexCare brush heads make for a much cleaner experience, especially if you travel and have to remove the head to put it in the travel case. The different cleaning modes are a nice touch (the Massage mode is quite effective), but I find the standard cleaning method to be more than enough. And the simplified charger connection makes keeping the charger clean that much easier, and allows for a much smaller travel charger. But those improvements, as significant as they are, pale in comparison to the Sonicare cleaning experience overall. You literally feel like you've left the dentist's office after a cleaning (sans the pain, of course) every time you brush your teeth. If you've never had a Sonicare, or gone with a cheaper electronic toothbrush, you owe it to yourself to buy one. And if you are an Advanced user and want a simpler experience, the FlexCare models are great. To be honest, I've had mine for 6 months and never had to use the sanitizer feature, so if you want to save the money, you can buy the lower model and still get most of the benefits. Either way, I highly recommend checking this out.
  631. I've been using Sonicares for about 10 years. Totally hooked and could never go back to a regular toothbrush. You really can feel a significant difference in how clean your teeth feel. I'm on my third one now, as eventually they do lose their charge and it just becomes an annoyance (especially if choosing to travel without the charger). Going from the Elite to the Flexcare, the Flexcare has a much improved design with narrow handle, very attractive blue and silver trim, ridges on back for better gripping, and most significantly a head which easily pops off for santizing and you never have to deal with the issues of what builds up inside it where it connects. (Apparently these replacement heads cost less, so that's good.) Performance-wise, I honestly find them exactly the same. Didn't feel any difference in the intensity or quality of vibration/cleaning. Was not jonesing for a santizier, but now that I have it I figure I might as well use it daily. Who knows if it makes much of a difference. The one flaw, in my opinion, and that is that when you are holding the base there is a button that often accidentally gets pressed and it changes the type of cleaning mid-cycle. (There are 5 different cleaning choices but I have no use for any except the standard 2 minute one.) This seems to happen about every other time I brush. I don't think I'm gripping it particularly hard - I think that button is just very soft. Price seems exorbitant. I missed the inventory at Costco and bought the double set for myself and my husband on Ebay. The double set is very hard to find. So overall, would highly recommend Sonicares, but this one might be overpriced because it's the newer model. If you already have one, I would say you'll be fine with the one you have, and suggest perhaps waiting until the price comes down more.
  632. This is my second Sonicare, been using them for 10 years or so. Purchased this one 1.5 years ago and this week it started buzzing (low level alarm) in the charger. I called Sonicare (Philips), they asked my name and are sending me a new handset with no further action on my part. I'm a fan of companies that stand behind thier products - and I'll be buying more Philips products in the near future.

  634. Which is not often. Seriously, Sonicare has serious quality issues. I had two of these, one lasted longer than the other. One Sonicare brush lasted nearly 2 years and died *just* within warranty okay, I thought it was a one off. Then I got this one and this one lasted *way* less time as in it died within 6 months. All I ever did that was \\"out of the norm\\" which I use loosely is when I changed the heads, I gently swabbed it with alcohol to clean the filth that had accumulated where the brush mounts. I had done this exact same thing with every other electric toothbrush I have ever owned and had no issues doing this (even with the previous sonicare) until this one gave me the issue. This means either I have the worst possible luck or Philips cheaps out on their seals and the thing isn't remotely as watertight as it should be. On another note, i've had huge issues with other philips items such as earbuds and whatnot. But on the other hand, if you are fine with the reliability issues, it is a great toothbrush and made my teeth feel incredibly clean when it worked so if you have the money for frequent replacements, go for it. Just don't get a stockpile of replacement brush heads since you probably won't get your money's worth.

  638. I purchased the HX6932/10, FlexCare with Sanitizer for around a $150 2 yrs 6 months ago at the recommendation of my dentist. It produced such fantastic results that even my dentist was surprised. For cleaning and dental hygiene effectiveness, I highly recommend this product. However, I could only give it three stars because the agitator shaft broke six months after the two year warranty expired. The only option is to throw the unit away, with its batteries, in the landfill. I've regarded Philips has being irresponsible in their approach to consumer products. FlexCare is an outstanding product, but did not last as long as it should have, in my opinion. Nor does it have removable/replaceable batteries. Having said that, I will probably replace it with another one, since the results were so impressive. One more point: Some reviews I've seen say that battery life is abysmal. I have not found that to be the case. I run the battery down to zero once a month, and two and a half years later I can still get well over a week's worth of use out of a single charge.
  639. Update to the below: I've been on hold for 35 minutes and counting, trying to get warranty support for my broken toothbrush. (Figure I may as well write this as I wait.) I guess that gives you an idea of Phillips' customer service... I absolutely love Sonicare toothbrushes and have used them for nearly 10 years, always getting rave reviews at semi-annual dentist checkups. In short, these are the absolute best toothbrushes for dental care. Every time you use it, you feel like you just stepped out of the dentist's office after a cleaning (except there's no pain!) When I purchased my Flexcare in September 2009, I'd owned three Sonicares before (two Advances over a several-year period, each lasting 3-4 years, which in my mind is OK, and one of the battery-operated ones for extended travel, since the older models didn't have dual-voltage chargers). The Flexcare was the best of all of them so far, both in streamlined design, charger size, dual-voltage capability and brush head design. However, after 11 months, it began turning on by itself in the middle of the night. Within a week, it was completely dead. I hate to give such a great product only one star, but to pay that much for something and have it last less than a year is inexcusable. We'll see how tough the customer service routine is to get a replacement ...
  640. I absolutely love brushing my teeth with this toothbrush! I used to think electric toothbrushes were a huge waste of money because I never had any problems brushing my teeth without one, but I finally decided to try one out after hearing so many great things. It really takes the brushing experience to a whole new level and I feel like I just came home from the dentist after each use. Typically I am pretty frugal and don't like to spend that much money on something that seems so trivial, but Sonicare really makes you feel like it's worth the high price. The toothbrush itself is enough, but all of the included accessories are of fantastic quality as well. The different modes are a great feature as stupid as they may seem, but I love using the timer function depending on what kind of brushing session I am looking for. At night I typically turn it to MaxCare for a solid 3 minute clean, whereas after lunch I just go for the quick 1 minute GoClean. I have not used the UV cleaner as much as I thought I would, and I am not going to get out a petri dish to test its effectiveness, but if it works half as well as the toothbrush it's worth price and also looks nice on the counter. Just be careful not to open your mouth while brushing, that takes a little while to get used to. Other than that, I don't think I have ever been so pleased with a product in my entire life.

  643. We bought this to replace a very old Sonicare that finally stopped working. The new one is lighter and smaller, and the performance is great--our teeth get really clean. We also like that the new brush head design uses much less plastic and metal, so there's less waste. On these two points, it gets five stars. But why is it that companies nearly always tack on a bunch of bells and whistles and don't quite design for the way people really use the product? We don't see any real need for the massage and sensitive settings and just use the standard one. The go-care (about one minute instead of two) can be helpful. What's really annoying, though, is that while the brush is running, the silver button is too easy to touch, so we end up in the sensitive or the massage modes unless we're careful to hold the wand at the far end. We have used the UV sanitizer, but, of course, there's really no way to tell how well that works. The little travel charger, which we used on a recent trip, is handy, but it would be nice if it had a couple of pegs to store the brushes on. Normally, the brushes are evidently meant to be stored within the sanitizer, and the sanitizer run every time the brushes are used. But we prefer to just leave the brushes out in the air most of the time and also not have the charger (most likely) sucking electricity constantly. The brushes do stand up on their own on the counter, although they're fairly easy to knock over.
  644. Bought this because of all the positive reviews and wasn't disappointed.   656. I've used a Sonicare Advance since 2001. They are, in my opinion, top notch toothbrushes.<br /><br />In fact, people were such a fan of my Sonicare FlexCare that they stole it from the dorm bathroom when I went to get my toothpaste. When I discovered the loss, the first thing I did was to go online and immediately purchase another. (I ended up purchasing the FlexCare without UV, which other than having a lime green handle and no UV, is functionally identical).<br /><br />Other toothbrushes rotate- this is a million steps above. The bristles clean deep. It's easy to use and has several modes. The normal clean is a 2 minute, 30 second per side (lower front, lower back, upper front, upper back) program. Then there's GoCare (15 seconds each - good if you want to do a brief brushing after a meal or something), MaxCare (3 minutes, 45 seconds each - 30 seconds normal, 15 doing a pulse). Sensitive turns down the power a bit, and oddly enough, I've never tried massage.<br /><br />The toothbrush will start you off easy. If you are a regular flosser/good brusher, or you own an older Sonicare, you probably don't want 14 days of gentle ramping up. If you want to disable Easy Start for whatever reason, put the toothbrush on the charger base and hold the power button for 5 seconds. One beep means you just disabled it, two beeps means you turned it back on.<br /><br />Now, time for some pros and cons vs. the ancient advance I had:<br />+This brush is much smaller and the rubber is more ergonomic.<br />+The old brushes were bulkier too, the newer brushes are better. Additionally, the older brushes had exposed magnets, which would easily detach. Newer brushes do not.<br />+The old handle had a recessed area. This tended to build up with all kinds of crap. This newer model is not recessed, and as per the manual's recommendation, you should wash out the bottom of the brush and the top of the handle (where you attach the brush). This probably goes without saying, but don't submerge thehandle...<br />+The charger base on the old Sonicare was also recessed. This newer model is just like the brush handle- no area for gunk to build up.<br />+The UV base provides a clean, closed compartment to store your brushes, in addition to cleaning them.<br />-The newer brush heads are notably more expensive than the older ones.<br />-I paid a similar price for my Advance, and got a second brush with hard travel case. This comes with a travel charger, but no second handle, and only a soft case.<br />-My dentist doubts the need for the UV cleaner and advises people to buy the FlexCare without it. Better safe than sorry, and I got the UV cleaner model on sale, so it was the same price anyways.<br />-Just like older models, there's no removeable battery. If it stays at home, no big deal, but if you travel...<br /><br />Easily recommended, great toothbrush. Sonicare support is also amazing- a friend of mine had an Elite that just died a couple months after the two year warranty expired. Philips took him at his word and shipped him a brand new brush for free- no need to send the old one back. That's customer service, in my book. Also, my Advance of 8 years worked fine- I just heard the newer models were better and opted to upgrade.
  657. I've owned this brush for about two weeks. It was an upgrade from one of those cheaper Crest Spin brushes. It has worked just fine and the automatic timer feature is really nice. I was also pleased to see it comes with two charging cords. One for the larger base unit, and a minimal charger cord that is easy to pack for traveling with the brush.<br /><br />I did not find the brush action irritating at all when using it and noise was not an issue.   662. Had the last model, think called elite, and it worked great for 3 or 4 years until it died in India. Wasn't brushing out of the Yamuna or Ganga river water either. The new model is easier to hold, has soft brush for gums as well as teeth. It's lighter. These features may not be important but together, despite recommendations I can brush in 30 seconds or less if pushed. Makes mouth and gums feel good.
  663. This toothbrush was amazing, but unfortunately it broke within a year so I have to give this a product a THUMBS DOWN!!!

I originally bought the model with the sanitizer but that never worked well and I soon gave up using it. Save your money for the replacement heads.

I am a regular dental patient and always get compliments on my well taken care of mouth. I highly recommend buying one of these, especially is you are not so keen on flossing daily.

Do NOT believe a word these people tell you! It is a good product as long as it is WORKING, if it works!   671. This is the second Sonicare toothbrush I have used in the past few years. The first one I had was an older model but gave similar results. I used the previous model for almost 2 years while I had braces and for each of my semi-annual checkups at the dentist, the dental hygienist was amazed at how clean my teeth were even with braces. The previous model ended up breaking as the buttons got corroded, and stopped working, but given how well the toothbrush worked at cleaning my teeth I decided to give Sonicare another chance. I've now had this model for almost a year and a half now and it looks like Sonicare really worked to improve their quality. After using 3+ times daily for 1.5 years, I have not noticed any wear on the buttons and am confident this will last. In addition to an improvement in quality, the flexcare model uses the smaller, ProResults brush heads. Previous Sonicare models required a large replacement head that I always thought was a huge waste and very environmentally unfriendly. The ProResults brush heads use what looks like half as much plastic. It would have been nice if Sonicare passed some of the materials savings onto the consumer, but the replacement heads seem to be about the same cost from what I remember. I also really like the addition of the UV Sanitizer. I've read research that this may be more of a gimmick than anything else, but nonetheless I like the ability to \\"quarantine\\" my brush head away from whatever germs may floating around in between brushings. Additionally, the two brush head holders in the sanitizer make it easy for two people to share the Sonicare and have their individual brush heads. This is one way you can offset the high cost (relative to a normal toothbrush). I am 100% satisfied with this Sonicare and I recommend it to all of my friends. I also bought one for my father recently and he has nothing to say but good things as well. I have always believed there are good things to spend money on and products that improve your health definitely fall into that category. I continue to get great feedback from my dentist and the Sonicare is the main reason. It makes perfect sense to proactively take good care of your teeth/gums in order to prevent future issues. Not only will any dental work as a result of poor dental health be much more expensive than this toothbrush, but there's always the chance that whatever damage is done cannot be reversed. Do yourself a favor and buy this toothbrush now to save yourself a headache (or toothache) later.
  672. This is the second electric toothbrush I've owned and mostly love it. It is a little more powerful than my older one from a different brand and the multiple options are great. I don't use the UV sanitizer very often since it seems a little gimmicky but it's nice piece of mind and someplace enclosed to store the brush head. My only complaints would be that stuff can dribble down under the brush head while using it, necessitating its removal and cleaning after every use. My older brand never had this issue and kept everything off the body of the device. The other thing is the mode button underneath the power button is way too easy to activate, just the simple act of picking it up can trigger it if your not careful. About 30% of the time even after owning it a few years I still end up accidentally triggering the quick brush mode because that button is way too soft and easy to hit.
  673. I have had the original Philips rechargeable toothbrush for many years and when it came time to get a new one, I went again with my dentist's recommendation and selected this FlexCare model. The battery life is excellent (so far about 2 weeks on its initial charge), the slimmer design is easier to hold and maneuver, and the 3 selectable 'speeds' are very useful. Top notch product!
  674. I have only had this toothbrush for two days now and I have to say that I am in love already. I wish I would have invested the money in my oral care when this first came out because it is worth every penny. The feel of the brush takes some getting used to the first time (only because the vibration really tickles) but once you get used to this you will have the best cleaning experience of your life. Day two and my teeth are already whiter, and they feel fantastic! Thanks Philips, I am sold for life!
  675. I purchased this product after one of my other family members told me how great it was. The massaging action and different brush heads insure my teeth feel \\"just out of the dentist\\" clean! The UV cleaning system is good too, I have seen too many TV shows that tell us how much bacteria are on our toothbrush!
  676. I have had no less than 10 Philips Sonicare tootbrushes over the years for our family. I don't know if it is the best clinically but these things always break at some point and Philips Customer Care is amazing. I will keep giving them my business as they deserve it.
  677. Your Dentist is like your Mom and Dad: really, they just want what's best for you. Of course, sometimes what's best isn't always what's practical. I've had the Sonicare suggested to me by my dentist for a few years now. At this last checkup, my dentist spotted a problem area where brushing just can't reach: the very pits of my molars are pretty deep. When I thought about the price--and complete lack of fun--involved in getting my head drilled, I decided a hundred bucks was worth the investment to avoid a cavity. The last filling I had was twice that.<br /><br />The Sonicare comes with its own small charging base. It's really simple to set up and with daily use the battery should last for a couple of weeks. Battery life depends on how you use it, and the nice thing about the Sonicare is that you can change your mind any time: there's \\"Go Care\\", which will run the brush for a minute, and \\"Max Care\\", which will give you a full 2 minutes of time. I tend to do Go Care in the morning, Max Care at night. You can also adjust for \\"I want you to focus on cleaning\\", \\"I have sensitive gums\\", and \\"I'm really in the mood for a good gum massage\\". I'm typically more no-nonsense than that and just focus on cleaning. One drawback is that the battery is not replaceable, so I'm not sure how many charges the Sonicare is good for.<br /><br />The technology behind Sonicare deserves some mention. This isn't an 'electric toothbrush' - I still work it across my teeth and gums like a normal toothbrush. The difference is that the head pulses and emits sonic waves that shake the microscopic ick that you've accumulated right off your teeth. The vibration doesn't rattle your head or make your eyes water: it sounds like you're gargling with a lightsaber, but the feeling amounts to a mild vibration that leaves your gums tingly.<br /><br />The last time I had an electric toothbrush, it was heavier than the Sonicare, despite being much shorter. It had a shorter stem where the Sonicare's attachment head is long and slender, and I had a tendency to drool messily down the thing--while the Sonicare doesn't cause me that problem at all. The Sonicare brush comes with one of each head: a large and a small. Both have long stems but one has a smaller run of bristles for smaller mouths.<br /><br />Using my Sonicare for two weeks now, the effects have been noticeable: it's not just the odd sensation that my toothbaste has almost taken on the texture of whipped cream...it's also that my mouth feels clean like the Dentist just got through with it. Even with \\"Max Care\\" and \\"Clean\\" settings, I don't have that achy, itchy gums feeling that a Water Pik turned on full can do. Instead, I have this odd sensation that this is what good brushing should feel like.<br /><br />The Sonicare package I purchased here at Amazon came with:<br /><br />- a small charger just slightly wider than the toothbrush<br />- a larger charging base with UV sanitizer (to kill stray bacteria accumulated on the head)<br />- the connector plug<br />- two heads for the brush<br />- a travel carrying case<br /><br />All of it was packed into a relatively small box and the heads even have a plastic cap to slip over the bristles when you're not using the toothbrush.<br /><br />If you care about your teeth, the Sonicare will help you do what you need. Whether you're OCD-obsessive about teeth and gums or you just want to have clean teeth without a lot of effort, this is definitely worth the investment. The only downside is that the battery is not designed to be replaceable--but if I get even two years' daily use out of it, I think I'll still call it money well spent.is long and slender, and I had a tendency to drool messily down the thing--while the Sonicare doesn't cause me that problem at all. The Sonicare brush comes with one of each head: a large and a small. Both have long stems but one has a smaller run of bristles for smaller mouths. Using my Sonicare for two weeks now, the effects have been noticeable: it's not just the odd sensation that my toothbaste has almost taken on the texture of whipped cream...it's also that my mouth feels clean like the Dentist just got through with it. Even with \\"Max Care\\" and \\"Clean\\" settings, I don't have that achy, itchy gums feeling that a Water Pik turned on full can do. Instead, I have this odd sensation that this is what good brushing should feel like. The Sonicare package I purchased here at Amazon came with: - a small charger just slightly wider than the toothbrush - a larger charging base with UV sanitizer (to kill stray bacteria accumulated on the head) - the connector plug - two heads for the brush - a travel carrying case All of it was packed into a relatively small box and the heads even have a plastic cap to slip over the bristles when you're not using the toothbrush. If you care about your teeth, the Sonicare will help you do what you need. Whether you're OCD-obsessive about teeth and gums or you just want to have clean teeth without a lot of effort, this is definitely worth the investment. The only downside is that the battery is not designed to be replaceable--but if I get even two years' daily use out of it, I think I'll still call it money well spent.

  722. When the commercials say \\"straight from the dentist clean\\", its no joke. This bush is wonderful. My dentist even notices the difference.
