  723. I have been using Sonicare electric toothbrushes for many years. Although I liked the brushing action of the old design, I hated the design of the brush head itself because the screw-in head became all gunked up and nasty if you didn't take it off the motor and clean it regularly. Otherwise, they were virtually indestructible. Those who use the old design know what I'm talking about. Only time I had to replace them was when the sealed Ni-Cad battery died and failed to keep a charge, usually lasting about 5 years.<br /><br />Then they took a page out of Oral-B's playbook and changed and simplified the brush head design whereby they are inserted onto a metal post like the Oral-B design rather than screwed on. Now it is much easier to change and keep the brush head / inter-connect area clean. I also like the fact that they switched to lighter Li-Ion battery and the charge seems to last longer. The brushing action also feels more powerful than the old design. The UV sanitizing chamber is bit gimmicky but at least the science behind it is sound. I love the Sonicare brushes in general. The reason I deducted 3 stars is because with this particular model, I had 3 units fail prematurely in less than 2 years where the metal post retaining the brush head had come off the main body. Once that happens, the water-tight seal is broken and the unit is rendered useless. Being a dental care professional, when I called the Philips service center to address my concerns, their reply was perfunctory at best and only emphasized the fact that my warranty had expired. Therefore, I'd be weary of recommending this particular model; I'm not certain if they improved or corrected this design weakness with FlexCare Plus. I would consider a newer model without the UV chamber for less money or DiamondClean model.<br /><br />Currently, I've been using DiamondClean model for about a year and half now without any issues.
  724. My original Sonicare with NiCad battery finally couldn't give me enough charge for one brushing so it was upgrade time.<br /><br />This LiOn powered model easily lasts 3 or more weeks of daily brushing, is thinner and the new head style (vs the old vibrating magnet style) feels like a more focused brushing. I'm totally sold on daily use of a Sonicare (along with flossing of course), as the dental hygienist has almost never found plaque in the years since I began using one, and my gum health has been great. (Gum recession necessitating surgery by a periodontist first got us on Sonicare about 6 years ago.)<br /><br />The only thing I don't like about this FlexCare unit is the mode switch's location and sensitivity. If I hold the device the way that I'd like to, my index finger too easily brushes against the mode button and the mode changes. I've learned to hold it closer to the base, but it isn't comfortable. Hence, 4 vs 5 stars.
  725. I have had Sonicare brushes for at least 15 years - bought the first one from my dentist, and it lasted forever.   726. I've used Sonicare toothbrushes for as long as I can remember. I've used this particular model for over 4 years! My teeth are very healthy because of them. It does it's job and is very durable. I have to replace the brush heads every few months though. Buy it! Definitely worth the value!
  727. I got this a couple of weeks ago and it is hands down better than my old oralb sonic complete. My wife loves the compact brush and the other is perfect for me. On the first use it was obvious this was a superior product. My teeth just felt clean. I have had problems with sensitive and bleeding gums for years and since switching to this toothbrush the problem has gone away. The regular mode gives you plenty of time for each quadrant and the quick clean is perfect for that hurried morning, it still gives a good and still has quadrant timer so you get an even brushing. I thought the price was a little high but now that I have used the toothbrush for a little while it was worth every cent.
  728. The timer function is very useful. This little machine cleans my teeth far better than a regular, manual toothbrush. And with the timer, I know I'm not scimping on one or another area.
  729. Great toothbrush but doesn't last forever (must register on Sonicare's website!). I didn't use all the different \\"modes\\"- I have sensitive teeth but didn't notice any difference in the \\"sensitive\\" mode. Your teeth do need a few weeks to adjust to the vibration. I wouldn't pay extra for the UV sanitizer- it makes the bristles brittle so I rarely use it. I always need more than the 2 minute timer allows- I wish they had a model without the quadpacer. I buy a big pack of heads at Costco but only replace the heads every 4-5 months and take them off the brush to clean the connection every other week.<br /><br />The cheaper \\"HealthWhite\\" [[ASIN:B0019ZEVZU Philips Sonicare HX6711/02 HealthyWhite 710 Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush]] cleans just as good but the battery needs to be charged every other week (I don't leave it on the charger)- the higher end models have a much longer battery life. If you get a cheaper model- I would recommend the ones with the smaller heads and handle profile like this one. The cheap-cheap ones have bulky handles and crap gets gunked under the heads worse than these models. The rotating OralB ones are lame from what I've seen.<br /><br />I've gone through 2 of these exact same models- my dad never used the one I bought him so after my first one burnt out in 2 years I stole his back lol. They lasted about 2 years each- maybe I am hard on them? Now I bought the cheapest \\"HealthyWhite\\" (without the sensitive setting) which lasted a little over a year before making loud grinding noise (the head starts to wobble). But this time I had registered it on Sonicare's website (extends warranty to 2.5 years) and they just sent me a brand new replacement (actually an upgraded model) free of charge after a quick webchat! I wish I would of kept track of the first 2 I bought but out well- I'd still buy one every year for $80 a pop because they work so great.
  730. It worked well for the first year. The UV light burned out quickly but as I'm not a germaphobe I didn't mind then the toothbrush stopped working and sonicare wont just sell you the handle. The force you to buy the entire product again. I'll be switching to Oral-B's product this time around.
  731. I'll admit it. I'm lazy when it comes to my teeth. Sure, I brush regularly but not for very long, and certainly not following the suggested charts of up and down and side to side for two minutes or more.<br /><br />That fact has sometimes bothered me, I suppose. I wonder about how much whiter my teeth could be. I wonder if maybe I'm inadvertently allowing problems to begin. But that laziness thing. It overpowers the worry and so I've gone my life with only the basics.<br /><br />But something bit me, and I decided to sink my teeth into something a little bit more helpful. I love gadgets and I was hoping that just that fact might be enough to get me to pay more attention.<br /><br />So I ordered the FlexCare. And I love it.<br /><br />A couple of key things are important.<br /><br />Is it easy to use? Absolutely. There are about five different settings but it's pretty clear which each do and why a person would use them. Also the most standard setting is default. So just turn it on and start.<br /><br />Even better it reminds you how to brush. Thirty seconds in each quadrant--top front/back, bottom front/back. The brush pauses when the thirty seconds are over to remind you to move along. After two minutes it turns off. Couldn't be easier to use or to use exactly right.<br /><br />This is my first electric toothbrush so I wondered how my teeth and gums would respond. No worries there. The brush has a 14 use warm-up to get to full power.<br /><br />The second factor is whether it works. It absolutely does. My teeth are whiter after a week. Of course it doesn't matter if it works if it's not handy. Not only is it easy to use and works great, it comes with a handy travel pouch, and is a breeze to use regularly. I actually (embarrassed to admit this) got a little giddy this week when I remembered, \\"I get to brush my teeth.\\" I want to use it. The laziness has been vanquished.<br /><br />The included UV light completes the package, helping make this toothbrush consistently clean and healthy.<br /><br />Not noisy at all. Easy on the mouth. Not even a little bit of splatter.<br /><br />Very much worth buying. My teeth haven't been this happy with me for a long time.y at all. Easy on the mouth. Not even a little bit of splatter. Very much worth buying. My teeth haven't been this happy with me for a long time.
  732. This is the first Sonicare brush I have ever tried and I'm kicking myself for not trying them sooner! The manual action of brushing teeth can get tiring sooner or later, leading to non-brushing. That, of course, is the quickest road to the dentist's, a place we all know and love.<br /><br />Well, after trying this toothbrush, I'm very pleased to know that the number of trips I will be taking to the dentist will soon rapidly diminish. Brushing with the Sonicare FlexCare toothbrush is a positive joy. I can choose from several modes (including GoCare, for when you're on the run, or MaxCare, when you have more time); I can even choose a nice, easy gum massage mode. These people have thought of everything!<br /><br />It comes in a nice package with two brush heads, one smaller and more compact than the other, several easy-to-understand manuals and a travel case and a travel charger, plus the main charger which houses a UV sanitizing unit. See what I mean about thinking of everything?<br /><br />The first brush with the Sonicare was an interesting experience because I wasn't expecting the feeling of a hypercharged, intensely vibrating bristles--I used the MaxCare setting. After I got used to it, I could actually feel the plaque-busting going on. Afterwards, I felt around my teeth and the gums felt great and very clean, even between the teeth without flossing. I've never felt better after a brushing, even with the Oral B electric brushes I've owned in the past.<br /><br />Highest recommendations if you want good, clean teeth and lesser visits to the dentist's.

I can actually see bits of plac when I rinse after brushing. The UV cleaner is an added bonus. I highly recommend this appliance. malaprop
  734. I love this toothbrush! I have never owned a sonicare toothbrush before but I have owned other rechargeable brushes and battery-powered brushes. Never before has a toothbrush made my teeth feel as clean as they do after a professional cleaning! I love the sanitizer feature too. I'm a bit of a germaphobe so even though I can't say for sure that it works, it at least makes me feel like my brush is cleaner. I love the fact that it is timed and shuts itself off once you are done. I think I do a better job of brushing with that feature. The unit is much more compact than I expected and not nearly as loud as I expected. The vibration of the brush does tickle a bit but you get used to it. If you are looking for a high-quality brush that will give you dentist-clean teeth, I definetely recommend the Sonicare FlexCare!

  736. இ Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary:<br />ѾѾѾѾ Recommended with warm fuzzies.<br /><br />I love how this thing cleans!<br /><br />The UV Sanitizer adds a high-tech functionality to the whole package, even though I cannot vouch for its effectiveness. I have always alternated between two manual toothbrushes, thoroughly rinsing each brush after use and letting each totally dry in between use, and I never had any issues with hygiene from contaminated brush bristles (heck, doorknobs, public drinking fountains, kitchen sink sponges, and shaking peoples' hands can carry far more germs.)<br /><br />ѾѾѾѾѾ Excellent 5-fuzzies feature ratings:<br /><br />ѾѾѾѾѾ The unit's design makes it easy to clean off toothpaste residue, there is not much vibration in the handle, and given the vigor of the brushhead's action, I do not mind the \\"bumblebee on steroids\\" sound of it. All of the different cleaning modes are highly useful for different users. It has a nice sleek look to its design - this is the toothbrush that George Jetson would be using before he starts his 3-hours-a-day workdays.<br /><br />ѾѾѾ Average not-good not-bad 3-fuzzies feature ratings:<br /><br />ѾѾѾ My first minor nitpick is that the brush should remember the cleaning-mode setting that you used last. I always use its MaxCare setting, a nice mixture of teeth cleaning and gum massage. And so instead of just applying toothpaste and turning the unit on, I have to first move the setting down to MaxCare each time before turning on the brush.<br /><br />ѾѾѾ My second minor nitpick is that at $170, the brush is a bit pricey for what it is. Yes, one could reason that it is worth the dental health benefits. But along with the $8 replacement brush heads, I image that Philips is making a tidy profit from their premium Sonicare model.<br /><br />ѾѾѾ My one major nitpick is that I see absolutely no logic in designing the brush to have a non-replaceable battery (other than purely for Philips' marketing/sales purposes of planned obsolescence). In this age where too many people throw too many things away, and where our nation's landfills are increasingly cluttered with plastic grocery bags and plastic water bottles being thrown away, this is a disposable product that could have been designed to not be disposable. I would have the same major gripes if Black&Decker designed their rechargeable cordless string trimmer and cordless drills such that I could not replace those batteries and I had to throw away the entire string trimmer or cordless drill after the battery could no longer properly recharge, or if Motorola's cell phones did not allow you to replace its lithium battery and required you to buy a new cell phone after its battery wore out. The cylindrical shape of the toothbrush would be perfect to use with two high-powered (and widely available and inexpensive) 2700mAh NiMH AA rechargeable batteries that one could insert into the barrel of the body, without too much added bulk added to the handle.<br /><br />௫ Fuzzy Wuzzy's Conclusion:<br /><br />This toothbrush works great and my teeth always feel awesome after using this!purposes of planned obsolescence). In this age where too many people throw too many things away, and where our nation's landfills are increasingly cluttered with plastic grocery bags and plastic water bottles being thrown away, this is a disposable product that could have been designed to not be disposable. I would have the same major gripes if Black&Decker designed their rechargeable cordless string trimmer and cordless drills such that I could not replace those batteries and I had to throw away the entire string trimmer or cordless drill after the battery could no longer properly recharge, or if Motorola's cell phones did not allow you to replace its lithium battery and required you to buy a new cell phone after its battery wore out. The cylindrical shape of the toothbrush would be perfect to use with two high-powered (and widely available and inexpensive) 2700mAh NiMH AA rechargeable batteries that one could insert into the barrel of the body, without too much added bulk added to the handle.<br /><br />௫ Fuzzy Wuzzy's Conclusion:<br /><br />This toothbrush works great and my teeth always feel awesome after using this!
  737. I tried a little different version of this toothbrush, the Elite 7300, and it just didn't compare. This brush has less vibration, and the battery is many times better. I can use this brush for about a week on a charge. The sanitizer is great too! It rids your brush of bacteria that can grow on your toothbrush head. I would recommend this to anyone! Of course I purchased it because it was my first electric brush but I just could not afford the Sonicare so to save a few bucks I got the Oral-B. Then a while later I upgraded to the Oral-B Triumph because it had the lcd, but it just looks better than the 8850, the 8850 is a way better brush than the 9400. I have not been happy with the 9400 so I have been thinking maybe I should just get a Sonicare. I always think about that video clip that shows them vibrating in the water & how the Oral-B barely moves the water & the Sonicare goes bananas! Well I had read the reviews before I purchased & remembered the tip to put the toothbrush in my mouth before turning it on because this thing splattered toothpaste like if the main artery had been slashed on the side of my neck with just my mouth barely open LOL I am sure with time I will get used the scary sound & tingling sensation. My mouth feel very clean. Just makes me think that I wasted alot of money & time on the Oral-B's, even though when I had them I did like them alot better than a manual toothbrush, having a Sonicare now makes Oral-B barely a step above a manual toothbrush. If you are a person that has always used a manual toothbrush and are contemplating getting an electric toothbrush for the first time, I know the Sonicare costs more that is why I first purchased the Oral-Bs but now that I have the Sonicare I would tell any friend or stranger that it is well worth the extra money.

  748. This has got to be the best toothbrush I have ever owned. I had a standard toothbrush before this and my mouth would start to feel unclean about halfway through the day. I prefer the compact ([[ASIN:B0013TVEYS Philips Sonicare ProResults Compact Brush Heads, 3pk]]) as I feel I get into hard to reach places better. The battery life is fine. It lasted about two weeks on a full charge with both my wife and I using it twice a day (usually on the max care cycle). That's about 56 brushes. The UV sanitizer is a nice addition as well. The toothbrush is a little loud but it is no where near as loud as some of the other reviews make it seem. I highly recommend this toothbrush. Your mouth will thank you for it. _________________________________________________________________________________________ UPDATE: Changed rating from 5 stars to 2. I have owned 2 of these brushes now and both of them have broken after about 1 year of use. The break occurred inside the base both times just below the brush head connection rendering the \\"sonic\\" aspect of this brush useless. I am now back to using a regular old manual brush. This product was great while it worked, but for as much as this product costs, it should last longer.
  749. This is the best Sonicare toothbrush yet. It has 3 settings. The default is like last years model in that it brushes for 2 minutes, broken up into 15 second intervals for top front, back, and bottom front and back. However this model has a max clean that adds 15 seconds to each interval with a more intense vibration. It also has a 1 minute cycle that uses the intense vibration for a quick brush. The bristles seem to be more stiff and really gives you the \\"just got my teeth cleaned at the dentist\\" feeling every time you brush. The UV clean kills any residue germs that might be left on the bristles. Overall a real professional toothbrush that makes your mouth feel extremely clean just like you came from the dentist.
  750. I first received this item last year before Xmas and I enjoyed it very much. During the time I've used it, I felt that it was giving me everything my dentist wanted. I like the UV Sanitizer and this is great for travel. The down fall of this product is really up in the air. Before I had this item for a year, it broke. I do a lot of traveling, and the item being damaged could be blamed on the careless acts of the TSA. Who knows, but when I arrived home that night I went to brush my teeth and noticed that the power on the toothbrush was very low. Being tired and not thinking, I figured that it was maybe because the battery was not charged. The next morning I still noticed that it was very weak. I let it charge again and that night I saw that it was fully charged. I ended up taking the toothbrush apart and noticed that the motor had been damaged. This could be just a flaw in this particular toothbrush, or it could be the TSA for smashing my bag and damaging the motor. Who knows at this point. I have a new toothbrush, same model, and I still love it. Give me that clean mouth feeling. I would recommend this item to anyone!
  751. I've been using Sonicare products for years, and this toothbrush is their best yet. My dentist loves the results! It's as if I get professional cleanings every day. I particularly feel good about the sanitizer feature, as I can only imagine what types and quantities of germs normally cultivate on the head of a used toothbrush.   752. Being a dentist I have used just about every toothbrush out there for free or next to free. I have gone through everything from the old manual ones to the so called best electric ones from Oral B and Sonicare. After using both the Oral B and sonicare I must say that sonicare has to be the best toothbrush out there hands down. It takes some time to get used to, about a week or so, but after that you will love it. I clean teeth all the time with professional dental instruments consumers can not buy and this toothbrush is the only thing that comes close to the thoroughness of specialized equipment. The timer function is nice because it forces you to break up your mouth into 4 quadrants and brush every area for a full 2 min which is what is recommended. I believe that there are areas in ones mouth you can't possibly clean with a manual brush to get the majority of plaque off. This brush picks up the shortcomings of your hand motion with its oscillation almost doing all the work for you. I also believe that the UV sanitizes is a big marketing scam, its nothing more than a fancy brush head holder that can give you a blue light show when you push the button. In my opinion UV light is not sufficient to kill as many microorganisms as they seem to claim. Just rinse/soak the heads in Listerine if you are that much of a germ a phobe. The little traveling case is fantastic, I can go on trips for days and it fits snugly in my bag and does not need a charge for days. In short I highly recommend this brush to all my patients, especially those with many fillings and crowns/bridges. Combined with good flossing and mouth wash I feel this is the best you can do at home until you come in for a dental visit. It may not be cheap but its a sound investment in your mouth and is alot cheaper than what you will pay for dental work due to decay.

  778. I can not say enough good things about this product & the manufacturer.... where to start:<br /><br />I upgraded from an electric Oral-B toothbrush to this one and notice a major difference. My teeth are whiter, my gums are healthier and my whole mouth just feels cleaner. Random people comment on my &#34;white teeth&#34; and believe me... my teeth are not perfect.<br />Even my dentist and hygienist asked me what I am doing differently or if I am &#34;bleaching&#34; my teeth - and I do not.<br />Because of my rave reviews of this product both my sister and mother have purchased it.<br /><br />Occasionally when I travel overseas for several weeks at a time and do not take it with me (even though it comes with a travel case and charger) I miss using it and actually look forward to coming home and having that &#34;clean mouth&#34; feel.<br /><br />I have owned this toothbrush for almost 4 years now. The warranty has run out and just yesterday it started making funny noises and seems like it's not working properly anymore. I talked it over with my husband and we immediately agreed we would buy a new one, because we like this one so much. Today I decided to call Philips to see if it would be possible to buy just a new wand (since the UV sanitizer and charging station still works fine) and they are sending us a NEW ONE FOR FREE!! Plus the customer service rep was so friendly and helpful. I am so happy.<br /><br />I say this and mean it all the time: This is the best money I have ever spent on any household product!

  782. I bought this toothbrush in the hope that it would reduce the frequency of painful cancer sores. My mouthwash suggestion is Biotene. it is expensive, but it really does the best job without hurting your gums.   798. I'll admit, this is my first electric toothbrush that cost over 20$. I was going to buy an Oral B Pro 5000, but these were on sale for much cheaper. The flexcare is the comparable model to the Pro 5000, so I went with it for that, and also because I try my hardest to avoid P&G products because of their tendency to test on animals. Granted, I know they're not testing their toothbrushes on animals (though, that may help with lab animal dental care!) it just seemed like a worthy plus for Sonicare.<br /><br />It arrived, the packaging was surprisingly easy to break through, and I set about to charging it for 18 hours... just kidding, that's what the package says but I ended up charging mine for about 6 hours before using it for the first time. What? I just couldn't wait!<br /><br />I had purchased two of these (one with the sanitizer) because I was unaware how easy it was to change brush heads. It's literally just one placement. No screwing, you just place the head with the brushes facing the \\"panel\\". Now I realize I definitely could have just gotten one toothbrush for my spouse and me to share. Unfortunately, I just don't feel like a good person returning a toothbrush for no other reason than my own disbelief!<br /><br />My GOODNESS! This thing is powerful. The first time I used it, I actually wasn't sure I was going to be able to handle it. I only used it for about a minute, gingerly pressing it to my teeth before pulling it back, and this was on the sensitive setting. What power! It's now been a week, and now I can make the full three minutes of the \\"Max Care\\" setting and I look forward to an extra thirty seconds or so on the massage setting, which I just run over my gums where they meet my teeth.<br /><br />Here's what the settings are from what I can tell.. max care is three minutes of alternating toothbrushing gloriousness. It alternates regular speed with the massage. The massage is formulated for your gums, so I'm not sure if there's any benefit to this being in your toothbrushing routine. Go care is a minute of the standard speed, which apparently is for those of you who can't spare an extra minute to brush your teeth. If you neglect to choose go care or max care, you apparently get 2 minutes of \\"Clean\\" setting with little breaks in which it's suggesting you move to another quadrant of your mouth.<br /><br />I initially thought the little breaks were because I was pressing too hard and it was automatically stopping for that reason, but no.. perhaps I should have read my manual instead of just assuming. I wasn't pressing, really. ;)<br /><br />After reading my manual, I also learned that my first time wasn't even as powerful as it could have been! Apparently for the first 15 uses it doesn't vibrate at full power in an attempt to get you used to the toothbrush. If you read your manual, you can find how to turn that option off. I also learned it doesn't even have a setting to alert you if you're pressing too hard. I thought that was kind of standard for expensive toothbrushes.<br /><br />Anyhow- this item has made my teeth so happy. They're dentist clean on a daily basis, and I had to use a regular toothbrush as I forgot to pack mine for an outing and was appalled at how \\"unclean\\" my teeth were.<br /><br />So...<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Gets teeth wonderfully clean<br />-Lightweight<br />-Aesthetically pleasing<br />-Simple operation, made even more simple by reading the manual<br />-Nice options and settings<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Nothing to alert you of if you are pressing too hard<br />-Price point could be considered high<br />-Very STRONG and something to get used to at first<br />-Creates a lot of saliva, which your husband WILL fling at your just-washed bathroom mirror<br /><br />All in all, I think it is the MOST WONDERFUL ITEM I'VE PURCHASED. Well. This week at least. Again, keep in mind that I have no electric toothbrush to compare this to.<br /><br />Now... as for the Sanitizer? I have no clue! I bought it considering the sanitizer is 20 bucks when you buy it alone, and only an extra 10 bucks when you buy it as part of the set (and it comes with 2 heads instead of just 1). So there, I got a sanitizer and an extra brush head for 10 dollars. I'm not sure if it's actually sanitizing the two brush heads, or if I'm even putting them on right, since they always seem to rest precariously on the pin. I just toss them in, and turn it on. Since I lived a toothbrush sanitizer free life before, I can only assume my lot has improved.ust 1). So there, I got a sanitizer and an extra brush head for 10 dollars. I'm not sure if it's actually sanitizing the two brush heads, or if I'm even putting them on right, since they always seem to rest precariously on the pin. I just toss them in, and turn it on. Since I lived a toothbrush sanitizer free life before, I can only assume my lot has improved.

  804. I absolutely LOVE this tooth brush. I've been using this tooth brush for about 3 years and love it as much today as I did 3 years ago. Prior to being a proud Sonicare owner, I used the Oral-B electric tooth brush. I went looking for a new brush for two reasons: one, the Oral-B brush heads always accumulated a gross slime inside of them, that really grossed me out. Who wants to put slime in their mouth when they are trying to CLEAN their teeth? Not I. The second reason I went looking for a new toothbrush, is that I really wanted a UV sanitizer for the toothbrush heads. Again, going back to not wanting to put something gross and loaded with germs in my mouth with the intention of cleaning. I solved both of these issues with this Sonicare, and much more!<br /><br />To begin with, there is no gross slime getting stuck in these heads, and the UV sanitizer is amazing. I have read some other reviews that mentioned that daily use of the UV sanitizer can be cumbersome. I don't find this to be an issue at all. It does take a full 10 minutes to complete a full sanitization session, but I just turn on the sanitation while I am showering and/or flossing- my regular morning routine, and by the time I am ready to brush, my heads are nice and sanitized =). Other reviewers have also mentioned that the brush heads need to be perfectly aligned in the sanitizer for the door to close, but I have never had an issue of them not being \\"aligned\\" correctly. I just plop um on the peg, facing any direction and they fit perfectly! The brush heads come in 2 sizes, small and large, and one of each is included in the package, and I use the large ones and have still never had any issue with them fitting in the sanitizer.<br /><br />Successfully meeting my 2 requirements for being happy with my new tooth brush, the Sonicare went above and beyond when it comes to the actual brushing. It truly is a revolutionary sort of \\"sonic\\" vibration. The Oral-B brush I used before just vibrated, this tooth brush seems to be a much more precise and advanced movement that vibrates with purpose. Its nearly impossible to explain the sensation of the Sonicare, but it truly cannot compare it to my old Oral-B. After using the this Sonicare for awhile, I went on vacation and grabbed my old Oral-B. When it came time to use it, I felt like the Oral-B didn't clean my teeth at all! If felt clunky inside my mouth, and the vibrating felt almost useless. The Sonicare really leaves my teeth CLEAN; like just after a dental cleaning clean feeling.<br /><br />I really like the different brushing mode options. 'Refresh' is the 1 minute option, perfect for when I am in a rush. 'Clean' is the 2 minute option, that I use most often. 'GumCare' takes 3 minutes, the first 2 minutes of this mode are just like clean, and the last minute is more of the 'massage' feature, which is a bit softer and is meant to use for brushing your gums. I use the 'GumCare' option at night when I have the time. Then there is the just 'massage' feature. All of these options have an amazing slight pause every 30 seconds, that you use to make sure you are spending equal time in each quadrant of your mouth. I know other reviewers have mentioned that the programming of the brush modes can be annoying, but honestly it is just pushing one button next to the name of the program you wish to use at that time. I know some people might want to set it for the one they like and have it always use that option, but me personally, I like to use different modes at different times, so it would annoy me more if it was set to one and I couldn't change it as easily as I can now.<br /><br />Another really cool thing about this brush is that it comes with 2 different chargers! One has the sanitizer attached to it, and the other one it for travel and does not come with a sanitizer. This toothbrush also comes with a travel case, and brush head covers, which is really cool. Also, the heads have a little plastic circle on it that comes in a few different colors, which is great for couples who share the toothbrush- each with a different color head.<br /><br />I am a bit confused about the difference between the NiCad battery and the Li-ion battery. The newer models have the Li-ion which is supposed to mean that the brush will run longer on a single charge, and won't develop a memory by leaving it on the charging stand. However, I had the older model first and noticed that the newer one doesn't hold a charge as long. However, I had to purchase this newer one because my other battery eventually died, so hopefully this one will have a longer shelf-life, even if that means more charges in-between.<br /><br />I love this toothbrush VERY much, and strongly recommend it to everyone. One more thing I have to mention, ever since I began using this brush, my dentist tells me at every cleaning that I am plaque and tarter free! I really believe that I have this tooth brush to thank for that. =)ifferent colors, which is great for couples who share the toothbrush- each with a different color head.<br /><br />I am a bit confused about the difference between the NiCad battery and the Li-ion battery. The newer models have the Li-ion which is supposed to mean that the brush will run longer on a single charge, and won't develop a memory by leaving it on the charging stand. However, I had the older model first and noticed that the newer one doesn't hold a charge as long. However, I had to purchase this newer one because my other battery eventually died, so hopefully this one will have a longer shelf-life, even if that means more charges in-between.<br /><br />I love this toothbrush VERY much, and strongly recommend it to everyone. One more thing I have to mention, ever since I began using this brush, my dentist tells me at every cleaning that I am plaque and tarter free! I really believe that I have this tooth brush to thank for that. =)

  819. Our periodontist suggested that we purchase the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush. He said that an ordinary toothbrush could not possibly perform as well as this one. When a person brushes manually, he does most of the work, but when operating a sonic toothbrush, the user must be careful to apply only apply light pressure, angle the brush so that it touches both the tooth and the gum, and move the brush slowly from tooth to tooth. There will be a period of adjustment for the average person who is used to putting extra effort into cleaning his teeth.<br /><br />The Sonicare FlexCare has a clear and thorough instruction booklet explaining each feature. The handle is comfortable, the on/off button is conveniently located, and there is a travel charger if you want to take the brush with you on the road. A fully charged brush will work for two weeks, but you may leave the brush in the charger 24/7 without causing any damage. For those who are nervous about germs, there is even a UV sanitizer to zap any bacteria that may have settled on the brush head.<br /><br />If you want to experiment with different brushing modes, there is a standard \\"clean mode,\\" a \\"sensitive mode\\" for a more gentle feel, and a \\"massage mode\\" for extra gum stimulation. There are also short and longer brushing cycles and a \\"Smartimer\\" that automatically turns off the toothbrush at the end of a brushing cycle. Having used the toothbrush for a while now, I find it refreshing, stimulating, and easy to operate. If you want to put your money where your mouth is, this high tech item would be a sensible purchase.
  820. Awesome! Since Optiva created Sonicare, I have bought their toothbrushes. Nothing comes close in competition. Then, I found that garbage tends to collect in the toothbrush heads and handle base, which bothered me a lot. This toothbrush delivers 2 items on my oral healthcare wishlist in one fell swoop. Bravo! Philips! I am impressed that a corporation the size of Philips actually listened to its customers. I am thoroghly impressed. No more gunk collecting inside my toothbrush and I can rest easy now that my brush heads are UV sanitized! I would spend $300 for this gadget. Also, it is fantastic that this has some useful programs ~ unlike its predecessors, which left you with like gentle and hard brushing (totally useless, in my humble opinion). Really great improvement over previous models. I suppose the next revision of the Sonicare toothbrush will be an ultra-sonic model?!?   821. DEVICE INSTALL/SETUP<br />The Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush required no complicated setup, simply removing the items from the packaging and plugging it in.<br /><br />MANUALS/DOCUMENTATION<br />I was pleased to find that not only does this product come with very informative, concise written instructions, but the manuals can also be easily downloaded from the Philips' website in PDF format. This is very handy for those of us who don't always keep up as easily with the printed manuals, or who prefer to be able to text search the manual for the information we need.<br /><br />FUNCTIONALITY<br />I have never used an electric toothbrush of any kind before, and although I've been intrigued by the idea for some time, I was a little nervous to use this one at first. Turning the toothbrush on for the first time didn't alleviate my nervousness much, as the device certainly SOUNDS powerful. To my relief, actually using the toothbrush was painless, although the first few times it tickled a bit. I have been using the toothbrush daily since September 21, 2007 and am happy to report that this product performs as advertised. In fact, my teeth feel and look as good as if I've just had them cleaned at the dentist's office. I'm brushing in half the time I did manually, and the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush is doing twice as good a job as I ever did with a standard toothbrush.<br /><br />The toothbrush is packaged with a number of items, including a travel case and a travel charger which packs in a toiletry bag much easier than the countertop charger with the built in sanitizer. Also included is two toothbrush heads, a compact size and a full size.<br /><br />I use the sanitizer faithfully each time I brush my teeth, but to be perfectly honest, I don't know how to judge whether the sanitizer is really making any difference or not. I love the idea of it, and I hope that it is truly keeping my toothbrush germ-free.<br /><br />I particularly love the massaging function on the toothbrush, designed to prevent gingivitis by massaging the gums. With just over two weeks of regular use, I can already tell a difference here. Using the massager stimulates the gums, making them stronger and healthier. The cleaning routine I prefer, the `MaxCare', includes massage in the routine for each tooth quadrant, making it easy to incorporate into your daily brush habit without extra effort.<br /><br />Speaking of the cleaning routines, there are two: MaxCare, and GoCare. I've tested the one-minute GoCare routine and found it acceptable for a rush job, but I much prefer to perform the full MaxCare routine, which runs through a 4-quadrant brush and massage cycle in three minutes. There aren't many times I can't spare my teeth that extra two minutes, and my dental health is important. After running through the brush and massage cycle for each of the four quadrants (upper front, upper back, lower front, and lower back), the toothbrush automatically shuts off.<br /><br />EASE OF USE<br />There are a number of buttons on both the base charger/sanitizer and the cordless toothbrush, but they are simple to learn and easy to use. After checking the manual once on how to activate the cleaning routines, I've not needed to consult it again for this information. The sanitizer activates with a simple push of the button on top of the unit and shuts off automatically when it completes the sanitizing cycle.<br /><br />QUALITY/DURABILITY<br />Of course, I'll be better able to report on this area in a year, but the product seems sturdy and built for long-term use, unlike some hardware which feels more like it is made for disposability. The product inspires confidence in me that Philips truly means this unit to last the consumer for many years, only needed to replace consumable parts such as the toothbrush heads periodically.<br /><br />VALUE<br />This area is the real kicker. I love the toothbrush, and find myself extremely satisfied with all of its parts and features, as well as the results of brushing with it diligently for almost three weeks. Is it worth the initial investment? I think that is a question better answered by looking at your own budget and how important your dental health is to you. The general person will not likely spend this much on a toothbrush, sonic or not. In fact, it is the pricing on these units that made me waffle over the decision to invest in one for the last year. Having used it, I am now confident that it is worth the price, and am looking forward to fewer dental visits, other than the general check-ups necessary. Again, only time will tell here if that is wishful thinking on my part or a true benefit.<br /><br />In the end, this is no doubt a luxury item for most, more likely to end up under the Christmas tree for those who are interested in a sonic toothbrush.<br /><br />QUICK RECAP - PROS & CONS<br />Easy to use - I adapted easily to the button functions on the unit.<br />Durable - the parts feel sturdy and built to last.<br />Pricing a little high for most - more likely a luxury expense or gift item.<br />Replacement parts - Brush heads are easily ordered through [...], but I am uncertain if they can be purchased in local stores. [[ASIN:B000WHNI2I Philips Sonicare ProResults HX6013 Brush Head Standard 3pk]]<br />Performance - Brushing with the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush leaves your teeth feeling like you've just had them professionally cleaned.it diligently for almost three weeks. Is it worth the initial investment? I think that is a question better answered by looking at your own budget and how important your dental health is to you. The general person will not likely spend this much on a toothbrush, sonic or not. In fact, it is the pricing on these units that made me waffle over the decision to invest in one for the last year. Having used it, I am now confident that it is worth the price, and am looking forward to fewer dental visits, other than the general check-ups necessary. Again, only time will tell here if that is wishful thinking on my part or a true benefit. In the end, this is no doubt a luxury item for most, more likely to end up under the Christmas tree for those who are interested in a sonic toothbrush. QUICK RECAP - PROS & CONS Easy to use - I adapted easily to the button functions on the unit. Durable - the parts feel sturdy and built to last. Pricing a little high for most - more likely a luxury expense or gift item.   822. I have to admit that I was quite a bit skeptical about the Philips Sonicare Toothbrush. I've used electronic toothbrushes (all battery operated) in the past, and never saw a compelling difference between using them versus the traditional 'manual' toothbrush.<br /><br />So, trepiditiously, I tried the Sonicare....<br /><br />The device itself was easy to install (you'll have to wait two hours after initially charging the unit before you can use it). The toothbrush comes with a handy gauge that indicates its charge. Using the Sonicare was extremely easy - there's a button on the back of the toothbrush unit that you have to press in order to activate the brush. One thing I quickly learned is to not turn the toothbrush 'on' with toothpaste before putting it in your mouth - doing so will result in your toothpaste lining the base of your sink instead of your mouth.<br /><br />The unit isn't overly noisy, at least to me. Brushing was easy, unobtrusive, and fairly comfortable overall. The smaller toothbrush head makes it easy to clean those hard-to-reach places - leaving my teeth and gums shiny and my breath fresh. One thing I like in particular with the Sonicare is that you do not have to apply any force while brushing. (The common cause for gums to recede is usually due to over-brushing). You simply move the toothbrush around, and the brush vibrations take care of the rest.<br /><br />There are 5 brushing modes you can choose from, including one for sensitive teeth. The package also includes a travel charger and a UV sanitizer, which kills any germs which may live on your toothbrush.<br /><br />For most people, this unit is overkill - but it is well thought out and works well for its intended function. I personally enjoy using mine and would recommend it without reservation.<br /><br />Update: my Philips Sonicare died last week. I called Customer Service up. They sent a new one out in 3 days (with no cost to me) and provided return shipping to send the old unit back. Excellent customer service!ellent customer service!
  823. The Sonicare FlexCare has a mind / programing of it's own which for me is a good thing. Sometimes I'm in a rush to head out the door and don't realize how little I did actually brush my teeth. With this toothbrush not anymore! It has timed programs and beeps to let you know to move onto the next section of teeth! I started with the sensitive program which found out later by reading more of the manual it actually increases the level of sensitivity over the course of 14 brushings! I love that it's not harsh on my teeth which I consider to be sensitive (It wasn't until the age of 31 that I had my first filling). It says it leaves you with a Dentist office clean which I agree whole heartedly and in my case without any of the pain that I would typically be in from keeping my mouth open and having them clean my sensitive teeth! I like how the toothbrush head and handle is small, actually smaller then the manual toothbrush I had been using! I have a small mouth so it's great! I feel better knowing it has the UV Sanitizing feature which kills 99% of germs on the brush head! Overall I'm extremely surprised and happy with this product and believe I'll be looking forward to a shorter cleaning time at the Dentist Office!
  824. UPDATE - Two Years Later<br /><br />It's been more than two years with the Sonicare Flexcare for me and more than 10 years using Sonicare toothbrushes exclusively, save for trips where I took a non-electric standard toothbrush with me. I can say that it's time for me to move on and move back to the world of non-electric toothbrushes, and hence lower my original score of a 4 to a 3. Let's see why:<br /><br />Durability: this is an issue that bothers me because the handle with the soft rubber began peeling/coming off after just a year of normal use. When I received the Flexcare I wondered about durability of the soft handle since I knew from using previous Sonicare models that the hard plastic handles were very durable, and only yellowed over time. A $150 toothbrush should not look like this with normal use.<br /><br />Other issues: another issue I have is that the timer is only for two minutes, though this is the case with nearly every electric toothbrush, two minutes is just not enough time for me. Another issue is cleaning the Flexcare which is as much a chore as it was with previous models. Finally, the quality of the brusheads appear to have changed when they went to the brushead indicator rather than the sticker expiration date system. Finally, the brushead is just too small for me, though it is nice that I get to feel when I brush each individual tooth.<br /><br />High points: Customer service is top notch. I had two minor issues and they were ironed out very quickly. Unlike many reviewers, aside from the cosmetic durability, I had no problem with the toothbrush. I also had no problem with the battery life and I think this is key - I NEVER KEPT THE BASE PLUGGED IN. No matter what others say, it seems that keeping the Flexcare on the stand will diminish battery life. Finally, the toothbrush works and I believe that sanitation system also works.<br /><br />Why I'm moving back to a regular toothbrush: that said, the cost of the brusheads is just too much, cosmetically the toothbrush is done, and I've come to the point where I feel that this toothbrush offers nothing over standard toothbrushes. A few times over the years I used a Swissco brand toothbrush and recently began using a Radius Original toothbrush three times a day. The size of the head is huge and the bristles much softer than the Sonicare. After using it for a few months, my dentist noticed that my teeth were as good as when I was using the Sonicare - plus the Radius lasts me 9 months, 3 times longer than each Sonicare brushead. I'm not sure what the verdict will be in the longrun, but I feel that if I continue to brush for at least two minutes, there won't be a difference. While I enjoyed my time using Sonicare, I feel at this point it is a luxury and doesn't offer me anything more than a standard, albeit special kind, of toothbrush.<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW<br />I had two Sonicare Advances that lasted me eight or so years, then I took a three year break and used a manual toothbrush. Last month I bought the Flexcare and the improvements over the Advance are drastic. The brush is contoured, the unit is easy to grip and light, and there is no moldy gunk buildup anymore because the brush head snaps onto the brush.<br /><br />I'm taking a star off because the unit is a little loud when I'm brushing, but there is almost no vibration, so I guess that is the tradeoff. Also, I could have done without the UV Sanitizer, but I do use it at least once a week, especially when I have a cold.<br /><br />Also, customer service is really excellent. The little Phillips logo on the travel case arrived broken, and when I contacted Sonicare, they said they would ship me a new one out for free without me having to send my broken one back. The customer service representative even called me back when my phone lost reception. Overall a great brush and company, Sonicare makes brushing fun!
  825. My dental hygienist had recommended that I get a Sonicare several times. When I finally followed through, I was very pleased with the results. Yes, it's an investment, but worth it. It takes some getting used to, but after several weeks, I love it. Gets my teeth sparkling clean every day. Now I don't have to wait months to achieve that super clean feeling that comes from a dentist visit!
  826. I've been using Sonicare toothbrushes for many years with very good results as asserted by my dental hygienist. I've just purchased this new model, and 'wow' it's even better!! The cleanness of your teeth and the massage in your gums are much superior. I love to brush my teeth with this new model. Believe me, it is worth to pay more for this model than the Elite. I rarely use the infrared receptacle (sanitizer). So, I'm buying another one for travel without it. You may consider doing that to save you some bucks. Suggestions for Philips/Sonicare: - I would love if Philips would launch a simplified model. I just use the \\"clean\\" mode, and sometimes I accidentally touch the button and change to other modes (boy, even to brush my teeth I need so many options?? Can't life be easier first thing in the morning??). - I would love a battery (double AA) operated model since I travel a lot, and it's great not to have to worry about voltage and outlet compatibility (and not carrying a charger). - This model is so superior to the other Sonicare toothbrushes, that I would suggest Philips stopping making them, and reduce the price of this one.
  827. I read the previous customers review of this product, and it does not do this product justice. My teeth have lightened dramatically, and are dramatically cleaner. I will never use a regular toothbrush again (except to clean the toilet).

She told me that the difference is not comparable. Therefore, I knew it was time to post a review for this product. You'll probably like using one.

  838. I upgraded from an Advance 4000-series, for three reasons: battery was dying, gunk in head was awful, the base was getting calcified and difficult to clean even with CLR. The FlexCare has so many positives. Everyone has listed them here, and I can't add anything new. The design is wonderful, the gunk is 95% reduced, the charger base is nice and small. However, it doesn't clean as well as the Advance. The nice large brush area on the Advance just BLASTED my teeth clean. For four years my dentist was amazed at how clean my teeth were (and I barely flossed). On the other hand, the Flexcare's much smaller (and spikier) head just doesn't clean as well. I have a quadrant in my mouth that the brush just won't clean, and as a result I have significant plaque buildup in that quadrant. I've tried different angles, sequences of brushing, different gels... And the other quadrants collect food much faster than before. All my teeth remain smooth only until the next meal. With the Advance, they'd be smooth and shiny all day. I'm also flossing nightly now, because the brush doesn't get between teeth the way the Advance did. (I have also used Listerine twice a day sine 2002) Overall, the brush just seems wimpy. I like the reduction in noise but I miss the invigorating blast of the Advance. My dentist noticed immediately after only a few months of the new brush. All quadrants needed to be scraped, compared to zero with the Advance. I wanted to hard to give a 5 star review, but the brush is simply not working. I've taken to scraping my own teeth every couple of weeks. What am I doing wrong? I'm stuck with this expensive brush.
  839. This was Sonicare's last chance to earn and keep my business...and they blew it. This particular model was in some ways a big improvement over their previous design...more streamlined and not prone to gunking up. Very simply it worked great in all respects right up until it stopped working. The first symptom after just 45 days of use was the the brush head would no longer seat properly...causing the brush head to vibrate off. Next after about 60 days the brush stopped moving. It did't appear to be a battery issue as I could hear the internal motor humming...it was just not engaging/driving the brush head anymore. This device is WAY to expensive to have these kinds of issues in the first year...let alone in the first 90 days. I don't have time to chase down warrenties and mail this back to get fixed. I simply ordered an Oral B and won't go back to Sonicare.

  849. The number of options available with this toothbrush is wonderful. Also the cleaning apparatus is a great addition. I would have liked to receive a docking station that would hold 2 brush heads, as my husband and I both use one Sonicare and switch out the brush heads.
  850. First, let me preface this review by stating that since the early 2000's I have been a user of the Sonicare line of toothbrushes. Their cleaning capabilities is second to none and they are an excellent choice for teeth and gum health. So then, why the 1 star review? So that Phillips will pay attention to a glaring design quality issue in their FlexCare models.<br /><br />Unfortunately, the reliability of the Sonicare toothbrushes has dramatically declined since the release of the FlexCare series. I personally have gone through two toothbrushes in four years. That is unacceptable when considering the cost of the units (~180 per unit), and when considering the lifespan of my previous and my wife's current \\"e-Series\\" Sonicare toothbrushes (at 5+ and 6+ years respectively).<br /><br />The Sonicare FlexCare line of toothbrushes, out since 2008/2009, uses a significantly different design to attach the brush heads to the handle:<br /><br />* In the older e-Series units, the connection was performed via a screw top connection to the handle. The vibration was generated internally in the handle and transmitted to the brush head by means of metal feet in the brush head, resting on the top of the interior of the brush handle. This made for a robust, and reliable connection.<br />* The newer FlexCare series has the vibration carried externally to a metal pole, which then slides inside of the brush head. This new design has several internal attachment pieces that hold the metal rod in place. This system of internally mounting the metal vibration pole is much more fragile than the previous system and is the weak link in terms of reliability.<br /><br />Over time, each of my purchased FlexCare model Sonicare toothbrushes has had its internal mounts snap, causing a significant loss of vibration and cleaning power, with a simultaneous increase in noise. It took 2 years in the previous unit, and 1 year in the most recently purchased unit. This lack of reliability makes the value of the purchase decrease dramatically.<br /><br />Given all of the above, if you can, please steer clear of the FlexCare units and purchase the older e Series units instead. They provide the same level of cleaning power, but with the added benefit of much more reliability over multiple years of use.e value of the purchase decrease dramatically.<br /><br />Given all of the above, if you can, please steer clear of the FlexCare units and purchase the older e Series units instead. They provide the same level of cleaning power, but with the added benefit of much more reliability over multiple years of use.
  851. My toothbrush was great initially but then started turning itself on and off throughout the day without provocation. And believe me, when it's 4am and your toothbrush starts buzzing like crazy from the other room, it is REALLY ANNOYING. Do yourself a favor and buy a different brand. Sonicare does NOT stand for quality.

  855. I've been using Sonicares for almost a decade now. The last one that I had was the Philips Sonicare Elite e7300 and I liked that even more that the first one that I had. Unfortunately I lost that on a business trip so I was in the market for a new toothbrush. I got the Flexcare a few months ago and I like it even more than my previous Sonicares. It's great, thoroughly cleans your teeth and there are a couple of additions that make it just that much better. The UV sanitizer is a nice feature. The other thing is the new brush head design. Instead of screwing the brush head down onto the base this Sonicare has a brush head that clicks onto a metal fitting that sticks up out of the base. As a result it's much easier to clean that previous models, which would be my only gripe about them. If you are looking to replace your old one or want to get an powered toothbrush I would recommend.

  857. I use the brush twice daily, in the morning and before the bedtime on full 2 minute cycle. I charge it once a week, otherwise it lays on my vanity counter top with the brush covered. In the last 2 month I feel my teeth clean and gums healthy. I registered the brush with manufacturer and so far there were no problems, except when I press brush too hard to the gums, and it slips, then I relax the pressure and it resumes operating.   858. I have been using the FlexCare for a little less than 2 years. It has done a superb job of cleaning my teeth and massaging my gums. I am so pleased with its performance in those areas. Its mechanical durability has been another issue for me, however. I am about to return my second FlexCare toothbrush. My first one lasted only several months before it broke down. The second one lasted about 16 months. When the first one broke down, it just started making a strident noise and then failed. I returned it and received a replacement. Now, the second one failed in the same manner. I understand that this type of failure can be an issue with the FlexCare -- particularly if the user switches from one mode to another while the brush is running, e.g, from \\"clean\\" to \\"massage\\". Unfortunately, Phillips will not replace my broken Sonicare with the cheaper Essence or even the earlier Elite, although I would prefer one of those products. So, I will receive another FlexCare -- my 3rd in less than 2 years! (Customer Service has been very good about replacing the failed toothbrushes!)
  859. This appliance works exactly as they state. My teeth and gums feel and look great. It took me a couple of days to not move the brush and to let it do the work. Thought at first I wouldn't be able to stand the \\"tickle\\" on the roof of my mouth but quickly got used to it and it doesn't bother me anymore. The timer helps make sure you take enough time in all quadrants. Another nice thing is that you use very little toothpaste and will save money on that purchase. The battery lasts a long time so I don't keep mine plugged in. I highly recommend this unit.
  860. I've been using an electric toothbrush for around 5 years. I thought that was steps above using a regular toothbrush, but I was in for a surprise with the Phillips brand electric toothbrushes. My teeth feel extremely clean after use and I like that you can choose your style of brushing. Very easy to use - like that everything can stay clean with the toothbrush covers and the UV sanitizer. Some people have complained about the noise, but really - you are brushing your teeth - does it really matter? Love, love, love this toothbrush!
  861. This was my 2nd toothbrush Philips Sonicare Flex Care. The first one stoped working after 6 months, and I thongh that my son broke it. I bougth a new one becouse I love it. but it only worked for 3 months. I couldnt even use the brush replacement. I was taking care of it more carefully than my car. so this cost me about U$5 per day for use.
  862. I love the cleaning this toothbrush provided when it worked. The problem with this style brush is that it vibrates itself apart. There is a small metal shaft that the brush head is mounted on that provides the &#34;sonic&#34; vibration when you brush your teeth. The problem is that it eventually vibrates itself out of the mount down int the brush and once that happens you have to throw the brush away.<br /><br />Calling CS for Sonic Care I found out this brush is non repairable. After finding that out I decided to dissect the brush and that's when I found the problem. The metal shaft has a ridged end that gets pressed into the socket that makes it move. It eventually wiggles itself back out of the socket and can not be pressed back in.<br /><br />My first brush lasted 9 months, the second about the same. I almost gave up on this manufacturer even though I found it superior to the Oral brand brush. I decided to give it one more try but with a different model, the one that has the large bottom to the brush head that you screw on. Well its been a year and no problems so far.<br /><br />If you are considering buying this brush, save yourself some money and buy the cheaper model.
  863. I bought this because it was one of the better, yet slightly cheaper electric tootbrushes on the market. I tend to get cavities often (soft enamel maybe?) and my dentist said that an electric toothbrush would help (along with more regular flossing and rinsing). I did like this product, the brush heads were a good size and the battery kept a charge for several weeks. But, the two year warranty ended 3 months ago and all of a sudden the battery died. Since it's a recharchable lithiom ion battery I expected better longevity, especially for an investment of over $100. It's obvious that this product was made to last only until the warranty expires, then you have to shell out another $100. Wooo capitalism.....
  864. My dentist likes the condition of my teeth & gums, so it works well!<br /><br />The switch on the UV sanitizer failed on my old one after 7 or 8 years, so I bought another. New motor is a bit quieter than the old one.

  866. I purchased this item in July, 2011. Within a year it started to vibrate slowly, and now it turns on and off automatically. It is very annoying.<br /><br />The worse part is that the 2-year warranty, advertised in the description, cannot be verified unless one keeps the receipt. The agent said: \\"Since, you do not have the reciept I will suggest you to purchase a new unit.\\" I asked why serial number does not suffice, and the agent replied, \\"we only need the reciept to validate the warranty\\"<br /><br />Seriously? Am I expected to pile up receipts from every single purchase that I make?

  873. This is the second one of these I bought. It broke due to my own clumsiness. I dropped the rechargeable handle once on a carpeted bathroom floor and the metal prong to which you attach the toothbrush head was never the same afterward. I bought the same model as I had before, though I probably could have gotten a cheaper one. We wanted the ability to \\"sanitize\\" the brush heads in the little capsule but honestly, I have no idea if that makes much of a difference at all. All I know is, a pretty blue light comes on when you hit the button. For all we know, it's a waste of money to spring for that feature.<br /><br />Without a doubt this system has made a difference in our family's dental checkups, but I want to warn you how delicate the unit is.   874. My Sonicare FlexCare RS930 broke only after 1 year and 5 month use. That is unacceptable for such an expensive product. I was expecting to get at least 2-3 years of usage before replacing it. My guess is an internal part broke that connects the motor to brush shaft. Anyhow, it is a piece of crap! Do not purchase this product if you want something to last more than 2 year or so.   877. I purchased a Sonicare from my dentist, many years ago. After sometime, it stopped working so I call Philips. They sent me a new one and requested that I send my old unit back. I did that. It seems that since I did not register it, although I thought I did and that I don't have a three year old receipt, they told me to buy another one at Target or Walmart. They will not back their product in spite of the fact that the issue of turning itself on is well founded on the Internet. I was told by the representative that my model is out of warrenty....it is an older model and it may have been damaged by sudden power surges one experiences in a storm.<br /><br />Unfortunately, I just purchased seven new brushes for this toothbrush and now have to either buy another one at Target, Walmart or Amazon or throw my money out the window.<br /><br />Think long and hard about purchasing this toothbrush AND keep your receipt AND register it. Funny how Philips has no record of my previous exchange even thought it only happen about two years ago. So, even if one keeps the receipt and registers the producy I doubt Philips would back their product even if you have all the supporting evidence.

  883. I bought this toothbrush on July 8th, 2012. It worked amazingly for about two years on the dot, then mysteriously started acting crazy. I guess the toothbrush had other ideas, though, because now it won't even turn on when I press the &#34;on&#34; button. Or sometimes it does turn on, but then it won't turn off. It's pretty much gone insane, even though I took great care of the handle for the two years I owned it.   892. I upgraded from an old Sonicare I got from Costco, wanting to upgrade the type of brush head. This product is definitely an improvement. It's easy to clean, compact and sleek, and very powerful. It took a week or so for my mouth to get used to it but now I can't live without it. I love the UV sanitizer, and use it every few days or week. Even though I can't say for sure that it's cleaning or protecting from bacteria, it definitely makes me feel that it's sanitized. And it's great that they have a 30 day guarantee, in case it doesn't work out.
  893. I love this. I hate going to the dentist and I hardly ever go, I don't floss, I don't use mouthwash, and to be honest, I'm not great about always brushing my teeth before bed. Bad oral hygiene, I know. I'm not proud of it. However, last time I went to the dentist, which was the first time in 3 years, I got a very clean bill of health, for this first time in my life! He didn't believe that I hadn't been to a dentist in 3 years. He guessed I had a cleaning 6 months prior, which I definitely did not! It's all due to this toothbrush, that's for sure.<br /><br />I've had this now for a couple years and it's been great, no problems, no complaints! The only thing is that you have to be sure to clean the thing every once in a while because it gets kind of gunky, and that gunk is nothing but bacteria. So I wipe it down with some vinegar, and that does the trick.<br /><br />I share this toothbrush with my husband. We just use different heads, and we use the UV sanitizer to sanitize each head after use. The bristles become a little too soft after a while, and then my mouth starts not feeling as clean, and then I know it's time to switch it out for a new one. I buy new ones at Costco or on Amazon.
  894. This is my 2nd Sonicare toothbrush and I'll never go back to a regular toothbrush. I feel like I get a professional cleaning every day.   900. I recentyl changed over to Sonicare after years using a Braun electric toothbrush. My dental hygienist recommended the change because she thought I would benefit from the different technology used by Sonicare. I really like the extra clean feeling on my teeth after using it but it seems to spray a lot of toothpaste and saliva all over my faucet and mirror, even my clothes. I never had this issue with my Braun and I think it's because of the sonic action of the brush. I also like the feature that santiizes your brush head after use. Very nice feature and easy to use. I don't use the different settings usually, just stick to the basic settings and don't really feel a difference between brushing and massage settings - they feel the same to me. Overall, very please, just wish it wasn't so messy to use.
